"Killers of the Flower Moon" is an ambitious and visually stunning film that showcases Martin Scorsese's masterful direction and strong performances, particularly from Lily Gladstone. The movie thoughtfully explores a dark chapter of American history, shedding light on the injustices faced by the Osage people. However, despite its importance and meticulous craftsmanship, the storytelling feels overly drawn out, making it difficult to stay fully engaged. The extended runtime, while intended to add depth, ultimately slows the pacing, making the experience more exhausting than immersive.
A masterfully crafted film that shines a spotlight on one of the darkest chapters in American history. Martin Scorsese delivers an intense and poignant narrative. 10/10.

Good performances and great production, despite some major core issues. The first 15-20min of the film is awesome. The production design was so accurate, giving the sense that the cameraman had time-traveled right back to those days and filmed real-life events. Scorsese lures you in, and you find yourself trapped, unable to look away as the horrors unfold... and keep unfolding... until you find yourself just as exhausted as Lily Gladstone looks in her final scene. "Killers of the Flower Moon" is a gripping historical drama showcasing stellar performances and an evocative narrative. One of the standout elements is Leonardo DiCaprio's transformation, achieved through prosthetics that alter his appearance dramatically, giving him a permanent frown reminiscent of Orson Welles. DiCaprio's acting reaches its pinnacle in a heart-wrenching scene where he processes the death of his daughter, delivering a performance that feels raw and genuine. Lily Gladstone, however, emerges as the film's most captivating presence. Her expressive eyes communicate a profound depth, keeping the audience guessing whether her character is aware of the sinister plans around her. Gladstone's portrayal adds an air of mystery and emotional weight to the story. Robert De Niro, as expected, is masterful, bringing a duality to his role as a public figure and a Mafia boss, blending menace with charisma. Supporting performances from Jesse Plemons and Brendan Fraser are equally compelling, with Fraser's physicality adding an intimidating dynamic to the courtroom scenes. Martin Scorsese's direction is exemplary, blending his signature style with historical authenticity. The film seamlessly integrates archival photographs and dynamic sequences, such as a memorable scene mixing rock and Native American music during a discovery of oil. The period setting is brought to life through meticulous attention to detail, from vintage cars to cultural nuances, creating a vivid depiction of 1920s America. The narrative also highlights racial tensions and the early days of the FBI, offering a sobering reflection on the era's complexities. Despite its strengths, the film isn't without flaws. Some editing choices, such as continuity errors and a broken 180-degree rule in a conversation, stand out as distractions. DiCaprio's accent, while period-appropriate, feels slightly forced and occasionally pulls focus from the story. At three hours long, the pacing falters at times, particularly in the early sections, which may lose some viewers' engagement. Emotionally, the death of Gladstone's character’s mother fails to resonate as strongly as intended, which detracts from the film's otherwise powerful emotional core. Additionally, DiCaprio's morally corrupt character may surprise viewers expecting a more traditional hero, ultimately shifting the narrative's emotional center to Gladstone. In conclusion, "Killers of the Flower Moon" is an ambitious film that succeeds in delivering a compelling story with remarkable performances and meticulous craftsmanship. While not without minor shortcomings, its powerful themes, exceptional acting, and Scorsese's visionary direction make it a memorable cinematic experience.

Another great film by the master craftsman, Martin Scorsese. It is unbelievable that he is still at the top of his game at 80 years old. The acting is great, especially in the case of Lily Gladstone. Her performance makes her an instant legend in my eyes. She was given the opportunity to show a wide range of her talent as Mollie Kyle. Robert De Niro, who is also 80 years old, gave one of his career best performances. Leonardo Dicaprio gave an exceptional performance as well. The cinematography is a thing of beauty! The signature Scorsese camera work is something to behold. The way the camera moves seamlessly through the house at a high rate of speed around the 44 minute mark is vintage Martin Scorsese. Him pulling off that shot with those mirrors on the wall is an impressive feat to say the least. I love Martin's cameo appearance at the end of the film. That entire sequence was a rather creative way to update the audience on the years that followed. Rather than simply using inserts, Mr. Scorsese chose to present the story in the style of a stage play, which was really effective, in my opinion. I love the final shot, which shows the resilience of the Osage people with the use of an elevating bird's eye view shot, showing the modern day tribe, dancing and celebrating, leaving the audience with something in the way of a happy ending. Killers of the Flower Moon is a great, yet dark motion picture that is even better upon a second viewing. I most definitely recommend this film. 95/100

It's a long movie, but absolutely fascinating. You would think that with so much time, the pacing would become boring, but that wasn't the case. With the editing, the acting, and even the narrative, it was always smooth and captivating. There was always something happening that caused shifts in the storyline, which kept me hooked throughout the entire journey. In fact, I would dare to say that I didn’t feel the three and a half hours. Literally, they flew by for me. The only thing that didn’t quite convince me was the way they presented the ending, because—although creative—it wasn’t entirely satisfying for me. Maybe they wanted to rush it, considering it was already a very long movie, but I would have been willing to watch another half hour just to see the successive events. Additionally, I’m very happy that Mollie survived and that all the scoundrels paid for their sins. By the way, I also find it fascinating that this happened in real life, and that it was the first major case handled by the newly established FBI under Hoover. It’s not like he had a good reputation, but—at least—in this case, justice prevailed, or something close to justice, since—it seems— they all walked free, regretting their crimes.

I'm honestly not sure if my problem with this movie stems from me first reading the book or that because it is a Martin Scorsese movie that means everyone thinks it's instantly good. Firstly, I'm not sure who decided that this story needed to be told from Ernest's perspective, but that person should be ashamed of their decision. The book was more of a murder mystery non-fiction, and if anything it was mostly from the FBI agent's perspective because it was based off his notes in the actual case. Ernest is a reprehensible, spineless tool, and although the movie demonstrates that at times, it very weirdly tries to get us to empathize with him as well. It makes it seem like he was just a man put in this position and things grew out of his control, but he knew from the beginning what the plan was and went along with it anyway. It also just seems like bad storytelling to me to lay out the perpetrators and plan of this murder plot right from the start, and have the audience watch the police/FBI fumble around while we know exactly what happened. This story was poorly written/adapted, and it doesn't matter that Martin Scorsese was the director or that the acting was amazing because none of that is able to fix a bad screenplay.

Based on a true story, Scorsese’s latest outing tells the tale of a 1920’s Oklahoma family that tries to “inherit” Osage Indian land by marrying the landowners and then murdering them. This was news to me, but yeah, that really happened. Apparently, something like 60 Osage Indians were murdered over the course of a decade in these schemes, leading the U.S. Government to change laws regarding inheritance of Native American land. Unfortunately, the film is just too damn long. Clocking in at three and a half hours, it takes an interesting premise and just drags it out to the point of being boring. This seems to be an unexpected consequence of the streaming era. In the old days, studios were a lot more demanding with filmmakers when it came to runtime. This ensured they could get as many daily showings in a cinema as possible. With more viewers waiting to stream films, runtime seems to be less important to studios, allowing filmmakers to indulge to the detriment of their own films. Leaving an hour of this one on the cutting room floor would have benefited this film immensely.

Speechless but not in a good way. The brutal story of how the Natives were victims of American colonialism and genocide needs to be told. However, I do not think this film did it justice. While it showed how truly awful people can be, well that’s all it shows. Only in the last 5 minutes showed the resilience of Osage people. The rest of the film is them getting gruesomely murdered, swindled, and being bred/married for money and to be ethnically cleansed/killed by their spouses. All the characters were truly one-dimensional with De Niro being as solely heinous and egomaniacal as the devil himself, and DiCaprio being very seemingly stupid and having no redeeming qualities. [SPOILERS AHEAD] … He goes along with and participates without needing much coercion from De Niro. He seemingly never has a moral dilemma to be honest to his wife or at least not POISON her. Sure he acted sweet in front of her while behind her back he was committing evil acts but to me it makes him less likable. Not only is he a murderous thief, he pretends to be a sweet loving husband while killing her family. The gratification of seeing justice to the bad guys is overshadowed by the long run time and unfortunately is not gratifying at all. We see Lily Gladstone’s character finally show some resistance to DiCaprio in the very end, and I like how she just walked away with poise, it was true to her character, but honestly she deserved much more. I cannot believe she didn’t kill him in that field but embraced him. There was no way she did not know he was guilty at that point. Particularly because she was well enough to meet him in the field. I know “rose colored glasses” but he was never that great of a husband and he killed your family and tried to kill you. She knew this I believe, otherwise that would make her very ignorant. She is the ultimate victim who loses truly everything. We only hope her life after this was peaceful, but we don’t know for sure. All we get is a obituary. We don’t know what became of the Osage people or how they fought back. Or how we could support indigenous people today

The first 2 or 3 minutes were interesting and all. Then, while the film has barely even begun, a montage of people dancing pops up. It's not accompanied by credits or any helpful information about the backstory, just music and dancing. I can't critique the rest of the film because I have no tolerance for this nonsense. I thought maybe the 3+ hour runtime might have been justified by a *story* that required that much time to tell. That may have been mostly true, but I'm not going to ffw a film just to "get to the good parts". That's basically selfserve censorship. I don't believe in censorship, not because violence, nudity and cussing are necessary to be included, but because they're part of the filmmaker's manner of communicating with the audience. If I'm in the middle of saying something and I get interrupted for using a word someone doesn't like, I'm probably going to just quit talking. If a movie is truly worth making, it should not be censored. If it's not worth making... Well, that's entirely subjective, but bottom line is I'm giving this film 3 stars for the benefit of the doubt because selfserve censorship is the only thing that could make this film tolerable.

The film certainly got more interesting in the back half, but the ultimate payoff was weak. I would have liked to see the villainous characters get what was coming to them. Instead, I got an innovative old-time radio show description of what happened to them. The presentation was interesting, particularly for someone who enjoys listening to old-time radio show podcasts. But as someone else noted, it was effectively a glorified caption. As I sit here now I realize I didn't feel a strong connection to any of the characters, not even Lilly. I simply didn't care. I didn't feel any emotion, which is a shame as the subject matter should have been deeply emotional. The movie gets high marks for sound, visuals (costumes/sets/etc) and cinematography. But overall, it's not one I'll ever return to, and there's very little from the film that will stick with me. Five years from now, it will be one of those movies I barely remember watching.

Killers of the Flower Moon is a crime western that is adapted from the book of the same name, telling the story of The Osage Murders and how the events occurred. The movie stars Leonardo DiCaprio and Lily Gladstone in the leads as Ernest and Mollie Burkhart. The movie also stars Robert De Niro, Brendan Fraser and is directed by the infamous Martin Scorsese. Just like many people going into this movie, I didn't know anything about this true story and these events that took place but the trailer intrigued me enough and after a few tries of watching this 3 and a half hour movie, I can happily say that this movie is what cinema is all about. The performances in this movie are no joke and are some of the best acting from an ensemble in a long time. The chemistry between DiCaprio and Gladstone felt so organic and natural, and when the intense drama took place, they both knew how to perfectly deliver their performances. The atmosphere and cinematography in this movie was beautiful, and the best scenes that showed this was probably the opening, or this one scene with an explosion. But most importantly, the story is incredible. I mean, the amount of detail that was put into this story when showing the different points of views and making sure to tell every aspect of the story with such dedication and thoughtfulness is what makes this movie such a masterpiece. The way Scorsese executes certain scenes with this slow pacing that makes up for it with world-building, and telling the story in a way where it's easy to understand and dissect, while also making it entertaining, suspenseful. emotional, and satisfying with the conclusion to this heartbreaking story, it's really incredible and inspiring to see such a true story be brought to the big screen in such a fantastic way. Overall, Killers of the Flower Moon tells a true and real story in an entertaining and suspenseful way, filled with intense drama, incredible performances, this a movie that will be legendary for sure. A-

Killers of the Flower Moon This epic western crime saga recounts the tale of the Osage people in 1920, whose newfound wealth from oil discovery on their land brought both prosperity and a wave of violence and death. "Killers of the Flower Moon" presents a grim examination of how individuals, driven by greed and cowardice, can commit heinous acts. Ernest Burkhart witnesses his uncle's ruthless killings of the Osage people for their wealth and becomes complicit in these atrocities. As the violence seeps into his own home, he remains indifferent, even contemplating ending his wife's life despite his love for her. Despite its lengthy runtime of three and a half hours, the film maintains tight pacing throughout. While it delves deep into the lives of the Osage people, it also explores the broader circumstances surrounding them, offering a comprehensive view of the events that shaped their lives. Leonardo DiCaprio delivers a fully committed portrayal of his character; Ernest embodies both heartlessness and cowardice with chilling authenticity. Robert De Niro, true to form, delivers a stellar performance. Lily Gladstone's portrayal of Mollie stands out as one of the 'daintiest' performances I've witnessed. Despite her character, Mollie, not delivering monologues or extravagant expressions, her gentle demeanor exudes life and commands attention effortlessly. She serves as a brilliant representation of the positive values inherent in her tribe. Martin Scorsese's direction is immersive, and atmospheric, and demands patience from the audience. With meticulous detail, he resurrects a forgotten incident, shedding light on it with painstaking care. While "Killers of the Flower Moon" may pose a challenge due to its lengthy runtime, for those willing to weather the storm, it offers a blend of education and entertainment. 8/10

Adapted from David Grann's 2017 nonfiction book of the same name, "Killers Of The Flower Moon" finds director/co-writer Martin Scorsese yet again pushing against the bounds of a normative runtime for the purposes of narrative scope and the study of American moral degradation. Like "The Irishman" before it, I'm fighting real hard to try and justify the length of this in my head, but it's just a little too long. Interestingly, though, this did feel a bit shorter than that 2019 effort, even with the two being roughly the same length. Could be this one had a livelier wrap-up, but I digress. What a well-realized epic this was. De Niro, DiCaprio, Plemons; all bring their A-game here, but make no mistake -- this was the Lily Gladstone show for me. The amount of strength, poise and stoicism that she brought to this role is so beyond impressive. So cool to see someone previously regarded as an "under the radar" indie performer finally getting some mainstream exposure and regard. Hope we'll be seeing her in more things after this. Honestly gotta recommend everyone watch this for the historical significance alone (even if you gotta do so in installments). Of course, it helps that one of the greatest living filmmakers is at the helm of things. Not a regrettable watch in any way other than having to witness the harrowing conduct depicted.

Adapted from David Grann's book of the same name that investigates the calculated murders of affluent Osage people at Osage County, Oklahoma, in the early 1920s, for their headrights to oil deposits, Martin Scorsese delivers a solemn moving eulogy that ends nimbly with a radio drama that recounts the fate of the characters and an overhead shot of a present-day Osage powwow dancing circle.

Opera mastodontica di Martin Scorsese che, come ormai sempre ha fatto nelle sue ultime fatiche da regista, crea un prodotto imponente senza minimamente curarsi della lunga durata. Ovviamente di prim'ordine la fotografia e la musica, di altissimo livello e senza mai pecche. La sceneggiatura introduce subito i personaggi e l'inizio della trama, con una fretta non del tutto in linea con il resto del film molto più compassato nei tempi e negli eventi. Storia assolutamente interessante ed unica, che merita di essere raccontata e che viene raccontata con immenso tatto da un lato ma allo stesso tempo con la giusta rappresentazione della ferocia e dell'avidità "bianca" dall'altro. Peccato, con il tempo a disposizione, non essersi addentrati meglio nella psicologia dei personaggi; scelta mirata che però viene parzialmente disinnescata da alcuni momenti effettivamente un po' lenti. Finale molto intenso ed emozionante, che rende giustizia al mastodontico racconto.

Synopsis : Une tribu amérindienne découvre du pétrole sur leur terre. Résultat, toute la tribu devient riche. Un américain rejoint alors son oncle, ami de la tribu, afin de planifier comment voler la fortune de la tribu. Leur plan : se marier avec leurs femmes et tuer leur famille dans le but de toucher l'héritage, puis recommencer. Durée : 3h26 Mon ressenti : C'est un bon film, qui malgré l'énorme durée, arrive à te tenir en haleine pendant 3h26. Il réussit notamment un tour de passe-passe scénaristique super intéressant de te faire détester le personnage principal sans pour autant te faire détester le film. Les trucs qui m'ont le plus maintenu en haleine sont : 1- Ma haine des actions des personnages et ce que l'argent leur fait faire 2-Quand est-ce qu'ils allaient enfin de faire chopper (car pour rappel, ceci est une histoire vraie) 3-L'espoir et la tension dans le personnage principal qui malgré ses crimes, a un bon fond, et donc peut faire une rédemption arc Ma note : 16/20, pas le film de l'année, mais un film important à voir pour sa culture historique et qui est aussi intéressant avec le contexte géopolitique actuel car tu te rends compte de à quel point un génocide peut se dérouler dans l'indifférence générale TL;DR : film d'enquête sur une histoire vraie, qui est très long, mais intéressant, je recommande 👍
