You probably don't like spoilers so I'll just say go see it. You may end up buying it on ebay like I did.
Long, Slow, Boring, Poor character development, Acting especially Robert D was painful at times. I have to admit I could not even make it to the end. Don't waste you time. Cure for insomnia

Martin Scorsese is amazing, the acting fantastic but whilst I feel the story should feel more mafia type, I got bored. It just passes because, objectively, it is a good movie, I just don't think it was for me

You must see it! The history and the story of this are unbelievable. Still, Scorcese did it beautifully- the soundtrack was great, the visuals were stunning, and the length of the movie was needed to tell this story properly and give it due respect. Lily Gladstone brought this story to the center of it all, stoically bringing these events to light. Well done, and a must-see for historical movies, one of the Scorsese's best!

Leonardo DiCaprio's character is so two-dimensional and his back-story/motivation pretty thoroughly unexplained. It's absolutely inexcusable, considering that they had over 3 hours in which to do so. Otherwise, the care and cultural accuracy to the Osage people and to this important story is excellent and important.

It doesn't need to be that long. Repetitive, lacks drama, no suspense. A 1 hour documentary would've been far more entertaining. It looked and sounded good and the acting was fine but it was still a very unrewarding watch. Everything was given to the audience on a plate from the start and we just had to wait 3 hours for it to finally play out. Zero rewatch value.

I got 1.5 hours in and I don't care about any character or plotline. There is almost no attempt at real character development. The relationships between characters are not explored in any meaningful way. This movie does a horrible job telling a story that should be compelling and meaningful. With the total runtime, the movie could have really gone deeply into a compelling story with complex characters. Instead, the time is wasted, and the characters are incredibly shallow, one-note avatars used solely to get through a very "and then" storyline. I expected much better from this director. These talented actors were wasted (but gave good performances with what they had).

I enjoyed it, saw another side if history I had zero idea about. However I think there might have been an error in hyping the movie as much as they did. The whole time I'm waiting to be wow'd. I was not. Good mood. Not great.

I don't understand why this movie was given such praise. If not for the director and huge actors no one would consider this a "masterpiece". Yet another band wagon film that viewers claim to love. Of course the acting is great, the cast is extremely talented, but that does not create a good film on its own. The story should be told but my personal opinion is that they really missed the mark. It might have served better as a documentary and not a feature film.
It was slow and boring. Not too mention it's just bad guys winning the whole movie. It was just really depressing watching such greedy people with no conscience and no appreciation for life.
This same story has been told time and time again. Acting was terrific as you'd expect from some of the stars but the stories just been done to many times. Didn't hold my attention.
Unreasonably long and slow. Could have benefit from good editing. The plot is given away at the start, and then on repeat for next 2.5 hrs to get to sth interesting.

3 and a half hours plus 10 Oscar nominations, it's really cool in the details of tradition, telling the brutal truth of history, the cruel heart of man, sequencing work that looks like it was in a real event. It's a pity that the investigative part would have added more issue, more complicated and vague than this.

Tremendous acting here, but an overly-long story that should have been severely edited way down from its 3 and a half hour excessive run-time. Asking moviegoers today to sit in one place for that length of time is kind of dubious at best these days when so many people would much rather watch this at their own pace in the comfort of their own home where they can pause this for bathroom, cell phone, and snack breaks. Love Scorcese and you get the very best from DiCaprio and Gladstone as expected along with solid work from De Niro in addition to some terrific cinematography and well chosen sound direction. The story though, much as I tried my best to really get into the characters and the main story-line, I really struggled to love this one and I think the tremendous praise thrown at it all over the media played into me going in with even higher expectations then usual for a Martin Scorcese film which it just never really lived up to. I do love most of all that this kind of vehicle is going to open doors everywhere now for actors like Lilly Gladstone raised in places like Blackfeet Reservations.

Martin Scorsese goes back to the cinematic triumph of Killers of the Flower Moon -- an epic crime saga based on non-fiction book details a series of gruesome murders of every members of the wealthiest Osage Nation in 1920's Oklahoma fueled by oil and greed.

The music underscoring - literally - this masterpiece remains in my head, as does the lead actress' Lily Gladstone's mona lisa face, robert de niro's magnificent evil, leo's road to ruin .. stunningly filmed in true 'cinema' style. Scorcese forever.

I heard the story of Osage before and was excited to finally see the film. The cast is truly great, the film was a disappointment. The characters are exaggerated and shallow, film unreasonably slow. It swings between kitchy American pathos and an eerie zombie movie. We didn't even finish watching it. There needs to be another take at the amazing story of Osage. Maybe a young native american director should give it a go.

Holy cow this move could have been an hour long and you still could get the point. Robert should just retire he is just awful. This movie was soooo boring. If you feel like you want to be bored out of your mind for three hours then watch this train wreck

A story with enormous potential wasted with a bad script. The film drags on for almost two hours, showing many scenes of everyday life and few of murder. So, the investigation, which is the most interesting part of the real story, was compressed into less than an hour of film. Finally, the ending, the staging of which would have been much more exciting to watch than the entire everyday life at the beginning, was narrated in a radio program that conveyed no emotion whatsoever. Overall, the image is given that Ernest Burkhart was more of a victim of his uncle than a criminal, which is a dangerous message. This film could have had an immense cultural impact if the story had been told from the point of view of the Osage, rather than their killers.
A Scorsese slow burn thar gnaws at you all the way to the end. While De Niro's accent is, well, not worth the attempt, the performances all around were noteworthy.
How to turn a great story into a boring and unnecessarily long and slow picture with expression-less actors and ridiculous soundtrack and flashbacks. Too much money to spend in the wrong hands.

Thoroughly enjoyed all the way through in a time when you feel anxious about the film length. When you think your uncertainty would be concerning justice, which you definitely are, you are truly engulfed by the protagonist's relationship and their feelings toward each other.

Extremely well done, although I thought it could have been less than 3 hours. I didn't care for the changes from the book, but the story is basically what people need to know. One of the horrors of American history.

Too long & too overrated. .. Big Cast, with a couple surprises: DeNiro seemed uncharacteristically nice as the evil ol' man. Plus hardly recognized Lithgow & Brendan Frasier. I dictated a lot of ruff notes, so see those. The scenery seemed authentic. What interested me was that my Grandpa brought the family up from North Texas, stayed a while in Oklahoma about then, befo on to L.A. Sawr it at 'lerton AMC soon after it came out.

The movie itself is a masterpiece: great acting (not only DiCaprio and DeNiro), great writing (the psychology of the characters is amazing), and very respectful of Indian culture. But the events it depicts are so awful, it makes the movie very tough to watch.

A sensitive and mature exploration of inter racial issues that still exist the USA and elsewhere today. Shot with characteristic Scorsese genius and precision and with brilliant characterisation. The sets and backgrounds all look good and expertly curated. Ocasionally quite difficult to watch because of the subject matter - but this film does make you FEEL. The film falls down on pace - the audience is ahead of the story much of the time - and the length makes for a tiring view. All told - excellent and, above all, important.

Recognizing one's limits is one of the greatest demonstrations of humility a person can give. Evidently this is a lesson that Martin Scorsese struggles to learn despite his venerable age, because his latest and interminable effort fully demonstrates what happens when a director embarks on the making of a movie without knowing how to manage its running time. Killers of the flower moon takes what would basically be a plot full of events, mysteries and food for thought and barely manages to give the latter away, staging various events stacked together in a manner totally devoid of pathos and sense of progression of the narrative. Many facts and things happen but somehow the more the minutes pass the more it seems that nothing has happened. The movie is simply correct, to the extent that: the acting, the direction, the photography and the staging are correct. However, there is not an acting performance, a scene, a line of dialogue or a shot that is memorable and a movie directed by someone of Scorsese's caliber is unthinkable that it is "simply correct". Every aspect of the movie is subdued and if this were to be a consequence of his directorial maturation, perhaps Scorsese should have taken refuge in directing a more intimate movie with a less gargantuan duration since he proves to be totally incapable of knowing how to manage it while keeping the audience's attention high from start to finish. Yet in the same year in which this movie was released we had in Oppenheimer a clear example of how the narration of events so distant in time from us can keep us in suspense for 3 hours. The difference between Killers of the flower moon and Oppenheimer, however, lies in the fact that Nolan did not have the same claim as Scorsese to want to teach new generations of spectators what the "right" way of making cinema is, without realizing that times are changed and that the way of making movies has changed. Scorsese's career has suffered no more or less the same decline as those comicbook movies that he did so much to denigrate: it began by entertaining crowds of spectators with countless memorable moments and is concluding with a series of products whose only memorability is linked to their anachronism. Because this too, dear Martin, is cinema and you are part of it.

I really enjoyed the film. With that being said, it could have been much better. It is just too long, and there were multiple scenes that drag and that could be cut down or cut all together. There were also moments in which I felt Scorsese was trying to be too clever with his camera movement, when it was completely unnecessary. It was noticeable and the story should always be the focus. But it is a compelling story and it is mind boggling that Leonardo DiCaprio didn't get an Oscar nomination for best actor. Definitely worth seeing, but I don't know if I'd ever want to watch it again.
i absolutely loved this movie it's worth the 3 hours i think this movie also has a good representation of indigenous peoples. this movie is one of the best movies.

Did they run out of money at the end of the film? The wrapping up of the story in that weird theatre format was just strange. During it I thought that editors and lighting people must be in short supply. It was very badly lit and it rambled on. I did like the Indian cultural references though but cannot see why it got so much hype. Indulgent - could have been good with stringent editing.

Killers of the Flower Moon - 7.3 - Big enough blockbuster of a movie to crack into my reviews. First of all this movie is simply put way too long. The story is interesting and flows well, but three and a half hours at the movie theater is just a lot to ask of any movie. Especially one that is very dialogue heavy and lacking direct like intense action. So going into the movie I knew absolutely nothing about this story, nor had I read the book. The story is very intriguing and keeps you engaged the whole time with how crazy it of a concept it truly is. Leo does he usual At work and delivers an epic performance. Himself and Mollie have a dynamic relationship and it really makes you feel for the story and feel there love for each other to make it so deceiving what was actually going on. It was like a murder mystery of the Osage people, but the point of view was from the point of the murderers. It really did feel at times that Leo did not know he was doing anything wrong. It really felt that he loved his wife, and that he thought he was just helping out his uncle. DeNiro plays his role well in his sinister Oklahoma businessman gangster type role. It is a story showing how greed and power can so easily corrupt people. The cinematography is great, and really immerses you in this rural area in such a wild time in American History. I would not say it is Scorsese's fast ball but it is definitely worth the watch. If this movie was even 1 hour shortly, it would have be night and day better. One thing I did not get as well, how were there not subtitles on some of the long native speaking parts. It felt at times entire conversations happened and we knew nothing what was said. Two Hours perfect, two and a half fine, but three and half is just criminal stuff. Official sundaynightstreaming rating of 7.3

This is a must see for any film lovers out there. DeNiro and DiCaprio are so good as usual and Lilly Gladstone was such a good surprise. This was the first time i watched a movie of hers and she was so magnetic, even without heer character saying much. What a trio of actors! Without getting into spoiler territory, i am glad this movie was made.

Great storytelling by Scorsese and an important part of history to learn more about. Love seeing so many great “character” actors given juicy roles, where as some of the bigger names have smaller (but effective) roles. DiCaprio and Lily Gladstone are great together- she has a stirring presence and the scenes with Leo and De Niro are perfection.
Don't waste your time with this one. It is boring from the first minute and doesn't get better. Hollywood self importance and self indulgence at its finest. Oof, that was a terrible movie.

Movie did not feel like it was 3.5 hours long. Incredibly tragic for the Osage people. I do wish they kept the same theme in finishing the movie. The ending was strange but overall the movie did its job in portraying the story of the Osage murders.
A wonderfully atmospheric movie with a tragic context. Great acting by the three main characters! A must-see. But the movie is a bit dragged out and gets boring at times.
Well, Gladstone was excellent. Dinero was Dinero and unfortunately DiCaprio is starting to be just like DiCaprio. Love Jesse but again I want to see these guys do something different and interesting.
I thought I would have to watch this movie over a couple of days because it's so long. That was not the case at all. It was so interesting and the acting was amazing! I couldn't stop watching it!!!

An amazing yet tragic film. Scorsese finds a way to bring this horrific untold U.S. historical event to life in a well-acted and written film. The cinematography and score are beautiful and can bring you into the film. DiCaprio and De Niro bring their A-game and are fantastic in each of their roles. As good as they were, Lily Gladstone's performance is the heart of the film as she brings the emotion and strength of the film. This is where the problem lies with this film, it should have been told more from her perspective as Scorsese tries to make you sympathetic to Ernest (DiCaprio) when he is doing these evil things. I think the film would have worked better having Molly (Gladstone) in the lead. At the end of the day, it is still a must-see film that you can't miss.
Frankly after loving the book, I was disappointed in the movie. The story and the investigation of the murders was so compelling that I expected more. It is long and plodding it still worth seeing.

Ploddingly slow. Could easily have been 45 minutes shorter without sacrificing any of the story line that was included. Full of Oklahoman and Native American stereotyping. The movie focuses on Leo's character, Ernest Burkhardt. It would have been far more intriguing for the film to focus on De Niro's character, William King Hale.

Was it good? Beats me :/. I made it 30 minutes in and yet again don't care about any of the characters, if they live or die. Write your movies better; with pace and an audience in mind. Edit your movie in case it's overly written and long. If it wasn't Scorsese would anyone have watched this?

It was a very. Very. Very. Long movie that I feel didn't need to be that long. The acting and story were good. But I feel like it could've been told an 2 hours instead of almost 4. It was decent enough but I most likely will never watch it again.

"Killers of the Flower Moon" unfolds an important chapter of history with captivating storytelling. Clocking in at 3 and a half hours, the film's epic scope might test your patience, but it's a narrative that deservedly demands attention. The Osage wealth from oil becomes a sinister backdrop, drawing in a conspiracy of corruption among guardians, judges, lawyers, doctors, and businessmen. While the runtime may feel excessive for a movie, the intricate worldbuilding and classic Scorsese touch make it a visual treat. Lily Gladstone's Oscar-worthy performance as a standout Osage character adds a layer of brilliance, stealing scenes effortlessly. Despite the slow pacing, the evolution into a full-blown mafia drama feels quintessentially Scorsese. De Niro and DiCaprio deliver solid performances, though Gladstone shines brightest. The soundtrack, deserving of its Oscar nomination, complements the immersive experience. The film's second act, albeit a bit sluggish, weaves a captivating narrative. A surprise cameo in the ending adds an extra layer of satisfaction, enhancing the overall impact. While some might argue for a shorter runtime, the engrossing storytelling keeps your eyes glued to the screen. A few casting tweaks could have enhanced the experience, but the film stands tall as a cinematic achievement. Oscars are beckoning, especially for Lily Gladstone, whose exceptional portrayal deserves the spotlight.

If you have 3+ hours to commit, this is a solid watch. I typically can't sit for long movies like this especially when it's an early, 1900's, setting. The character development was solid and it keeps you on the edge of your seat. Overall, good watch!

Scorsese is at the height of his powers, and the artistry of DiCaprio and De Niro is on full display, and astonishingly matched by Gladstone. Films like this are an endangered species not to be missed

Way overrated. This movie is too long by at least an hour. More to the point, it provides no particular insights into the Osage killings. It just ploddingly tells the story. Set design is a plus, but it's not nearly enough.

This very long Scorsese period piece is a tale of two halves for me. The first hour and a half or so are full of intrigue with DiCaprio's relationship expanding within the Osage tribe while a conniving Robert Di Niro makes plans to inflitrate them for his own gain. The second half sidelines a lot of the Osage and focuses on the Hales in a sort of courtroom drama swing that I feel was far less interesting than the focus of the first two or so acts. Still, another solid Scorsese historical drama with great performances and constant interesting camerawork.

What makes this movie disturbing is to know its based on history. Caused me to research after watching movie. That and Leo playing a bad person....... I know he doesn't always play the good guy, but this is a new character low. Good cast. Lily Gladstone was excellent & I hope to see her in more movies!!

Deniro and Dicaprio are solid. No one else stood out. Mollie character was too sickly to act much. Overrated by most on RT. Way too long. Good plot ruined by too much dead air. A 90 minute run time would have earned more stars.
Thankful for this story to be brought to the screen. One cannot stop to be amazed at how greedy humans can be. Watched it at the movie theater, and unfortunately I had to take a break to pee.
An assault on the human senses. it was fantastic up until maybe about an hour and 2030 minutes perhaps but beyond that it just completely dragged it out. there is like barely any dialogue
Great acting. Very impactful story. However, the movie drags and is far too long. If certain unnecessary scenes were cut, this could have been the best movie of the year.
Will go down as one of the definitive American epics of the 21st century. Evil has never felt more grounded, more real, or more close to us as it does here. A masterpiece.
Too long, boring and demoralizing. Poorly dramatized lacking any real friction between opposing forces until near the end. Overall dark and dreary and a low point for Scorsese.

Great book. Great historical non-fiction of a cruel time in Oklahoma. A sad but true tale of human greed. Poor depiction of the people of the days, 1920 post WW1...they took the 1920's and made the characters way too modern..

Really good movie, Jesus is it long. I hate to say it because I am all here for a long movie but it felt like I was watching an extended cut and I could have done with a little more editing and cropping. However the acting is really good, scripts are great and I very much enjoyed engaging with this story. I loved most of the characters…

This artfully scripted and performed movie reveals an unknown darkside of American history. Performances by Lily Gladstone added an authenticity that swept me into the time and its events. DiCaprio was also flawless. If you are looking for light entertainment, this movie is not for you. If you are looking for a masterpiece that will stand the test of time, educate and elevate your perception. Go for it you won't regret it.

It only loses half a star due the extended running time of the film. We watched it over two nights, which I wasn't sure was going to work but it really did. It really does deserve all the hype, Lily Gladstone is so captivating. I am sad Leo didn't get an Oscar nod for this but happy Robert de Niro is being recognised for his amazing performance.
DiCaprio's performance is "Oscar worthy" The movie is long but needs to be in order to tell the whole story. Worth the 3 1/2 hours.

Good movie (acting, directing, etc.), but... With good movies, I often feel they should be longer to tell more of the story. With KoFM, it felt like they went 1.5 hours too ling to tell a simple story.
"Killer of an Afternoon" is more like it. The movie is okay but easily 1.5 hours too long and several accents seemed off… not sure what they were going for. A documentary would have been better.

An extraordinarily powerful and emotional examination of greed, corruption and exploitation, well outside Scorsese's familiar New York stamping ground, but dealing with themes common to all his films. It is stunningly well designed and photographed, and features great performances from DiCaprio, De Niro, newcomer Gladstone and Jesse Plemons. It is very long and might be best enjoyed in chunks. Astonishing that Scorsese could produce such fine work at his age.
I don't understand the good reviews. It looked to me like people acting in a film on a set. Not authentic. Contrived. I only lasted 45 minutes. This was not De Niro's best work.

Yes, it's a long movie. Very long. It's also rather slow in many areas. I've split it up across 3 evenings. That being said, it's not a Marvel et al movie, and makes no pretense of being so. The setting and story line require a slow pace. I'm pleased with how it's turned out so far. Am watching the last half this weekend. Definitely worth the watch, just approach it as more than the usual weekend entertainment film and you'll be okay.

It was a little too long for a movie in which there's little suspense. That doesn't mean it wasn't well done and well acted. And I'm giving it an extra half star for having Jason Isbell and Sturgill Simpson in it.

What is so great about a way too long movie centered around dimwitted Ernest? I also don't see how Lilly Gladstone won any awards... her emotional makeup was about as flat as a pancake. It's quite unfortunate that what was a horrific episode in our history ended up as such a snoozefest.

Killers of the Flower Moon is a brutal watch that makes you pay for all the beauty in it. Like watching a historic boxing match where both the fighters a destroyed and bleeding, but all long putting on one hell of a show. It was absolutely worth the wait and hype. The set design is flawless and Lily Gladstone's gift stands out amongst some of the best actors in Hollywood. A must see!

Look, it's a good watch definitely and it doesn't drag, which is impressive in 3.5 days of film (sorry, hours). So why only 3 stars? Well the story is nothing special as you know what's going to happen, what things are going to come to a head. Sure, it builds well but there are no twists, nothing unexpected, it's all pretty linear. Good but you'll never need to watch again.
An epic for the ages. Great historical drama based on true events. Impressive acting by its heavyweight stars, and relative newcomers alike. Scorsese hits it out of the park once again.

Was an hour to long. The film was one of the worst by the director and worst I have scene in a long time and I see a lot. Leonardo Caprio acting was bad this time. Best to watch on a steaming service than paying full ticket price.

A gorgeous cinematic experience with a gut wrenching story ultimately betrayed by the ego of Director Martin Scorsese and his inability to contain his vision into a reasonable running length. Unbearably long.
Es una peli muy divertida me encanto la trama y la comedia que se maneja es muy interesante por qué te traslada a emociones muy diversas

The beginning dragged, and then the ended went way too fast. Like someone just stood up, clapped his hands, and said "alright does this up guys!" Didn't bond or care about any of the characters. I really wanted to like this, but just didn't.
It was a good movie and it should have been made about the topic, but it could have been a lot shorter. It dragged along.

This is the third Scorsese film I gave 4.5 stars to. Maybe he is becoming my favorite director of all-time, and I haven't even seen his top five on Letterboxd. With Killers, he remains standing strong and tall as a competitive director at his age and in this day and age. The one bad thing I had read and heard about Killers was its runtime. It's true; I had to watch it for two days, but is it a bad thing for me? No. Watching it didn't feel like a chore. That is only possible if it's a gripping story with an even more gripping storytelling and has an equally talented cast. DiCaprio was no surprise, Gladstone rightfully earned all the Best Actress nods for her understated performance and bold presence in all scenes she was in (I have yet to see Poor Things for my final Best Actress pick), and we need more De Niro-Scorsese tandem because they just work so well together. I loved Killers for its important and enlightening narrative and how it was made for the audience to enjoy but also to be educated. It is a history Western but didn't waterboard me with breaths from panting so thirstily for awards. Learn it the hard way, the Scorsese way.

I hated this. Felt like 3 hours of Native American torture porn. Definitely needed edited down as it spent 3/4 of the film repeating the same plot points. Besides the Scorsese name and Lily’s performance, I don’t see why this film is as highly rated as it is.

By many directors few have a reputation as big as Martins Scorsese, from his start with Raging Bull, to his success of Goodfellas the director has certainly influenced cinema, as a consequence his latest release Killers of the Flower Moon left many wondering if it was able to stand proudly with his others movies and be remembered as another masterpiece or it would end up a massive disappointment. The movie starts with ww2 vet Ernest coming to an native part of America, he quickly marries a rich girl named Molly that is an heir for many lands with lots of oil in them and so to have the full inheritance Ernest and his uncle William slowly but brutally kill all of Molly sisters while Ernest struggles with the morality of his actions. It certainly is an emotional movie with its main strengths being their two main characters , Ernest remains a routable yet hateable protagonist quickly and effectively making you hate and love him, Molly also is a highlight in this movie giving silent but heartbreaking scenes furthermore the supporting cast of characters are all very entertaining, however the movie suffers for a 3-hour runtime making it feel sometime too slow for it own right. In conclusion Killers of the flower moon is a beautiful and heartbreaking movie, but it can only be fully appreciated for its 3 hours runtime
The movie back drop and costumes were great. The acting was kinda weird and it was way too long and progressed too slowly. Could have cut out an hour and lost no content.

Such an incredible cast and beautiful film overall. I'm in such awe of everyone's performances, especially Lily Gladstone. The film didn't shy away from the gruesome truth about the Osage's murders, but still told it with grace.

This film required 3 sittings to watch. It was good, informative, well directed, but would have been nothing without Leonardo DiCaprio and Robert De Niro. The story was one worth telling, but nothing stood out. The actors were okay, the cast was okay, the story was okay, the filmography was okay. It was all okay. Leo and De Niro, as always, killed it as actors. They managed to depict the personalities of real individuals who were greedy, but also honest and confused. They carried the entire film and the rest of the cast kind of just revolved around them. I can't say it's a must watch, but if you want to see a couple of masters practicing their craft, this is one way to do it.

Overall, this is a decent adaptation of David Grann's book. However, the historical truths get overshadowed by bombastic performances and cinematography. I would have preferred more editing and focus on the Osage experiences. Still, important to watch! 3.5 stars

It did a disservice to the story. Considering the people involved I think whoever wrote the screenplay should have spent more time or the director. Considering the people involved it is very disappointing.

As others have said its 3.5 hour runtime is arduous and I'm glad I watched it at home and not in a cinema. It's a long time to watch such a dark and depressing tale entirely devoid of heros or 'good guys'. Nonetheless, it is well made with standout acting performances from Lily Gladstone and Robert De Niro. I think my big criticism is it's predictability. There are no shocks or twists in this story and you understand fairly early on what is happening. Even the multiple murders lack any suspense and are handled so casually. That was obviously a stylistic choice (perhaps out of respect for the victims) but it doesn't make for the most engaging watch. A solid 3 and half stars.

If you can't sit through 3 and a half hours break up the movie into 2 parts which is what I did. Other than that it just felt so surreal watching the movie. The plot had my jaw to the floor at times. I have not read the book but I heard the book was also incredible.
esta pelicula centra mucho nuestra atencion ya que invoca diferentes estilos de emocion y sentimientos encontrados a nuestra realidad , los invito a verla , espectacular .

I must be in the minority that thinks that this admittedly well-acted movie was excruciatingly, painfully slow paced. Would've been more powerful & made it's point with more emotional impact at 2 hrs. But 3:15?? torture!

I did like the story and bringing this history to the forefront. I thought it was going to be the Osage at the forefront, the main focus was being told by Leo's character and not Lily's character. It was more focused on him. My only gripe but overall a great movie.

I was so looking forward to this movie, and boy am I glad I did not waste money watching it in a theater. Simply put, it was a hot mess. Scorsese's cameo at the end was laughable. The story, so important in our history was turned into something oddly and (assumingly) unintentionally comical and nonsensical. The acting was flat, and frankly the characters came off as bland and droll. If the intent was for the audience to feel their pain and suffering, that was certainly lost. The three-plus gruelling hours were an indictment on the narcissism that infests the entertainment industry.
Para Martin Scorsese, el mal de los hombres es un monstruo devorador. Algo que explora en profundidad en Killers of the Flower Moon, su película más ambiciosa. [Reseña completa en español]

Overlong? Absolutely, but the shere scale and production of this film is a must see. DiCaprio as ever is phenomenal, and everyone else involved take to the task and deliver award worthy performances accross the board. My issue, like most I can imagine, is the this current trend of making a story that could be told in 2hrs go on for nearly 4, it out stayed its welcome and then some. If this film was made into a 6 part mini series I would probably be saying different, but the thought of sitting in a packed cinema to watch this film gives me buckets of anxiety, thankfully I watched at home and split into 2 parts. Its scorsese so the detail is typically fantastic, based on the novel which I half read during lockdown, this film is true to the source and for those unaware of the story of the Osage, can learn alot from viewing this oscar baiting epic, will I watch again....maybe

Stunning powerful story and important history of our indigenous neighbors and ourselves, respectfully made with powerful acting, and well worthwhile. Kept hoping for redemption, but dominated by selfish brutality and hard to watch so many bad choices.

Hideously slow and overly looooong. The performances were fine (although a waste of top talent) and the production values are top-notch, but when you start checking your watch every few minutes halfway through the film, that's not a good sign. A masterpiece? I think not.

Am I rating how good of a film I think it is or how much I enjoyed it? I'm going with the latter and giving it a 3 -- I don't give half stars or else this might have landed at 3.5 -- otherwise if I was going with the former approach I would probably give it 4 stars on merit alone. I just can't really say I enjoyed 3+ hours of this story. Scorsese is so all over the place for me. Sometimes I love his work, other times it's meh or bleh, but it's never "wow that was not good". And this one was somewhere in the middle. Probably a great film by all "film school" sorts of accounts, but just very fine for me.

This movie is amazing, the story is shocking (especially because it's true story), the movie is beautiful, the acting is outstanding (especially Lily Gladstone). All in all I have two problems with the movie: this is a 2h30m movie packed in 3:30m and being so long it still manages to feel that the ending is rushed. So that is why I can't go with 5 stars only with 4.5

I absolutely loved it. It's not going to make you feel good, but it's gripping storytelling that's so masterfully done. The 1-stars on here make absolutely no sense to me. Only thing I can think of is that people are expecting an action-thriller type movie going in. There is no action. If that's what you're looking for this movie is not for you. I'm so in awe of the skills Martin Scorsese still possess and he is definitely the greatest director of all time.

So disappointing! I watched a docudrama about these murders and the creation of the FBI a while ago and it was more gripping, interesting and important than this dreary overlong film. I felt it should have been told from the perspective of Molly and her family rather than the 2 main protagonists. I thought DiCaprio and De Niro were both miscast and wasted on this movie. I wouldn't recommend it to anyone!

I liked it. Teaches you some history while being entertaining. Still, it is long and you do feel that. Some great acting from lily gladstone just takes this up a notch though Would recommend to "movie people" looking for something different to watch

The story is compelling and needed to be told. But it was so long and somewhat redundant that it lost some of its punch particularly on how the FBI made its case etc. 30-45 mins less and may have given it a 4. Do Caprio seemed miscast.
Absolutely superb rendition of a true story about the Osage nation! Brilliant performances by Leonardo di Caprio, Lucy Gladstone and Robert De Niro - definitely the best picture of 2023!
Loved it! I didn't know what to expect one into this movie but I walked out overwhelmed. It was really awesome. I'm glad I watched it.
Martin Scorsese has missed again. Putting Leonardo DiCaprio as a young handsome man back from the War, was laughable. If you need to snooze for 3 1/2 hours , watch this. It is slow, slower, slowest

The film wouldn't be bad even if it was too long for me but the question is: Is it possible that Scorsese has no other actors than the usual DiCaprio? Leaving aside De Niro who is now the default Among other things, his part could easily have been done by someone else... and perhaps better

Really long. DeNiro and DiCaprio feel way too old for their roles and despite doing a good job they don't feel quite right for the roles. Movie is well crafted and scenes are interesting but after watching it there's no way it needed to be 3.5 hours. It's an important story to tell, but that doesn't mean it is a movie worth devoting that much time to, for me at least. Wish the movie felt bigger, it seemed like 3.5 hours of tight shots and conversations about killing people or conning people. Would've liked to see more of the world, wider shots, more of the Osage and how they lived instead of just a few conversations they had about the killings.

Besides the movie being a little too long, the film was well executed. Liked how Martin Scorsese was able to implement a full setting to try to represent the time that Osage people existed. Robert Deniro and Leonardo Dicaprio had an unbreakable chemistry, with Deniro showing his act without having to overdo it. Lily Gladstone was a highlight in that I felt she was able to take us through the story of how her family shrank one by one, followed by the representation of discrimination and the evil part of humanity. I liked the usage of the supporting cast because the uniqueness was essential for each part of the story.

This one was definitely worth seeing. I would venture a guess that if it didn't have DeNiro, DiCaprio and Scorsese's names attached to it, it wouldn't have have been so critically acclaimed. You could have easily trimmed 45 minutes off of it without missing much.

I can't believe I let movie awards hype trick me into watching another slow, dark, and disconnected flick. Really disappointed. Where's the character development? Not a single scene expressing Leo's relationship with his children, then we're supposed to believe he's all torn up by his daughter's death?

What a SLOG. The arrogance of Scorsese to put forth this 3.5 hour film is mind boggling. The way in which the length undermines Mollie's story is criminal. I don't care about Leonardo DiCaprio's stupid character. He is way too much of the focus of the movie. All of the hype surrounding the Osage finally getting their story told by an influential ally in Scorsese is laughable. This isn't their story. It's Ernest Burkhart's dumb story. Just market it as such, or else take out at least an hour so that Mollie can be the focus. I'm giving it two stars because the acting is very good and the cinematography is beautiful.

There's two evenings I'll never get back! 94% critics and 84% viewers!? Is there two films and I've watched the wrong one? "King and his clothes" The plot was I obvious and could have been adequately conveyed in half the time. With exception to a couple of scenes the acting was one dimensional with RD just going through the motions. There must a number of middle aged actors that could have done a more convincing job. Far too many people getting swayed by a couple of big names.

Score was decent. Accents and acting were drab. Another one of those movies where all the best bits are in the preview. Nothing else of merit. 3+ hrs of waiting around knowing what was going to happen next. No surprises. Yawn. No action. Lame dialogue. It feels as though this movie was made for idiots. Wish I had spent that time doing anything else. Booo!

Don't let the 3 and a half hour runtime stop you from watching it. This movie is so good with some of the best acting you'll ever see, arguably Scorsese's best work with an emotional and sad story about the Osage.

Very compelling and moving storyline of Indigenous Peoples and their adversity of a hidden historical account of the Osage Peoples. DiCaprio and Lily Gladstone did amazing job in depicting this storyline and account of a true-American history of a family undergone tremendous misfortune at the hands of greedy oil workers.

It's that time of year again, when we reflect back on the best of last year's movies. Like clockwork, names that are sure to be part of that list are Martin Scorsese, Robert De Niro and Leonardo Dicaprio. Oh and hey, wouldn't you know it, Killers of the Flower Moon has all three. So, naturally critics immediately start throwing around words like "masterpiece" or "perfection, " but does the movie live up to the hype? In a word, no. For starters, this movie is long, I mean REALLY long. While I wouldn't have an issue with the length, if well-paced, this movie was painfully slow. What's worse is I can tell which moments needed to be shaved off. For instance, when I watch a movie, I ask myself, "why did the director want me to see this shot?" Sometimes this can be obvious. When they linger on a specific character or object it could be meant as a piece of foreshadowing, predicting events to come. In this case, however, there were so many unnecessary scenes to the plot, that ultimately slowed the pacing to a crawl. Next, is frankly one of my biggest historical movie faux pas. Watch any older video of the time and you'll find the streets, bars or restaurants vacant, 50-100 people tops, even during the busiest of times. Yet, for some reason, certain directors insist on packing scenes full of people, or activities, to visually stimulate the audience. They'll call it authenticity but I call it "visual noise" and disingenuous. Lastly, some directors prefer a bare scripts to allow their actors the freedom to ad-lib. This is designed to create a natural, authentic (there's that word again) interactions between actors. Unfortunately, without the proper guidance this can lead to uncomfortable and awkward performances. In this case, I feel the better performances were from some the supporting cast rather than the principles.
Brilliant performances. Beautiful, sweeping cinematography. An incredibly compelling and engaging story. Do not let the long runtime scare you - every minute is worth it.

Martin Scorsese's latest epic is long enough, but is it truly strong enough to make the guilty parties of our whitewashing society culpable? My thought is no, it's not. It's good to know that there is awareness, but it's not changing our culture. The elitist entitled class is still just that, no less burdened by anything their own forefathers might have done -- or not done in the form of remaining quiet. Scorsese hits a target, but it's not the target. De Niro is as good as ever and DiCaprio pales beneath all of them with a shoddy performance that falls well beneath those of De Niro and Lily Gladstone. Still, it's a very good film and, most importantly, an important one to know and tell.

Worst, most boring film in a long time… turned it off after an hour when I realized it had 2.5 hours more to go. The time frame jumped right over any pregnancies and births!! Imagine, you have 3 and a half hours to tell a story and you can't even multiple children joining the fold. Totally the emperors new cloths in my world

This is indeed a story that needs to be told but what a massive pile of poop!! This is a case of the Emperor has no clothes! Come on people, be honest and objective, this movie did not have more than three hours of content. The filmmaking was bad, the editing was bad, the acting was HORRIBLE, the script was bad and there were so many unanswered questions and random scenes, that I just wanted to stab myself in the eye from the boredom and frustration. I so looked forward to seeing this movie and it turned out to be the biggest disappointment of this century to date.

I was waiting excitedly to watch this movie. Even though the movie tells us the sad history of our country. However, the story did not flow as good as I was hoping for. Somehow the movie was less that what I was expecting.

I think Leo's glory days are OVER. I grew up a huge fan of his, ever since Growing Pains. However Leo has become so fat and disgusting, not to mention how we all learned his 25yr old or younger policy, this movie made me want to vomit bc of what I know about him. Leo can't lead a cast anymore.
Loved it. Way, way too long running time. They should have made it a series and it wouldn't have taken me 3 days to watch☹️ Wonderful acting and such sad true story

Martin Scorcese is legendary and he's still at the top of his game. Essentially what this movie is about is oil is found on Osage land and one by one all of the native Americans are murdered for their money, This was everything I expected it would be like and nothing like I expected it would be like all wrapped in one. I think Robert DeNiro actually gives a really good performance. I haven't been so impressed with him as of late so it was good to see him act the way I know he's capable of. Leo has some weird acting choices and accents in it that I didn't really like. I don't know of too many movies where I'm iffy on an acting performance by Leo- and while I respect him for taking a chance- I didn't really think it worked Lily Gladstone really steals the show in this one though. Leo and Robert are big personalities; however, she doesn't simply blend in with them. She commands the screen. This film topped most of the areas I look for when giving a review. The only knock on this film is I don't know it has the value of a rewatch. If you've seen it once, I don't think you'll be going too much out of your way to keep rewatching it. 9.3
Acting and everything about it first rate- but the material was a little dense and the movie so long that I can't really in good conscience recommend it.
This movie feels like homework. It is not good. I got 49 min into it and I literally don't know what the point is. I have watched slugs crawl that are more interesting.

Can we please stop pretending that these absurdly long and incredibly boring movies are some sort of cinematic masterpieces simply because they were made by relics of the past? This has got to be one of the most boring movies that I’ve ever watched. Somewhere in this half-day long movie, someone’s house blows up. I had the volume up kinda loud and I thought, “Man, I wish that were my house right now.” Maybe that’s how this movie is getting all of the attention it so richly doesn’t deserve. All of those mob movies. Maybe everyone is afraid to tell Scorsese that his movies kinda suck because they’re afraid that the mob will pay them a visit if they do.
Snooze fest. The story should've been told from the FBI investigators' perspectives, not the deplorable villains which erased all mystery and suspense. Book was great.

An amazing story that has escaped our history. A little slow at times but the acting and the work of Mr. Scorsese is amazing. The film left me both amazed and sad. Leonardo D'Caprio is engaging in his role as a moronic nephew to Di Nero's conniving character "King". The entire cast is amazing. Definitely worth the 3 1/2 hours.
Simply put, not an entertaining movie in my eyes. The editing felt really off and the length of the movie was unnecessary. Lily Gladstone's acting was the one bright spot.

DiCaprio once again proves that he is one of the worst actors in Hollywood! The movie was way too long and at least half of it should have been left on the cutting room floor. And, finally, the is straight up stupid.

One of the best movies of 2023, with superb acting from DeNiro and DiCaprio. Wow! (Paid $19.99 to rent and it was worth it) Well written script, fascinating, and the fact it was so long did not bother me at all, I could have watched another hour, it was astonishing in that fact it is based on real events. All fo the characters were intriguing and the plot was shocking and good.

Finally got a chance to check it out today. (Hey, when you're snowed in, bring on the 3 hour 26 minute Scorsese movie!) It was... pretty good. Not great, but pretty good. First of all, it's definitely a Scorsese movie. The visuals and technique are of course awesome, which is not surprising at all. The score by Robbie Robertson (RIP) is great... at turns menacing and wistful when it needs to be. And a lot of the performances are great. (DeNiro maybe doesn't nail the accent, but it's still a good "banality of evil" performance by him.) I can't really slag DiCaprio anymore, because he's really good in this film. Good supporting performances surround those two. Lily Gladstone definitely needs some award consideration as well for her performance. However... from a screenwriting perspective, I think there's some problems. I haven't read the book yet (I have it in my possession to do so), but I'm betting it's going to be a different perspective than what you see here. I certainly don't think it was an intention of Roth and Scorsese to make the people who were the SUBJECT of the atrocities peripheral to their own story, but unfortunately that's what you kind of get here, despite the director making some valiant attempts to circumvent that. Look, we get it: if your film stars Leo, then the focus is going to be on him, whether it should be or not, but that's the main quibble I have with the film. Small quibble is the length. Yes, yes, "saving cinema" and all that, thanks Marty, but "Goodfellas" is 2 1/2 hours and is, in my opinion, better than this movie. I'm still recommending it, but as I said, I get a feeling that when I'm finished with the book, I'm definitely going to be in the camp that feels the book is much better than the movie. Which is usually the case, I know, but I'm just curious to see what another director with, shall we say, a different perspective, might have brought to the film. With no disrespect to Mr. S, because I remain a big fan. This is just one of his "very good" efforts and not one of his masterpieces, in my opinion.

What on earth are the bad reviews about?! Yes it's a long film, and I wish I'd stocked up on popcorn, but boring?!!! What on earth??! It's a story of greed, and the story is grim. But the movie's a masterpiece!

Putting aside how relentlessly grim the story is, there's an inevitably to the unfolding of events that saps the film of suspense and narrative tension. At three hours, it's a marathon of murder that hardly feels worth the time, except as an overdue admission of guilt.
Seemed like it could have been shorter. Story was filled with repetition, and dragged. This isn't even a top ten 10 Scorsese movie. It felt like a premium TV show not a movie.

First, the good: Lily Gladstone. She deserves any accolades she will get for this film. Now the rest... What could have/should have been a compelling tale of greed and murder became an overly long exercise in directorial ego. This movie is what happens when no one wants to tell a legendary director that they should let an editor take a crack at the film before releasing the director's cut. An interesting story could have been about the Osage and the agents who tracked down the killers. Instead we get a overly long, muddled focus on the criminals. A focus on King and Ernest might have been okay if (1) we had gotten more of a backstory about the criminals (how did King come to be King?, was Ernest always as dumb as he was during the period covered by the film?) or (2) more exploration of the killings and how people in the community reacted to them (more detail on the impact in the community, who did they suspect was responsible?). It's amazing that in 3.5 hours, so many potentially interesting parts of the story were not told. Instead we get vignettes and glimpses which take the place of exposition. Perhaps tell us more about the KKK than a few seconds of them marching in a parade? How about a bit more detail on the relationship of the Osage killing to the Tulsa massacre? A lot of the press has lauded Scorsese for using Native American actors and Osage dialog. This is commendable, but at this point shouldn't that be taken for granted? Is it really so remarkable that a big budget file would do the right thing? And finally, what's with the radio play at the end? So many interesting pieces of the story are jammed into a jarring conclusion that seemed as though even the director knew this had gone on too long but he needed to tie up loose ends. Many films will end with a list the crimes and sentences in a series of scrolls but Scorsese decides to use a radio play as the delivery mechanism. An interesting look into Foley artists and radio play production to be sure, but is that what was important about the wrapup? The significance of the aftermath of the killings took a back seat to the vanity project of showing how radio plays were created. I had hope for this movie despite it's length. Given the critical acclaim, I figured Scorsese had made an important contribution to our understanding of this suppressed period of our history. I was wrong.
Over acted. Horribly long and annoying pointless scenes. 3.5 hours of my life i will never get back. I surprisingly stuck with it but make no mistake this is a very mediocre movie at best.

Film 101 teaches that you must edit your scenes to keep the plot moving forward and to avoid losing your audience. Scorcesee is self indulgent & selfish to put viewers through what felt like an uncut version of just an okay movie. Knock an hour off and it would have been more palatable. What I find truly silly is that this film is nominated for so many awards and has a 93% on rotten tomatoes by critics. Highlighting the ridiculousness of the Hollywood inner circle and the inability for those to potentially pan such a highly regarded director.

Through the roof production value, except for an edit which appears to be non-existent, fails to carry over-indulgence on a grand scale. Scorsese has done some great stuff but it was all a long time ago. Age is, more often than not, a talent killer and Scorsese is no exception. Hang up your boots old man while you still have some dignity.

Na década de 20, no século passado, a nação indígena Osage encontra petróleo nas terras da sua reserva, tornando-os milionários. Porém, uma série de mortes e assassinatos começam a acontecer entre eles. Isto é o pano de fundo para a história de Ernest e Molly Burkhart. Ele, um soldado retornando da Primeira Guerra, buscando fortuna. Ela, uma osage rica com o dinheiro do petróleo. Vendo esse filme, logo uma coisa aflora: para certas pessoas, é inconcebível que pessoas não brancas possam ter dinheiro. Fico pensando que os osages talvez achassem que eles seriam aceitos na sociedade dos brancos com o dinheiro do petróleo, mas isso apenas despertou o pior em muitos brancos. O dinheiro dos osages causou uma inversão: os empregados agora eram os brancos. O quanto isso deve ter pirado os preconceituosos! É nesse caldeirão que Ernest chega para ganhar dinheiro, trabalhando para seu tio. E o primeiro diálogo entre Ernest e o seu tio já demonstra todo o mau-caratismo de William Hale. Complementando, temos Molly Brown. Enquanto Ernest é falador, Hale, uma serpente sempre armando e pronta para dar o bote, Molly observa a tudo. Ela percebe as intenções de Ernest quando ele começa a cortejá-la. Ela tenta ser um apoio para a sua família, começando a ser destroçada, com os casamentos com homens brancos. E Molly tem a serenidade e a austeridade que os seus algozes brancos não têm. E que trio espetacular! Di Caprio, De Niro e Lily Gladstone fornecem interpretações magistrais, que merecem todos os prêmios e indicações que receberam. E Scorsese dá um show de direção, com um roteiro redondo e preciso, uma montagem excepcional, que não permite que o filme torne-se cansativo com suas mais de 3 horas de duração, figurino excelente, direção de arte apuradíssima, uma aula de cinema. E o filme assume várias identidades. É um western a la corrida do ouro. É um filme de gangster, onde o silêncio a todos protege. É um filme policial, investigativo, com os integrantes do iniciante Bureau de Investigação tentando resolver o caso e prender os culpados. É uma denúncia de uma parte da história norte-americana que estava sendo apagada dos livros. E é uma fábula sobre ganância, preconceito, inveja, como somente o cinema e Scorsese podem produzir.

"Black Panther: Wakanda Forever” is an underwhelming continuation without a star but also without nuance that is or a messy holding place til the next installment in the MCU. Ryan Coogler clearly rushed this story after they lost their lead actor but it ultimately causes an unfinished poor quality to this changed story. Let’s face it, the first “Black Panther" despite being a very average Marvel film was a cultural phenomenon. It was largely over praised by the critics with better reviews than made over $700 million in the US, and was the first comic book movie nominated for an Oscar for Best Picture. It was a significant film but not a memorable film. Disney has pumped up the Marvel fan base like crazy. But I think they, like the regular audience I saw “WF” with this afternoon, will be disappointed. The opening act is all about losing and mourning T’Challa, which director Ryan Coogler milks for everything he’s got. They’ve even turned the opening Marvel logo sequence into its own memorial montage. And then there’s the majestic funeral. The only thing they’re missing is lox and bagels at the shivah. Then, however, you have to have a movie — and they don’t. The world is mad at Wakanda for not sharing its vibranium, the magic material in the water under the powerful island country. Even the UN is mad the Wakandans won’t share it with them. (There’s a UN in the Marvel universe? For what purpose?) Eventually enemies arrive to try and dig the stuff up. Tenoch Huerta plays Namor, the leader of the pack, dressed as a gladiator from a 1950s epic. He is no Thanos (Josh Brolin) the really upsetting villain from the Avengers movies. Forget the hype. Namor is silly. There’s never a suggestion he’s going to win. You could almost call this movie “The Woman King,” but that title obviously is unavailable. But with T’Challa gone, he’s briefly succeeded by his mother, the always sensational Angela Bassett. Bassett is a STAR. Unfortunately, her Queen Ramonda exits the movie at the halfway point with not much character development. Letitia Wright’s Shuri becomes the Black Panther, but does not fill the void. The two remaining women — Lupita Nyong’o and Danai Gurira — are top notch but they also are written as supporting players. (Also, once Ramonda has left, Shuri doesn’t seem to miss her much.) Well, nature abhors a vacuum. And that’s what the second act is, even with cameo appearances by Julia Louis Dreyfus and Martin Freeman as rogue CIA agents. Winston Duke as M’Baku flits in and out but isn’t much of a presence. So when this two hour forty one minute extravaganza rolls to a somber ending, the audience just sits there hoping for something to chew on. Eventually they get it: a post credits Marvel when the gorgeous Nakia (the very underused Nyong’o) reveals she had a child with T’Challa who she’s been hiding in Haiti. He will be the Black Panther of the third and final movie. Yes, the audience applauded. I groaned however because that's the worst predictable storytelling soap opera like trope you could use, T'Challa doesn't need a biological son to make this transition to continue the character's legacy. If Boseman had lived, who knows what a sequel would have been like? He really projected heroism and nobility. He was the center of “Black Panther,” you couldn’t take your eyes off of him. Unfortunately, “Wakanda Forever” is a movie with a hole at its center. Boseman’s T’Challa is gone, and the movie doesn’t know how to get around that problem. T’Challa didn’t have a brother or son to replace or succeed him. The original film was already heavily stacked with powerful females, and they are all back. But without Boseman, there’s no movie star, no anchor to continue the story.

Establishing the villain early helped, unlike some other post-Endgame MCU films. It was an admirable effort to try and overcome the challenge the film faced, but it got to a point where it needed a lead. It was honestly a good subplot though, waiting to see who the next Black Panther will be, and as such it was a good impromptu origin story of sorts. Again, the fake languages and subtitles were too frequent and jarring, as was another nearly three-hour runtime for a non-finale MCU movie.

The plot makes no sense. I despise how they removed T'Challa? Unless it was some super virus that was sweeping the country that some super villain made then he should not have died. If it was a super virus sweeping the country then we should have seen them fighting for the people and trying to stop it with some cure coming in short order. That was a total cheese maneuver to just have him die in the very beginning. Did you ever tell cooperative stories when you were younger? Then you have one person who decides they don't like where the story is headed and say "then you wake up" just so they could change the storyline? That's what this was. For some reason, someone did not want T'Challa to be king so they whacked him in the dumbest way possible. Then there is M'Baku. M'Baku challenged T'Challa for the kingship previously, there is no reason to expect that the day he died M'Baku would not challenge for it again. With no king to defend the throne it would have gone to him. So, M'Baku should have been king throughout the movie. The rest of it could have generally taken place the same way but the focus should not have been on the queen. She would have just been a grieving queen mother and then a worried mother for Shuri. I'm a bit of purist when it comes to the comics so I prefer to keep the movies somewhat grounded in the comics. Namor is Atlantean, not Mayan. Even if we run with the Mayan idea, how did they develop their tech which seems to be ahead of the surface world in many ways (the mini-rebreather for instance)? They were not in a position to share ideas with other nations so most likely their society would have stagnated, not progressed in tech. And the depiction of the poor Mayan's dying from the Spaniards invasion. If we are going to depict the dark side of one culture we should include the dark side of the other. In order to get their deity to give them a sign the Mayan's likely sacrificed someone if not multiple people, likely children. The Mayan culture, just like the Aztec culture, was brutal and evil. I just can't stand cultural whitewashing to make one group look bad over the other. I lost interest in it and didn't finish. The action was decent, the siren idea was cool but again they should have been Atlanteans affiliated with the med and not the Mayans. I wish they hadn't killed off T'Challa and that they would have made the background and developing plot tie together better.
Given an impossible task, this film made a future for the Black Panther. Bookending the movie with funerals for the Black Panther, the leader, and T'Challa, the brother, was a great decision.

What I am sure was one of the most difficult films to make without Chadwick Boseman, Black Panther: Wakanda Forever tackles his in-universe passing, the introduction of a new nation, and the rise of a new Black Panther with grace—even if not every element are executed perfectly. Let’s start with the weaker aspects. The visuals are noticeably flatter than the first film, with more noticeable green screen use and sequences that are overly dark—especially underwater or nighttime scenes—making action hard to follow both in theaters and at home. While I loved the introduction of Namor and the Mayan-inspired nation, we spend surprisingly little time with this world beyond Namor himself, leaving it underdeveloped. Where the film shines is in its emotional balance and performances. The mix of grief, humor, and action feels more cohesive than in many recent MCU films. The action remains engaging and varied, from Riri’s aerial flight sequences to intense underwater combat. Tenoch Huerta’s Namor is a standout, embodying terror, anger, and compassion all at once. Angela Bassett also delivers one of the franchise’s best performances, channeling strength, grief, and authority with genuine power. While the film is not bad by any means, it doesn’t quite reach the heights of the original, Wakanda Forever is still a worthy successor—anchored by its emotional core, strong performances, and respectful handling of an impossible loss.
The story wasn’t as rich as the original, but it wasn’t a bad showing by any means. And it was a worthy tribute to Chadwick Boseman.
I cried so ugly watching this film. It was beautiful. My God, I cried and cried and cried. I ugly cried AT LEAST 3 TIMES!!!!

Black Panther 2 was an amazing sequel that honored Chadwick Boseman’s legacy while pushing the story forward in powerful ways. I was especially impressed by the introduction of Namor, whose presence and backstory brought a fresh and compelling dynamic to the movie. Wakanda Forever had big shoes to fill, and I was genuinely interested to see how the story would carry on after the first film. The sequel delivered more large scale scenes and action moments, yet somehow it didn’t feel as intensely action-packed as the first. That’s not a bad thing, it leaned more into spectacle, while the original carried heavier emotional and thematic weight through its quieter, dramatic dilemmas. What I really appreciated was how the sequel didn’t just try to replicate the first film. It built on it. The integrated story offered a fresh direction and development, rather than rehashing what had already been done. That choice made the movie feel purposeful and respectful to the world it was expanding. It’s hard to directly compare this to Black Panther, because the first one leaves a more lasting impact due to the nature of its story. But Wakanda Forever stands strong in its own place. Its an amazing film, meaningful in a different way, and a worthy continuation of the legacy.

The follow-up to the hugely popular Black Panther, which earned itself several Academy Award nominations back in 2019, Black Panther: Wakanda Forever had a tough job following the tragic death of actor Chadwick Boseman. Filming was interrupted with rewrites prompting reshoots as the film's release was delayed and Letitia Wright's controversial time on Twitter didn't help matters much. Wakanda Forever was tasked with building on the first film and concluding Marvel's Phase 4 as a new villain enters the picture, and a new hero is forced to step up and become the Black Panther. Wakanda is pressured by the rest of the world to share its vibranium resource, but Queen Ramonda (Angela Bassett) refuses so these political headbutts soon start to cause dangerous ripples. The bad guy this time is Namor, played by Tenoch Huerta Mejía, who breaks into Wakanda, threatening the country with an attack if he is not given the scientist who designed a machine capable of detecting vibranium. Losing the main actor in the franchise was always going to prove challenging for the filmmakers but the approach taken here feels appropriate: after T'Challa is given a considerable, moving send-off, the story continues and Shuri (Letitia Wright) eventually assumes the mantle. Having not one but two massive funerals in a film as lengthy as this one does hurt the pacing of the movie quite a bit, however. This is definitely a film that could have done with a bit of a trim but one suspects that necessary changes to the script caused the budget to inflate too much already so changing the entire plot was not really an option, which is understandable. All of that aside, this is a good sequel and the best film in Marvel's Phase 4 by far. The action sequences are big and exciting, the cast is on top form, there's plenty of drama and intrigue to hold onto, Namor is an interesting foe who lives in a bit of a grey area like Killmonger did and the new culture that is introduced is fascinating. The film takes what worked so well in the first Black Panther and puts it on a more global scale. On the minus side, the introduction of Riri Williams (Dominique Thorne) falls resoundingly flat and Lupita Nyong'o is barely given anything to do as Nakia, a character that has felt criminally underwritten since the first movie. Black Panther: Wakanda Forever isn't a perfect film by any stretch, and it's hardly one of Marvel's very best, but it remains a thoroughly entertaining sequel with new environments to discover, characters going through a lot emotionally and a well done build-up to an all-out war that is worth the watch alone.​Solid.

Another great thing is the character writing. Shuri is my favorite character because of this movie. She's not an average selfless hero. She cares for her people yes, but her motivations are much more driven by her family. And despite people liking to call her a Mary Sue, she is far from one. She fails in this movie a lot. She also is much more vengeful than many heroes and her arc is overcoming that vengeance. Riri is also better written here. Even with her limited amount of screentime, Coogler's Riri is a better version of Ironheart than Bendis'. Namor was also a pretty good villain. He is worse than Kilmonger, but he is written much better than the majority of anti-heroes. This movie also expanded Wakandan culture and represents Africa well. The CGI was okay and could pass. But CGI was way too evident in this movie. Everett Ross was almost entirely unneccessary and took away from the screentime other characters could've had. Riri was set up to be an important character in the first act, but somewhere during act two, she was not used much and I think that's a shame With that being said, I highly recommend this movie.

Marvel continues along a path littered with tired stories and unearned action set pieces that mix with flashy colors and one-liners and culminate in a lukewarm tribute for the late Chadwick Boseman. The thin plot that supports this films nearly three hour runtime consists of a intercontinental search for vibranium that accidentally uncovers an ancient civilization of, essentially, merpeople that are also quite advanced thanks to their unfettered access to vibranium. The merpeople threaten the existence of Wakanda and therefore they must be stopped. It's all so superficial now that many of the Marvel plotlines feel like unfinished first drafts. The acting is solid enough, without any glaring issues and the special effects look as great as always. It's the writing that continually sets Marvel movies up for failure, or at least disappointment. It's the universe in which the movies inhabit that's distracting as well. At this point the world is so convolutedly different than our own that it can be hard to get invested in the film's presented stakes, which is a charge that could be levied at any number of recent Marvel entries. All told, this Wakanda felt like it took forever to move along and, by the time we make it to the end credits, we're left wondering if we really went anywhere at all.

Black Panther - Wakanda Forever is probably the most emotional Marvel film of all time. After the sad death of former lead actor Chadwick Boseman, Marvel Studios faced a big challenge! How should they proceed with the planned sequel to Black Panther without the main actor? And it's safe to say they had probably the best solution. The film is simply a superhero masterpiece. We follow the journey of Shuri, we see how she has to deal with one blow after another and we see how she has to deal with the grief and anger that eats away at her. You have succeeded perfectly in turning Shuri from a marginal character into a real lead. They were also able to flesh out the supporting characters very clearly. Danai Gurira as General Okoye was again great, as was the entire cast. Okoye also gets a bigger arc in this film than before. She has to deal with her biggest fear, the loss of her title as General of the Dora Milaje. Nakia and M'Baku were also great again, though I would have liked to see more of the them. The two absolute scene stealers are Tenoch Huerta as Namor and Angela Bassett as Ramonda. Namor is arguably one of the best Marvel villains, with a good story and exciting powers, he makes you want more. Ramonda is probably the secret star of the film. Not only does she deliver arguably the most emotional scenes, but she is a great character for the main plot. Angela Bassett performs Oscar ripe. Newcomer Riri Williams aka Ironhearth is also convincing. She is a fun and likable side character with cool action scenes, even if Iron Man Fanboys probably don't see it that way. The action in the movie is great and also the CGI is mostly very good. Especially the underwater city Talokan can convince. The interplay of image and music is perfect. The film probably offers the most beautiful film music in the MCU. The film is quite long, but you don't notice that at all. The quiet pace gives the characters enough time to develop and make us understand how they feel and why they act the way they do. Goosebumps and tears are unavoidable. Alone the this time quiet Marvel intro with pictures and videos of Chadwick Boseman brings tears to your eyes. You can feel the real emotions in this film and that makes it even more powerful. In conclusion, Wakanda Forever is an absolute emotional masterpiece in the superhero industry that has no equal. It manages to honorably say goodbye to Chadwick and at the same time honorably begin a new story.
This was an emotional tribute to Chadwick. Even as an MCU fan, I didn't care about the MCU watching this one. I cared about the message and the tribute. Both were done well.

König T´Challa ist tot. Seine Schwester Shuri (Letitia Wright) und die Königin Ramonda (Angela Bassett) trauern und müssen dafür sorgen, dass Wakanda ein sichererer Ort bleibt. Shuri findet ein neues Volk, welches Unterwasser lebt und ebenfalls Vibranium besitzt und in Gefahr gerät bekannt zu werden. Der König Namor (Tenoch Huerta) möchte sein Volk beschützen und ist zu allem bereit. Gibt es Frieden? Ist Wakanda noch stark genug, ohne seinen König und Black Panther? Und wer wird der neue Black Panther? Black Panther Wakanda Forever ehrt am Anfang und am Ende den verstorbenen Black Panther Darsteller Chadwick Boseman. Dies macht er sehr gut und es ist auch emotional anzusehen. Shuri ist in diesem Film der Hauptcharakter und ist hier ernster und reist nicht mehr so viele Witze wie im ersten Teil. Dies liegt daran, da sie in starker Trauer ist. Das kann, aber auch daran liegen, da sie ja jetzt die Hauptdarstellerin ist und es für uns Zuschauer zu nervig wäre, wenn sie zu viel redet und nur Gags macht. Der Film generell wirkt nicht wie ein MCU Film. Es gibt eigentlich keine Erwähnung, anderer Superhelden oder Schurken. Am Anfang denkt man, dass der Film in die politische Richtung gehen wird, was zum Teil auch der Fall ist, aber meiner Meinung nach hätte es noch ein bisschen mehr sein können. Im Gegensatz zu anderen Marvelprojekten gibt es hier, weniger Action und mehr Charakterentwicklungen. Angela Bassett hat mir sehr gut gefallen und hat meiner Meinung nach zu Recht eine Oscarnominierung erhalten. Der Bösewicht des Filmes ist gut erzählt worden und könnte noch interessant für Fortsetzungen werden. Da man hier einen Bösewicht hat, dessen Motiv man nachvollziehen kann. Die Bewohner des Unterwasservolks sahen wie die Menschen aus Avatar aus und ich habe zwar Avatar nie richtig gesehen, aber die Handlung ähnelt sich schon stark. Der Endkampf war eher langweilig und einige Entscheidungen im Film fand ich nicht so toll z.b. was mit General Okoye gemacht wurde. Black Panther Wakanda Forever ist ein eher schwächerer Marvel Film, welcher zwar einen guten Ansatz hat und auch gute Szenen hatte. Aber am Ende hatte ich mir mehr erhofft und ich kann mir Shuri, nicht als neuen Black Panther vorstellen. 7,5/10

BLACK PANTHER: WAKANDA FOREVER Black Panther: Wakanda Forever is the sequel to the highly successful Black Panther movie. It serves as a poignant tribute to the late Chadwick Boseman. To be honest, it's amazing how they were able to sustain the franchise in spite of Boseman's untimely demise. Powerful performances from the main cast, especially Angela Bassett, who gloriously played the Queen of Wakanda. Great acting by Leticia Wright as Shuri, Danai Gurira as Okoye and Lupita Nyong'o as Nakia. The events of the movie led to a war between the Wakanda and Talokan. I loved how they presented Namor, in spite of the changes. For me, it was interesting to see him as a Mayan/Aztec. I understand why they didn't use Atlanteans, but I like how they kept the aesthetics. Costume design was beautiful for both tribes. The visual effects and battle sequences were amazing. I agree with the critics and fans that this movie is a great way to move the MCU forward. It's almost as great as its predecessor.
