Following the amazing first film, Ryan Coogler returned to direct the sequel of Black Panther, and I was excited to see what he could do with this one. Now the movie was dealt a devastating hand with the loss of Chadwick Boseman and they do a pretty good job of both honoring his legacy and character with respect (as they should) and moving the MCU's story into the future. Letitia Wright's Shuri was by far the best candidate to fill the shoes of the Black Panther and she is good in the role and holds a great on-screen presence. Angela Basset gives a very compelling performance, Danai Gurira gives another great performance as Okoye, and Winston Duke keeps bringing new and great energy to M'Baku. This movie falls short with both its villain and its runtime. The movie feels way too long, it takes way too much time to get from point A to point B and the time they spend getting there is almost meaningless. I wasn't a fan of Namor as a villain I think he was another poorly written villain in the MCU especially to compare him to one of the best villains in the form of Michael B Jordan's Killmonger, as they want us to feel sympathetic towards him and they never were able to fully get that across in a good and meaningful way like they did with the film's predecessor. This film definitely isn't the worst Marvel has put out as of late, but it falls short of being considered the best.

Avengers: Endgame - at least the first segment of it - was a film about life in the wake of trauma and loss. For such a high-profileBut film it was a boldly meditative, thoughtful way to go ... until the film pressed the Big Reset Button and it turned out that nothing means anything in this world. You can just undo the loss, and the MCU has been struggling ever since. Black Panther: Wakanda Forever is also about grief, but for altogether more serious reasons. What was to happen after the tragic loss of the first film's star was an almost impossible decision; I have no doubt this film was made in good faith in regard to that situation. There was no easy route. But the result is a strangely patchy mess, a little of this and a little of that. Some impressive set pieces, an antagonist people whose superpower appears to be singing; on the other hand, some moving stuff and good performances. It's way too long. Way, way too long. Somewhat dull as a result. It was always going to be a hard film to make, and doubtless, the makers deserve a round of applause for getting it done at all. The result, however, is much like the MCU as a whole in recent times: adrift, aimless, devoid of real meaning.

After Chadwick Boseman's unexpected passing in August 2020, director Ryan Coogler found himself faced with the mammoth task of trying to craft a soulful send off for a true king, while also building off the success and world of 2018's "Black Panther". The acclaimed director steps up to the seemingly impossible challenge of trying to make a film without its most integral character, but Coogler manages to exceed expectations, crafting a poignant and thoroughly entertaining film. "Black Panther: Wakanda Forever" draws out stellar performances from its cast and introduces marvel audiences to new threats these beloved characters face. After King T'Challa's death, Queen Ramonda (Angela Bassett), Shuri (Letitia Wright), and the entire kingdom of Wakanda find themselves mourning their admired leader. But with world powers becoming increasingly frustrated with Wakanada's refusal to share their precious Vibranium, they decide to take matters into their own hands. Their search inadvertently angers Namor, king of an ancient underwater kingdom known as Talokan. Determined to keep his kingdom safe and hidden, Namor asks Wakanda to find the scientist responsible for creating the machine finding the Vibranium. But, as tensions rise between the two nations, will Namor's desire to wage war on the surface world, and keep his kingdom and his people safe, wipe out Wakanda as we know it? Ryan Coogler directs a moving depiction of grief and loss with such tenderness that solidifies him as the perfect man to direct the film. Coogler takes Boseman's absence and builds off of it in such a way that audiences wouldn't think possible, delivering an outstanding sequel to one of last decade's most culturally significant films. "Black Panther: Wakanda Forever" manages to escape Marvel's curse of mediocre sequels, majorly surpassing films like "Thor: The Dark World" and "Avengers: Age of Ultron". With its ability to juggle its multiple themes and its duality of being an entertaining action flick with a suitable send off for a king, the film is a strong way to end phase four of the Marvel Cinematic Universe. Angela Bassett reprises her role as Queen Ramonda and delivers a powerful and vivid performance. Bassett flawlessly proves she deserves the Oscar nomination she received for her performance as the Wakandan queen, and quickly asserts herself one of the highlights of the film. Letitia Wright also delivers a fantastic performance, not only does she shine as Shuri, but the BAFTA nominee also brilliantly steps into the role of Black Panther with ease. Both women do a stellar job encompassing their characters' intense grief and emotion Tenoch Huerta makes his MCU debut in the film, bringing the aquatic character of Namor to the screen. The "Narcos: Mexico" actor brings the menacing villain to life with an assured performance that allows Namor to be an ominous new threat while also introducing audiences to a whole new part of the Marvel Universe. Huerta's turn as Namor benefits from Ryan Coogler and Joe Robert Cole's impressive worldbuilding when it comes to the underwater world of Talokan. As well as introducing audiences to a new villain, "Black Panther: Wakanda Forever" also finally brings the character of Riri Williams (a.k.a Ironheart) into the MCU. Dominique Thorne ("If Beale Street Could Talk") easily slips into the role as the gifted MIT student, injecting energy into the character even if at times her inclusion seems like a bit of a plot device. Much like its 2018 predecessor, the film features stunning cinematography that brilliantly highlights both the intricacies of the costumes as well as the elaborate sets of Wakanda, while also making the film a visual feast for the eyes. Autumn Durald Arkapaw ("Loki") crafts stunning imagery that rivals the cinematography of the first film, while also escaping the curse of Marvel's bland cinematography. Ludwig Göransson returns to the world of Black Panther with yet another incredible score. Working his magic once again, the Swedish composer, who won an Oscar for his work on the first Black Panther film, composes a score full of the work of talented African and Latin artists alongside grand classical pieces. Like "Black Panther", this film is accompanied by a soundtrack comprised of songs specifically written for the film by a myriad of artists from across the globe. Artists like Stormzy, Future, and Rihanna have their songs included in the film, with the latter writing two songs for the film. As well as being technically impressive, "Black Panther: Wakanda Forever" also ends up managing its complex themes with remarkable ease. Ryan Coogler weaves ideas of loss, grief, family and legacy into the narrative without allowing them to overpower the film, but including them in the film in such a tasteful way. The film is both an affecting send off for a king, and a stellar instalment in the ever-expanding MCU. In typical Marvel fashion, the film does include the standard mid-credit scene but departs from the tradition of using it to set up a future film or introduce a new villain, instead choosing to carry on the legacy of Boseman's character in a heart-warming and unexpected way. Ryan Coogler directs an outstanding film that manages to thoroughly entertain viewers, while also showcasing a fitting send off to Chadwick Boseman. Despite the hefty runtime, "Black Panther: Wakanda Forever" is loaded with intense action and heart-breaking emotion that keeps audiences engaged throughout, and sticks with you long after the credits have rolled.

Although it is not as good as the original one, we don't really need to compare them that much. It is a heartwarming tribute to Boseman's star role, and this story also feels fresh and it works on its own. As always with this universe, the characters, music, costume designs, visual effects, edition, performances, dialogues and much more elements all work together and create one of the best films that Marvel Studios has delivered recently. The cultural aspect is amazing as well and I enjoyed it profusely.

Chadwick Boseman became the Black Panther. He welcomed us to Wakanda. Outside, he remained as his character inspiring others. After "Endgame", he stood by Kevin Fiege in formally announcing "Black Panther II". Then a year later, he has become one within the Ancestral Plane. He was so great in embracing the role he could not be replaced, no matter if there are potential storylines for T'Challa to explore and grow. He owned the role by bringing him to life, and other portrayals afterwards followed his humane lead. We have seen recasts through the MCU, and they carried the characters well despite still missing the original star, but it is not the same on someone so incredibly definitive and personally close to the role till suddenly gone. The show still went on, for a reason to make him proud rather disappoint nor replace him, and "Black Panther: Wakanda Forever" became methodically personal, transcending above the MCU like an evolutionary cinematic piece. Chadwick died of colon cancer, only known by very few people being aware of his silent struggle over his final few years as he tackled projects and roles with 110% effort that finalizes his legacy while checking off some sort of bucket list. This real-life loss was integrated into the revised story. Originally, it was about T'Challa's grip on time after being blipped for five years, dealing with the political climate and his role as a father. Now in the given revision that acts as remembrance, Wakanda grieves over the sudden loss of their king that stirs intervening world powers to obtain their ancestrally cherished resources for their gain. With another nation, hidden from the world, threatening to surface war, Queen Ramonda must protect what is left of her family as Shuri is prolonging her grief, while the Wakandans as a whole strive to embrace this next chapter that would forge a new path for their kingdom. They will stand and fight, chanting T'Challa's call: Wakanda Forever! Already acknowledged out of preparation that this experience will differ without Boseman's outstanding energy, this became a very touching spiritual tribute that finely functions as closure on any sort of grief while somewhat. "Wakanda Forever" is not only your typical fashion of exceeding expectations, but it also became more than the MCU. To clarify, the interconnected films are mostly great in their own ways, some riveted only to the minimum four stars with questionable lows, as they embrace cinematic roots adjacent to their vast comic mythology while recognized as comic book adaptations. Only three features he directed priorly, storyteller Ryan Coogler continues expanding his craft from grounded "Fruitvale Station" to uplifting revival in "Creed" to culturally assimilated "Black Panther" whereas more topics are involved and thoroughly debated, further provoking thoughts. This is his fourth feature, ranking equally with the predecessor, and he achieved what any director sought through an artistically astonishing film. Uniquely presented, aesthetically distinctive apart from others, this is about a grieving assortment of well-established characters displaying their true strengths from experiencing losses and finding the courage to move on while protecting their nation from another with history under mirrored morality as counter reflection. Thematic communication in the narrative veins not only discusses grief next to family but also talks about power and sanctuary peace – as well empathetic royalty. These discourses became supportive structures in constructing the script under such thoroughness, they were thoughtfully written then remarkably executed as their own arguments with counterarguments fleshed out developmentally, continuing the politicism and switching around the questioned legacies that defined the first film as T'Challa became king. The wisdom he shared since "Civil War" is silently referenced under subtexts. If Boseman was still alive, grief would have been swapped with time as the only difference between the possible original vision and the final result. But then we would not have the emotionally difficult conflict that Shuri faces and how she connects with the film's antihero Namor's humanity through her inner struggle of unwillingness to let go. This is one of the two films' strongest elements since Wakanda is a hidden, invaluable nation that is advanced across technology and intelligence carefully treads unlike most others, till their considerable weakness under elitism when keeping outsiders from setting foot inadvertently open the setting to our reality. Hence how they are thematically driven with pivotal ideas spread out. Another elemental prominence that powers the themes is the emotional drive from the powerful performances, which is another bolstering source in its transcendent. As we explore the characters more, particularly both returning and introduced, they evolve towards newfound strength. Angela Basset as Ramonda is not just a mother, Letitia Wright as Shuri is not just a supportive intelligent sister who can fight, Lupita Nyong'o as Nakia is not just a love interest, Danai Gurira as fierce, traditional warrior Okoye is not just a loyal captain, and Winston Duke as M'Baku is not just a rebellious brawn for connective power. They become more, and the cast embrace their respective transformation, or better to describe it as a chance to explore more of their strengths and how to climb back up. They performed exceptionally, while Wright, Basset and Gurira in particular performed at their best when most charged, while one other performance is a satisfying surprise. Wright is the main star as she has been poised to take over the mantle, with reluctance hindered by grief over self-shame of failing to heal her brother (they bonded like true siblings in real life), held the film up with heightened caliber depicting raw emotions through her character's growth. She still has that humorous charm like everyone else, but this film dims more serious considering the stakes and how they pressure them down from fragility to truism. While Wright's performance is heartrending from the start then as an enjoyable presence till she mustered her resonating inner strength outwardly, her filmic mother figure Basset acknowledges her character is on the same boat and personally amplify it with a mesmerizing performance that solidifies the film's overall powerfulness as an emotional staple capably peaked. Her best scene may have been almost entirely glimpsed in the trailer – rightfully predicted towards her coming accolades, but the whole scene has proper buildup and a tearfully strained start. She was striking down on Gurira over a failed mission, and Gurira's keeps a stoic stance with constant fierceness and humor, but that moment broke her and brought out who she is within as a hefty representation for lined warriors.

Buena película, una secuela que cumple y que en mi opinión (ya que no me gusto mucho la primera) supera a la anterior cinta. Ryan Coogler logra hacer una secuela a la altura, el inicio es simplemente perfecto, la película es más una despedida a Chadwick Boseman, de ahí se me hizo muy inteligente que el conflicto interno de los protagonistas se base en la perdida, Shuri con T'Challa y Ramonda, y Namor el vengar la memoria de su mamá. El villano a mi me gusto, creo que tiene una buena motivación y cierra muy bien el personaje al final de la cinta, para mi fue de lo mejor. Por otro lado, cada montaje de la película tiene una obra de producción impresionante, cada escena es un deleite visual que junto a una fotografía con tintes naturistas combinada con una banda sonora perfecta, cada soundtrack te introduce en este mundo, Ludwig Göransson una vez mas demuestra su gran talento. Angela Bassett se roba la película, su impecable forma de extenuar sus sentimientos son los que le dan el peso que necesita esta película para funcionar, los actores son los encargados de navegar junto al espectador en los sentimientos de estos personajes, ellos son los que le dan vida a esta película que a diferencia de otras en la saga en esta se explora el lado mas humano de los mismos, sus propias inseguridades y hasta en su egoísmo, cosa que Letitia Wright y Tenoch Huerta hacen a la perfección. Hay aspectos que no me cerraron, ya que tiene cosas que no logran sentirse naturales, como la sobre exposición del conflicto que es muy notorio en las escenas de Valentina y Everett. Por otro lado, el ritmo es bastante lento y la duración de la cinta no acompaña nada, le sobran bastantes escenas con cosas que se podrían haber resuelto en un tiempo mas corto. Los efectos especiales, sobretodo en el aspecto de Black Panther, en el que ya en la anterior película en las escenas de pelea parece un videojuego. El personaje de Shuri esta vez ya convertida en Black Panther no me gusto tanto, me gustaron mas personajes como Okoye, Ramonda, Iron Heart, o M'Baku por ejemplo. En conclusión, una buena película, me parece muy larga y con un ritmo lento, cosa que no ayuda mucho a la cinta, pero hay cosas como el villano o la historia que cuenta que me gustaron bastante y no me parece que sea una mala cinta. La recomiendo.

This is a great, great Stanley Kubrick film. I first act of the film is the strongest, which some might consider a flaw. Vincent D'Onofrio really knocked it out of the park as Private Pile in what is quite possibly his career best performance. Before he got this role, he had gotten himself in the best shape of his life only to be offered a part in a Stanley Kubrick film, which was a dream for any actor in the world while Mr. Kubrick was still making films. He gained some 40 pounds only for Stanley to tell him that he just looks "like he could kick everybody's ass here". That meant he had to gain another 30 pounds to look like the pathetic Private Pile that Kubrick had in mind. He gained the weight, got the part, and the rest is history! Lee Ermey was born to play Gunnery Sergeant L. Hartman. He, Vincent D'Onofrio, and Matthew Modine absolutely owned the opening scene. Modine was exceptional in his role as Private Joker. Full Metal Jacket being a 1980s Vietnam War film, the comparisons to Platoon are inevitable. Oliver Stone's Platoon came out in 1986, and I consider it to be a masterpiece. Personally, I think it is the better film of the two, but Full Metal Jacket is certainly the more well-made, more professionally crafted film. Any critic can see the master at work in the finer details of the picture. Of course, Oliver Stone is a great filmmaker in his own right, but I'm sure even he would admit that Stanley Kubrick was the best or one of the top 2 or 3 in the history of cinema. I love Joker's thousand yards stare at the end of the movie. The film ends on an analytical note, appropriate for a combat correspondent. I most definitely recommend it. 94/100

The film is much more complete and powerful when honing in on his journey, an intellectual saddled with more empathy than an infantryman might like, he can see through the BS, but is he ultimately capable of harnessing the most primal of actions when a higher understanding demands it in the name of both mercy and necessity? Has anyone actually finished this film? Understandable if you haven't. The first half made such a significant impact that hardly anyone refers to the second half of the film. Rightfully so, considering how often R. Lee Ermey's legendary performance as Gny. Sgt. Hartman is quoted and referenced. Ironically, he wasn't even cast in the role when he earned the spot. Talk about manifesting your own destiny. Tim Colceri, the original actor hired to portray Hartman, still got his oft-quoted line in the movie though. "GET SOME!!" I would also be remiss if I didn't mention Vincent D'Onofrio's haunting performance as Private Pyle culminating in a scene so disturbing that I feel it's a right of passage for most cinephiles.

This film truly represents a mix of what made Stanley Kubrick a masterclass filmmaker and what he can't seem to get a grip of. 'Full Metal Jacket' is not bad by any means, it just feels inconsistent between the two parts it consists of. The first part, being the military training, is wildly entertaining, hilarious, and yet somber and concluded on a truly depraved note. The second part, being the meat of battle and combat, seems to lag and go for a bit too long (although still very thoughtful). It feels like Stanley is making two different films, one that works and one that exemplifies some of his flaws as a storyteller.

The conventional wisdom, that the boot camp section is great while the combat scenes are disappointing, fails to recognize how well the two halves of the movie mirror each other in both violent and sexual imagery.

Overall this is a great movie. Great acting, directing and writing. My only warning is you better not get triggered by people saying a mixture of slurs especially white people saying the Nword. If you can get past that then you're in for a treat. Kubrick is like Tarantino at points slow but everything has been thought through and is included for a reason and will build to really tense and high highs! I'd recommend this one for sure!

The war drama film, "Full Metal Jacket" (1987), directed by Stanley Kubrick is split into two parts. The first half follows U.S. Marines recruits as they train in a boot camp located in South Carolina and focuses on two privates nicknamed "Joker" and "Pyle" played by Matthew Modine and Vincent D'Onofrio, respectively. The film then switches to American soldiers including Joker as they actively fight in the Vietnam War. A crucial and captivating aspect of the film is the acting. Matthew Modine's portrayal of Joker as a quick-witted and morally grey character grounds the film and even helps balance the small bits of comedy with the harsh representation of war. Modine is skillful as he is able to switch from the squad's class clown to a serious Marine, who is fighting to stay alive while keeping his morals in check. Modine's best scene, in my opinion, is near the end revolving around the sniper. Just through his face alone, you can tell that Joker is going through a variety of thoughts and emotions as he's struggling with a hard choice to make. After doing so, his expression changes to capture the pain of war and how Joker has finally felt the true meaning of it. Another standout in the film is Vincent D'Onofrio as Pyle. Pyle is a slow-minded recruit but is also one of the more interesting and complex characters present in the film. In one of the more powerful and dramatic scenes in the whole movie which closes the first part, D'Onofrio shines as Pyle reaches a breaking point and chooses to fight back against his mistreatment, despite choosing the wrong way to go about it. It is a difficult one to watch thanks to D'Onofrio as the audience can empathize with him and what he goes through but at the same time, doesn't want him to go down the wrong path. You can feel Pyle's emotions boiling up to the surface through D'Onofrio's facial expressions and line delivery which drives home the uncomfortableness of the scene. As someone who doesn't really enjoy war movies, this one was no different. Although there were many parts of the film that interested me such as splitting it into two parts and the well-written characters, it was enough to win me over. I don't see myself recommending this movie to young viewers like myself as it was definitely a difficult watch from start to finish. However, it can be a good movie to watch for those interested in filmmaking and films in general as the writing and acting were the strongest parts in my opinion. I doubt I'll ever rewatch it again as it just wasn't for me. Overall, I would rate "Full Metal Jacket" 3.5/5 stars.

To mention this movie and The Deer Hunter, Casualties of War, or Platoon in the same sentence is shameful. The one-star is for D'Onofrio's performance. Ermey's character was over the top, bordering on comedic. The movie was boring overall and none of the characters were even remotely endearing or interesting. I'm flabbergasted this movie has garnered such good reviews. Full Metal Jacket is greatly overrated. It took me 35 years to watch it and that was 35 years too soon.

Kubrick has created a virtuous war movie. His signature style is on full display. The plot revolves around the Vietnam War and follows recruits through basic training and ultimately into war. During basic training we see the most iconic Drill Sergeant ever to appear on film preparing and molding his recruits for war. He is also trying to weed out the weak for their own good. He finds his target and then unleashes the most horrific psychological and physical torment ever portrayed on film. It is very difficult to view without feeling remorse for the target and respect for the Drill Sergeant. After basic training the plot follows the main character nicknamed Joker which is appropriate. Joker understands the duplicity of man and the absurdity of war. He is sent into war as a journalist but in the end becomes a product of the violence and environment he is submerged in. The platoon marches away from the battlefield singing in unison a song which this viewer believes Kubrick shot in order to convey his commentary on war and violence. The plot is dark, gritty, disturbing, violent and horrifying. This film has so many unforgettable scenes and dialogue. You'll hear fans quote famous lines such as, " Let me see your war face." to this day. FMJ is one of the most unique and insightful movies in it's genre.

I think what Full Metal Jacket intends is far better than what it actually is. It wears its themes on its sleeve and while the idea of showing the military brainwashing and dehumanization tactics in basic training that lead to broken people with guns leading a death parade in a country they know nothing about is fantastic, it only executes upon a percentage of this. The first half of the movie is intriguing with stellar performances and is iconic for a reason, but when the story transitions to Vietnam, it's frankly awful having to watch these guys "do war." They are disorganized, immature, selfish, and lacking humanity. Of course, in part it being awful to watch is the point. But moreover, the movie itself becomes disorganized and lacking humanity as well. It feels like a series of short stories with some being much more effective than others bookended by a random terrible narrator desperately hoping to pull it altogether. FMJ is ultimately interesting as it pulls off its darkly ironic tone. It's a story of men who don't know who they are, what they want, or how even how to be human. Are they to blame? Is the military to blame? The movie doesn't outright tell us, but it strongly suggests there's plenty of blame to go around.

A bipolar movie if there ever was one, the first half of this movie a masterpiece of storytelling, depicting life in Marine Boot Camp in the Carolinas, circa 1967. R Lee Ermey gives a career defining performance as the slightly off center DI Gunney; he should have at least been nominated that year, if not winning the Academy Award outright for best supporting actor. The second half of the movie, set in NAM during the onset of TET, was surprisingly ordinary, especially when compared to the rousing first half, although it begins promisingly enough with the half French, half Vietnamese hooker, immortalizing Me Love You Long Time to the tune of Nancy Sinatra's BOOTS. Since most of the NAM scenes take place in Saigon, Kubrick missed a golden opportunity to accentuate the urban inter-social elements, instead of the rather mundane battle sequences I suppose he was preprogrammed to follow from a book standpoint (never read it). 4.5 Stars though, for the unforgettable first half, and the promise of what could have been.
A brutal and at times confronting take on a popular subject and brilliantly done at that. Some amazing performances and a tight screenplay gives us one of 1987's best movies.

Shots of the portrayals of the Vietnam War are remarkable, Vincent D'Onofrio is impressive and language is used that probably provides a fairly realistic portrayal of training to be a U.S. marine for the war. An interview montage also provides important social commentary on the war.

Full Metal Jacket is masterfully knitted with a thick thread of dark tension, almost horror-like suspense, and intriguing character development. The film does an incredible job of expressing the aimlessness and sickening reality of the Vietnam War while staying true to what soldiers really did and creating a suspenseful storyline. The boot camp part of the film is particularly engaging. Vincent D'Onofrio is chilling and Kubrick is excellent. The best part, however, is the outstanding cinematography from start to finish.

Full Metal Jacket is a cinematic masterpiece that stands the test of time as one of the most iconic war films in history. Directed by the legendary Stanley Kubrick, this film explores the dehumanizing effects of war on soldiers, through the lens of the Vietnam War. The film is split into two distinct parts - the first follows a group of young Marine recruits as they undergo intense training under the watchful eye of the merciless Gunnery Sergeant Hartman, played brilliantly by R. Lee Ermey. This segment is a tour de force of filmmaking, with Ermey's commanding presence and the intense physicality of the training exercises creating an unforgettable and often unsettling experience for the viewer. The second half of the film follows the same group of soldiers as they are deployed to Vietnam, and here Kubrick expertly conveys the chaos and horror of war. The scenes of combat are visceral and intense, with Kubrick's signature long takes immersing the viewer in the action. The standout performance in this segment comes from Vincent D'Onofrio, who plays the troubled and ultimately tragic Private Pyle with an eerie intensity. Full Metal Jacket is a film that is not afraid to confront the darker aspects of war and the human psyche. It's a powerful and thought-provoking work that continues to captivate audiences decades after its initial release. From the iconic "This is my rifle" scene to the haunting closing shot, every moment of this film is a testament to Kubrick's masterful storytelling and filmmaking skills.
Gunnery Sergeant Hartman the Drill Instructor completely steals the show. A performance that's so remarkable and memorable it has you withdrawn once he's out of the picture.

Full metal jacket tiene un cómico y entretenido primer acto gracias a las ironías ,burlas ,chistes etc que suceden en el entrenamiento militar algo que en si es difícil saber que fue así el trato pero que entretiene ,luego el tono da un gran giro cambiando esto en el comienzo del segundo acto con drama y oscuridad que muestra los posibles daños mentales a una persona con un trato inhumano algo que plasma de manera atemorizante vincent d´onofrio una gran actuación sin dudas ,el resto del segundo y tercer acto se enfoca en lo que fue la guerra de Vietnam y lo que es en general las guerras ,batallas sin sentido que solo traen muerte donde inocentes ,niños ,mujeres y hombres llegan a ser asesinados o corrompidos ,una historia con un gran trasfondo junto a increíbles actuaciones y un guion oscuro e irónico.

Never have 2 hours felt so short. Kubrick masterfully tells two stories in one film; one of the dehumanization soldiers go through, and one of the realities of war, and it's the shocking speed at which these two stories flow into each other that makes the viewer also realize that a boot camp is far from the real thing. Amazing sets, some quality cinematography and great acting pull it all together. Sure, this movie doesn't do anything new or have a very interesting message, but it's rock solid all around otherwise.

Really enjoyed the first half of the movie. It was definitely great for its time, but the second half of the movie was completely different than the first half, and felt very similar to other war movies. Still good though, just wish the first half of the movie was capitalized on more.

Certain happenings could have benefitted from a more lingering effect, but Full Metal Jacket is a visceral, immersive and brutal analysis of the dehumanizing effects war and mental overload has on humans and also sees Kubrick use a lot of his trademark conventions and dark thrills to masterful result.

Had to watch this for History and WOW, the performances are awesome of everyone. These locations man and the cinematography and that all without visual effects, thats mental to me. The story was fine for me, it didnt really impress me because i have seen stories like this before, but honestly this is one of the first in its kind, so i cant blame the movie for that. The screenplay was really good and i have nothing to add to that. Its not really my kinda movie, but i really appreciate the filmmaking behind this whole movie, because it is mind blowing for 1987. That war sequence, heads of for the location scouts and the set designers, pfff.

First Half of the Film is one of the greatest first half's of any war film ever made. Second half is good but nowhere near as strong as the first. A Classic War Movie still. Anyone who is a fan of the genre or fan of any actors involved should give this a watch.

Stanley Kubrick fanatics have debated what is Kubrick's greatest film. Spartacus? Dr. Strangelove or: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bomb? 2001: A Space Odyssey? A Clockwork Orange? The Shining? None of them. The true greatest work of art by Stanley Kubrick is Full Metal Jacket. His take on the Vietnam War gives us a joker (Matthew Modine) and his life in the military during the Vietnam War. To start things off, the film's acting is spectacular. The performances from Matthew Modine, Vincent D'Onofrio, and especially R. Lee Ermey are all fantastic. R. Lee Ermey especially simply because he does a great job and gives us a memorable performance as the no nonsense drill sergeant. The music throughout the entire film fits the Vietnam War theme. Last but not least, the cinematography is nuanced throughout the entire film especially during the film's climax. Stanley Kubrick's Full Metal Jacket is intense, artistic, and even darkly comedic. The way Stanley Kubrick made the film is so perfect.
Great acting. But I didn't watch this at the time it came out for the same reason I could only give it 3 stars now. It's preaching to the converted, with blood everywhere.

Stanley Kubrick had such a storied carrier as a filmmaker and he is one of the few that could do any genre well. This is no exception. This is, essentially, two films about Vietnam tied together for one masterful tale. The first half involved boot camp and contains some of the most iconic and copied scenes ever to hit the scene. R. Lee Ermey's portrayal of the drill sergeant is iconic and copied but never equalled. Vincent Donofrio's portrayal of Private "Pyle" is not only the best of his career, but among the best you will see. The second half of the movie is a look at the front lines from the perspective of Matthew Modine's character. This is among the most dark and realistic portrayal of war ever filmed. Kubrick's Direction and cinematography make this hard to watch at times, but worth the investment.

While it may not be one of Stanley Kubrick's best films, Full Metal Jacket is distinctly a Kubrick film. The takes are long and filled with lengthy tracking shots, slow zooms and methodical pans, all traits of his later work. Dealing with the devastating dehumanization of war on its participants, the film is essentially told in two parts – Marine basic training followed by combat in Vietnam. The first portion features powerful performances by R. Lee Ermey as the sadistic Sergeant Hartman and Vincent D'Onofrio as the object of Hartman's abuse while the second half deals with Private Joker (Matthew Modine), a Marine journalist covering the war at the time of the Tet Offensive. Where does the film falter? Not for one second does the film look or feel like Vietnam, despite the dying palm trees spread around the shooting locations. As well, the soundtrack (Chapel of Love, Wooly Bully, Surfin' Bird, etc.) is totally out of place and wince-worthy. All in all, it's a decent movie – just not decent by Kubrick's standards.

Hilarious movie, and still plenty serious. Balanced that line pretty well. Leonard's character felt a little too exaggerated. I don't understand how someone like that can last as long as he did in basic without being discharged. For example, he clearly wasn't passing the fitness tests (or at the very least he barely was). Very enjoyable overall aside from a few plot points.

Kubrick's Follow up Film From The Shining Full Metal Jacket Offers Viewers Something Different From the War Film Genre from Explosive Violence it Offers how the Character's Get their where they are Ready for the War, a Madness endure from being a harmless to a violent world of Madness where the characters like the madness they enter but that's my view into the film the first act looks into the Boot camp of two Soldiers Nicknamed Joker and Pyle who Prepare to enter Vietnam for war while Both Struggle from the None Stop Abuse from Their Drill instructor and the later half focusing on the their own struggle in the war zone they enter overall the film is tension and unlike any war film I've seen where Kubrick Slowly Building up its story and Characters but i found the Films ending to Be A Let down and undercooked

Spoilers without context: - jelly doughnuts - SIR YES SIR - soap - mickey mouse clubhouse! I will be completely honest. My ratings for Full Metal Jacket went up and down like a rollercoaster ride while viewing. It started as a 4 ; then going up to a 5 to only later drop to a 4.5; the 4.5 became a 3 but don't panic! My rating ended in a 4.5. I still cannot decipher why I cannot give it a full 5 but forget numbers. Full Metal Jacket is officially in the top 5 of Kubrick films. War films are nothing new but it's how you make something repetitive look new where you find cinema. He captures the dehumanization of a man in war. Every scene has an important message and we see a blend of cynical humor, (surprisingly) heart, and disaster all in one. Full Metal Jacket does a full damn circle. Raftman begins timid, not really getting in on the war action until the end when he kills the sniper. He yells loud and proud with curse words how happy he is for murdering the enemy. Joker expresses his desire to shoot a gun at an early age yet he's conflictive thoughout the film, whether it's not wanting to join in on the soap-beating of Private Pyle or leaving the sniper to die on her own. Animal is known as this rock with zero f**ks, a killing machine yet we almost see this as a facade of a man who is suffering on the inside from the war and whether or not he shows it, there's still some human in him. Pyle is an interesting character. We experience the slow destruction of a human finishing in the climatic bathroom scene. It's the ending for me. One can't help but chuckle to soldiers marching by burning buildings while singing a Mickey Mouse chant. But, the laughter is short because it is actually chilling. These men still are "kids," who went into a controversial and unnecessary war extremely soon in their lives and in the process lost a huge chunk of their being, yet there is still a tiny percentage of childhood left in them. Talk about an ending. Also, one can't help but hear Gunnery Sergeant's Hartman voice saying, "What is this Mickey Mouse horseshit?! "In short, I'm in a world of shit yes, but I am alive and I'm not afraid.

Full Metal Jacket is locked and loaded from the opening scene. Like the marines to be you dive head first into the angry barrage of insults hurled from the mouth of a true drill sergeant R Lee Ermey. Like the Great War movies alike the story isn't so much about the war but how the human lives in and around the war are effected by it. If this movie had a personality it would hum to the tune of "War" by Edwin Starr.

One of Kubrick's later films, I really consider this film his best attempt to portray the ramifications of war since his early Paths of Glory. The plot of the film follows American soldiers from their first time army train camps to their horrifying experiences in the Vietnam war. The film is distinctively divided in two parts, the first, where we are presented the difficul times of some soldiers named Gomer Pyle, Joker, Animal Mother etc. in an army camp, and their training by psychotic Gunnery Seargant Hartman (R.L. Ermey, in what I believe to be one of the greatest acting achievements in film and some of the best character acting on the screen, I cannot get enough of him) up until the murder of Hartman by Gomer Pyle, who lost his mind after incessant bullying by his peer and harsh training, and the latter's suicide. Up until the ending of the first part, the film maintained a rather dark comical tone, with some harrowing moments, but overall excellent improv by Ermey. The second part of the film follows the soldiers in an attempt to fight off Vietnamese troops, and despite losing friends, they manage to clear the area, but with serious casualties, such as their mental health (important to note that the camera always follows Private Joker and the repercussions war has had on him). The characteristic ending follows the soldiers in a burning landscape marching to their base while singing the Mickey Mouse Clubhouse song, quite ironic, innit. I have nothing but praise for everything, from the carefully adapted screenplay that takes a rather cliche story and elevates it to a whole new level, to technical achievements such as cinematography, art direction, editing and art direction, the sigature Kubrick direction and amazing work from the cast. Only complaint is that after the end of the first part, the tone of the film shifts so suddenly that it takes a while to get used to it, it just feels like the two parts are two different movies. But overall, great film, possibly one of the most darkly comical, harrowing, hard hitting, best examples of war cinema to come out in the 80s. YOU LITTLE SCUMBAG, I GOT YOUR NAME, I GOT YOUR

Dark, disturbing, mind-numbingly violent and thought-provoking, with some particularly unforgettable scenes. That being said, there is something messy about it, and it doesn't hold a candle to some of Kubrick's other films. The ending is quite unsatisfactory.

Really good movie. My only complaint is that the first part of the movie feels a little bit unnecessary a0nd it drags on for too long don't get my wrong it was a good part just a bit odd.

R. Lee Ermey absolutely kills this first act yet again, delivering banger after banger in his maniacal deconstruction of the unit, and especially D"Onofrio. The emotions I feel while watching his insane behavior so vigorously accepted as "normal" by his cadets varies from absurd hilarity, to rage, and then to sadness, among others. There are some stunning shots in the second half which Kubrick gives a totally different look and feel, while sacrificing none of the emotional impact. The final scenes of the unit moving through the fire bombed city of Hue came to mind while watching the portrayal of Ecoust at night in Mendes and Deakins' 1917, as both are equally breathtaking in both their beauty and portrayal of destruction.

It's one superb movie through the 45-minute first act and it follows up with another act that is good, but just not up to the standard of the first. The first-act climax shouldn't be the movie's defining moment. Otherwise, it's a tremendous film.

Full Metal Jacket finds the perfect balance of humor and disturbing realism. With powerhouse performances from Matthew Modine, Vincent D'Onofrio, and R. Lee Ermey, this movie packs a big punch, mostly due to the amazing direction of Stanley Kubrick.
My favorite film, one of the best films I've ever seen, thank you Kubrick for showing us this brilliant...no...amazing movie! Hope you rest in peace, with your other successes.

The first half of the movie is OK, and then the second half is like watching an entirely different movie, we have put some emotional effort into the characters for most of them not to show up again! It's actually kind of disappointing.
Not for everyone but covers the subject in an very interesting and stylish way from start to finish. It proves the point that soldiers are normal people.
One of my favorites. A two part movie about training in boot camp and then action in Viet Nam. Humor, drama, suspense. A must see classic!
I really dont want to say anything but its a must watch if you love cinema and if you want to see R. Lee Ermey brillant performance in this film. Much Love.

This is my 2nd favorite War film of all time (1st being "Saving Private Ryan"). This film is great. The acting, and the war sequences were amazing in this film. This is definitely my favorite Stanley Kubrick film and one of my favorite films of all time.

Amazing movie and very fun to watch. First half was humorous, second half has suspense. I think a good idea would be a sequel set decades later about Pvt. Joker or Animal Mother replacing Gny. Sgt. Hartman's job as the Senior Drill Instructor
The 2nd best war film I've ever seen (first being Fury), and has terrific acting from everyone and great war elements to it. Definitely Stanley Kubrick's best movie.

Great pacing, characters, action, cinematography. Balances out some the depressing themes in the Vietnam War with some dark humor. The fun '60s music spices things up perfectly. Robert Lee Ermey is a legend and is the most iconic and quotable drill sergeant ever. Might be my favorite Stanley Kubrick film so far.

My 2nd favorite War film of all time (1st being "Saving Private Ryan"). This film is great. The acting, and the war sequences were amazing in this film. This is definitely my favorite Stanley Kubrick film and one of my favorite films of all time.

One of the most raw war films to be made. No nicely wrapped ending or fluffy bits. Full Metal Jacket is what Platoon could have been without the self-importance. But then, Oliver Stone is no Stanley Kubrick.

Quality filmmaking, but also very cold, sterile, without much of a human touch. Kubrick's take on Vietnam is filled with amazing cinematography, great performances, and an anti-war message. The movie almost feels like two separate films with one showing the boot camp experience and the psychological toll is can take on recruits. The second is about the experience of soldiers in Vietnam. You never feel too invested in the characters, as little is fleshed out about who they are and why we should care. It ends on a somewhat anti-climactic and melancholy note, showing the pointlessness of war and the cost it takes in human lives. My main gripe is that it never truly "feels" like we are in Vietnam, due to the fact that it was shot in England with only a few imported palm trees to maintain the illusion. Too much gray and not enough green jungle to really make it look like Vietnam rather than a set in near London. Still a well made film and worth your time.

This movie was really good!!! My favorite part of the movie is the training scenes and the jelly doughnut!!! Also my favorite part is the sergeant!!! He cracks me up every time!!! I thought Matthew Modine as Private Joker was great and he knew what he was doing!!! He alo made a great narrator throughout the movie!!!

A stark and uncompromising look at the Vietnam war, with a hyper-sense of realism and extremely impactful imagery. It's pacing gets a tad sluggish and the second act pales in comparison to the first but the movie is a masterpiece regardless.
Great performances, shocking and fun story, incredible cinematography and hard but realistic storytelling. This, Kubrick's one of the best works, is also one of the best war movies ever made.

"Born to kill", this movie is not just about the war like the typical war movie and its cliches we've all seen but the psychology behind it. The first half of the movie it's a pleasure to watch with that darkly comic, the screenwriting is sensational, this film caught you since the opening scene with the original soundtrack.

Intense, iconic, and darkly hilarious at times. Stanley Kubrick's brilliant Vietnam war drama follows PVT. Joker, a USMC war correspondent for 'Stars&Stripes', through boot camp and eventually, through his war. There are the Kubrick themes. The duality of man. "The Jungen thing, Sir!" As Joker put it. I could talk about it for a long time. Almost as long as Apocalypse Now. And this film is a classic, right up there with that picture it's a must see. Music is used to good effect here and the whole film is very memorable. A mark of a great film is how memorable it is. The next day after watching this, I remembered everything. Especially the first act. R.Lee. Ermy. The Drill Sgt. Wow. What a performance. He steals the entire first act. Such a powerful and funny performance. All in all, it's a must see. Gunnery Sgt. Hartman: "Well it looks to me like the best part of you ran down the crack of your momma's ass and ended up as a brown stain on the mattress! I think you've been cheated!"

Never underestimate Stanley Kubrick's ability to reach out of the screen and play with your brain like some cosmic Rubik's cube. It's a comedy, it's a tragedy. It's two short stories in one. It's a hilarious look at the shortcomings of men. It's a poignant and timeless allegory of the horrors of war. It's an investigation into enemies at home and enemies abroad. I guess he was trying to suggest something about the duality of man, sir.

A true cinematic masterpiece. Each and every scene has so much thought and emotion into it. Just randomly pause the movie at any point in time and not only is it visually stunning, but that still image also provides such a story. Dark humor, realism, social truths that are still relevant today, and scenes that will stick with you until you are old and grey. The best Vietnam, or might I say war movie, of all time.

Great movie. Second half seems a little slow in the beginning but quickly picks it up in the end in the sniper sequences. Both endings of the halves are drawing parallels of each other. Very impactful movie on the dehumanization of individuals during the war.

I know people rave about their loooove of Kubrick but I can never understand why. He's obvious, clumsy and heavy handed in the way he delivers his messages and conveys emotion in films. His films in their entirety are the equivalent of the Bill Shatner acting method. If he thought something was important it needed LOUD MUSIC, and if a person was going crazy they needed to look straight at the camera from under their brow in a menacing fashion. This movie is one that embodies all of these characteristics and then some. If you want to be a person who feels smart by quoting a bad movie then by all means use this one. But if you'd rather go with a movie that was done better, had a clearer message, and is much less embarrassing to quote, go with Platoon or Apocalypse Now. But stop pretending like Kubrick was good at this. He wasn't.
Yet another great film from Kubrick. This movie skillfully examines the psychological effects of war on soldiers, and is one of the best war movies of all time.
Strong opening with the training process. However, not a very compelling story and is weaker towards the end. Not many standout performances other than R. Lee Ermey's character as the drill sergeant.

It's hard to evaluate this film on it's own merits when considering the fact that one of the greatest directors of all time, Stanley Kubrick, made it and I recently saw The Deer Hunter (1978) and Apocalypse Now (1979). I will try to do that however as I still feel that divorced from the specter of those two elements this film doesn't completely work. I wasn't as disturbed as I should have been and I felt that a lot of the acting aimed for the sort of over the top pastiche that became iconic in a lot of Kubrick's other films but didn't quite reach it. It's not on the level of Barry Lyndon (1975) or A Clockwork Orange (1971) but it's unfair to ask for that level of quality with most films. This isn't a much watch unlike Kubrick's other work and I would recommend that you watch most of his other films before venturing to see this one. Private Joker, Matthew Modine, and Gomer Pyle, Vincent D'Onofrio, go through boot camp under the tutelage of Gunnery Sergeant Hartmann, R. Lee Ermey. Hartmann proves to be extremely tough and he turns all of the recruits against Pyle due to his being overweight which causes him to be physically and emotionally abused and ultimately commit a violent act. We jump forward to 1968 in the second half of the film as we see Joker become a journalist for The Stars and Stripes who write military propaganda. His relatively carefree life is interrupted when an attack on his marine base and he and other writers are left to defend themselves amongst the rubble. Eventually they discover that the sniper who murdered one of their friends is just a little girl but Joker is still pushed to kill her at her own request. The scenes in the film that work best are, in my opinion, those that come in the second half of the film. The first half felt like it was stealing from Catch-22 (1970) and MASH (1970) with the satirical elements it incorporated and while Ermey's performance is deserving of it's iconic status I felt he was a touch overused. The second half settled down a little and chose to satirize propaganda and then show the dark effects of the war on innocent people. I was emotionally impacted by the scenes that feature people being devastated by warfare and while other films show death and destruction better Kubrick at least shows he can make a film in which he is emotionally engaged. This may be a controversial opinion because I understand that a lot of people are big fans of the first half while they think the second drops into mediocrity, I would still tend to disagree. I suppose another thing I felt was missing from this film was an interesting visual style. Every other Kubrick film looks amazing and you feel as though the director has focused each shot intensely in an attempt to execute his outlandish vision. Cinematographer Douglas Milsome also worked on three of Kubrick's other films so he clearly knows how to make a film look beautiful but this film just looks sort of blah. Even Platoon (1986) looks better than this film and I have many problems with that film relating to how the director deals with the material he is working with. Not every film needs to look incredible to be affecting but a large part of the reason why Kubrick films are so brilliant are their visuals and you expect to see something new and exciting on the screen every time you watch one of his films. In the end I would say that this film is worth watching even if it's not a masterpiece because it's still post Paths of Glory (1957) Kubrick and we should treasure his work as he only provided us with a few great films but truly great ones at that. I am going to watch the only Kubrick film I have not seen this afternoon and I hope that it is better than this film but if it were on the same level I would still be able to appreciate it in some ways because it would still be better than most films.

Would've gotten a 5 star rating if the 2nd half of the movie(In Vietnam) was as good as the first. Ermy nailed the role as a drill sargent. The movie is unique as a war film because none of the other ones show how boot camp really was in those days. It's a great look at how the military molds young kids into killer soldiers. The second half it kinda felt like Kubrick didn't know what to have the characters do. Still it was entertaining, and actually really funny.

Classic Kubrick film. Disturbing and genius. People who say they don't like or don't get the second half do not understand this film or truly appreciate it. The second half does not make sense in some ways because WAR does not make sense. That is the entire message of this film. R. Lee Ermey definitely gives the most memorable performance in this film as drill instructor Sgr. Hartman. While it is difficult to choose a favorite Kubrick film, this is definitely in my top three!

Stanley Kubrick knows how to make good movies, that really aren't special. The first half of this movie was amazing. The drill sergeant, fantastic. The script and set-up, couldn't have been better made than this. This part was realistic and gripping at the same time. The second half though, was boring and forgettable. Severely lacking in action, character, and poignancy. It should have stopped when it was ahead. I recommend watching the first half and skipping everything else.
Kubrick depicts the raw reality of being a marine during both training and real action. Soundtrack, dialogue, occasional irony and action manage to keep you hooked up until the very end.

Full Metal Jacket set the standard for most contemporary war films. It doesn't have that much of a plot per se, but it is full of extremely memorable and startling moments. The horror is softened (or enhanced) by a great soundtrack.

One of my favorite all time war films, one reason why its one of my favorite wars films is because of its even handedness, even though the film is from an American soldiers perspective the ugliness of both sides of war is clear to see. Another reason I really like this film is its unapologetic dark humor and memorable characters.
Not a fully realistic war film, but director Stanley Kubrick is highly effective at getting his points across.. Hyper realism.. Hilarious first act, hyperreal second act.

Full Metal Jacket was Kubrick's take on war and what it entails. Divided into two stories this is one hard hitting film. The first focuses on a bunch of new recruits in boot camp and the other takes place smack in the middle of a warzone. Full of images that stick in mind and some great use of music Full Metal Jacket is Kubrick through and through. From the long takes to the nihilistic overtones there is a stamp of authority of the master filmmaker. The acting, as is the case with every Kubrick film is sublime especially Mathew Modine and Vincent D' Onofrio. If you want to see an auteur at work Full Metal Jacket is a film you should check out. (A master's outlook on war presented on film).

The first half set in a military boot camp is very entertaining and honestly really funny with the drill sergeant Hartman absolutely carrying the whole sequence with his stellar performance. The second half is set in Vietnam and is a lot darker with some unconventional filming that makes this half feel very surreal. The first half is a solid 10/10 and the second is a 8/10.

Stanley Kubrick has made many movies that people either love or hate, A Clockwork Orange, 2001: A Space Odyssey, Eyes Wide Shut, movies that are not very popular but are liked by some people, Barry Lyndon, Dr. Strangelove, Paths of Glory, and there are his movies that everyone pretty much loves, The Shining, and the movie I will be reviewing today, Full Metal Jacket. I picked this up at my local library on blu ray and watched it on a friday night. On the way home, my dad asked me what movie I got, I showed him the blu ray, and he was like "that's a very good movie" and yeah that was all. Watching Full Metal Jacket, it didn't remind me of other good war films I've seen. It was very different from Saving Private Ryan, Dunkirk, Hacksaw Ridge, it is really unique, probably the most unique war film I've ever seen. The storytelling and the elements in the story about the Vietnam war really made it raw. That's how I'd describe the movie, raw. R. Lee Ermey really gave one of the best performances in history in this movie, in my opinion. Even though he was on screen for about 15 minutes, he made those 15 minutes so intense, so great, and gives the movie dark comedic scenes. I think his performance as Sgt. Hartman is one of the best performances of all time. Vincent D'Onofrio's performance as a private that struggles in the beginning of the movie because of military training camp being too hard for him, and R. Lee Ermey's character being a hard mentor, challenging Vincent D'Onofrio's character physically and mentally, it is really compelling stuff. The part where he shoots Sgt. Hartman, then shoots himself, is one of the most jaw dropping scenes of all time. The look on Vincent D'Onofrio's face in that scene haunted me for the rest of that night. There is also another main character in this movie named Joker, (that's his nickname). He is in this military camp with Vincent D'Onofrio's character, and he goes through this camp, watching horrific things happen, you really get into the shoes of this character. The next acts of this movie is Joker going to Vietnam and experiencing the war. This part of the movie was really different from the first part back on Parris Island. A lot of people thought this 2nd part of the movie was not as good as the first part, but I thought both parts were great. The Vietnam war was portrayed so rough and raw in this movie, it was pretty breathtaking. The message/allegory of this story was so beautiful and 100% true, it really makes me look at war differently. The only issue I have with this movie is that I thought the movie really dragged at the middle of the film. Not much things were going on, there wasn't really much of a direction either, it just kind of felt like the story was going nowhere. Other than that, I thought this movie was really good. 9/10

Gran bel film firmato Stanley Kubrick. La pellicola è una di quelle in cui la storia è si importante ma la cosa più rilevante è il messaggio, la critica, che il regista vuole lanciare. In questo caso Kubrick si scaglia contro la guerra e l'addestramento militare che trasformano l'uomo in una macchina di morte, fatta solo per uccidere e infatti lo possiamo cogliere nel finale quando Joker uccide la ragazzina e i suoi compagni gli dicono di essere un "duro", o anche nel momenti in cui i personaggi difendono la base e nel mentre scherzano tra di loro. Il personaggio più umano è quello di Matthew Modine, ovvero Joker, e nonostante questo anche lui è diventato una macchina, non è più un uomo. Bellissimo il fatto che sull'elmetto, quindi sul cervello, avesse la scritta "Born to kill" e sul cuore avesse una spilla che rappresentava la pace. È stato bravissimo, ma Vincent D'Onofrio (Palla di lardo) e R. Lee Ermey (Sergente Hartman) sono stati strabilianti. Bella la colonna sonora, grandiosa la regia e anche la fotografia. Filmone.

Full Metal Jacket was Kubrick's take on war and what it entails. Divided into two stories this is one hard hitting film. The first focuses on a bunch of new recruits in boot camp and the other takes place smack in the middle of a warzone. Full of images that stick in mind and some great use of music Full Metal Jacket is Kubrick through and through. From the long takes to the nihilistic overtones there is a stamp of authority of the master filmmaker. The acting, as is the case with every Kubrick film is sublime especially Mathew Modine and Vincent D' Onofrio. If you want to see an auteur at work Full Metal Jacket is a film you should check out.

Another good film by Stanley Kubrick. "Full Metal Jacket" is a good potrayal of what war is like. Gritty, brutal, and intense in some moments, while having a few snippets of humor here and there, is a solid and realistic look at what war is like for veterans of the marine corps and navy.

Full Metal Jacket (1987) ??? / ???? Stanley Kubrick's vivid depiction of Vietnam splits in two halfs; emotionally shattering examination of boot camp and actual fighting on the field. This film is one of the first that comes to mind when thinking of all of Kubrick's masterpieces, and it's not hard to see why. For starters, the setting brilliantly captures the tense atmosphere of Marine Corps training to prepare for war. This is best demonstrated when looking at the character Leonard Lawrence, better known as Private Pyle. Over the course of the first half of the film, Sargent Hartman, the brutal drill instructor, belittles him for being slow-witted and overall just not prepared for battle. To make matters worse he decides to punish the rest of the Marines for Pyle's mistakes. This is first seen when Pyle smuggles a doughnut because he could not deal with the feeling of hunger. Hartman retaliates by forcing the entire cabin to do intense exercises, causing them all to dislike Pyle. Tired of all of Pyle's screw ups, the entire bunk gives Pyle a beating. By each getting a towel, filling it with a bar of soap, and proceeding to hit him in the stomach repeatedly while others hold him down. After feeling immense pain and realizing that everyone hates him, Pyle loses all emotion and becomes a killing machine. Hartman and the others are very proud of him and all seems well until the next night. Private Joker, one of Pyle's fellow Marines, hears a noise in the restroom and decides to investigate only to find Pyle loading a rifle. Joker tells Pyle to go back to sleep and put his rifle away or else they will be in a world of shit. Pyle responds with, "I'm already in a world of shit!", and proceeds to repeat various chants that were spoken on their marches. After hearing all of the shouting Hartman storms in and proceeds to yell at Pyle and belittle him more. Void of all emotion and thought, Pyle shoots Hartman in the chest, killing him. Realizing what he had done, Pyle spends a few minutes reflecting, only before putting the rifle in his mouth and blowing his brains out. While all of this is very malicious and depressing, it is very realistic and corresponds to the tense environment of war to the point that it is almost beautiful. The training portion of the film is one of my favorite parts of any movie to this date earning this movie an easy five star rating. The section that illustrates war in Vietnam is also well made, but is honestly quite forgettable when looking at the first half of the film. Yet, this is still a movie that I would recommend to anyone, whether they typically enjoy films of this genre.

This is, quite simply, the greatest (anti)war film ever made. A film in two halves, the training segment is a perfect balance of dark humor & dramatic insanity, & the Vietnam segment is depressingly violent & visually impeccable. Though they are disparate, they work together to show the dehumanizing nature of all aspects of war: the ugliness, the complication, the lack of cinematic heroism. One of Kubrick's quickest paced, least opaque & most accessible films...& yet another directing masterpiece.

Unique, well crafted, and a story that doesn't have to overly develop it's characters to get the point across. Similar to Dunkirk in that manner, but executed a little bit better in my opinion.Great movie.

A film of two halves, with the first being far superior to the second. As the cadets are put through their paces at a strict training camp, we witness the gruelling nature of what it could possibly have felt like being at the mercy of a sadistic sergeant major. You'd like to hope that the scenes are exaggerated for our entertainment value, but I suspect there is an underlying truth about how the events had the potential to pan out in those days. In the 2nd half, we witness the boys in real life combat in the Vietnam war. On paper, this should have been better, more action, more blood, and more drama, however it didn't materialise. Whether I just felt bewildered by what seemed a completely new cast or whether I was completely sidetracked from giving it my full attention, it just felt very anticlimactic in comparison.

To me this was always two separate movies.The first part(boot camp) is very good mpstly because of of Eremy.The second part is a generic war picture.Take the first part, extent it, drop the second part and you have a perfect movie.

Unforgettable performance by R. Lee Ermey as the drill instructor and very memorable performance by Vincent D'Onofrio as Pvt Pyle. This movie gets very intense in basic training and there are basically 2 parts to the story. Basic Training and being in Vietnam. The first half of the movie is way better then the 2nd half. R. Lee shines as DI Hartman and gives the viewer a sense of how hard Basic Training is. the 2nd half of the film is set in Vietnam and is average at best. There is no real plot to the movie. It's main purpose is to show the viewer that war is hell and unpredictable. Not my favorite Kubrick film, but still a very good film.
Though it occasionally stalls after the 45 minute mark. Stanley Kubrick’s Full Metal Jacket is a darkly comical and haunting depiction of the Vietnam War.
Full Metal Jacket is a aggressive and hard edged war film from Stanley Kubrick! Great performances and brilliant direction and crazy action scenes make you feel for the characters!

Frankly, I loved the film. It was a little disorienting, in that there are essentially two different parts of the film. I got so invested in Pyle's story and watching that evolve, that I found myself having to readjust when the film segued into following Joker's story. Up until Pyle shot himself, I had assumed that this story was about Pyle. It was interesting to me that the perspective seemed to change in each part of the film. The first part seemed to be more from Pyle's perspective, to then set up the second part of the film being from Joker's perspective. It made me feel intrigued by the psyche of the men in the military. It made me also feel concerned for how the constant negating and invalidating affects these men. The pace of the film was also interesting. Things sort of seemed to have a slow build in the beginning up until Pyle's emotional turn took place. For me, the same thing happened in the second part of the film when Joker and his crew were backed into a corner with the Vietnamese. In both parts of the film, it was interesting that there was this slower-paced nonchalant approach to setting up these stories, however, once things got going we very much-so "zoomed in" to the conflict in the story and what was going on. Music was a big part of the movie, however, in these moments Kubrick chose to have no, or very little, music be a part of them. For me, it allowed me to be more attentive to what was going on and what was at stake.

An incredible achievement of dialogue, visual character development, tension, and the ability to throw us into the harsh mindset that soldiers are forced into during war. Definitely one of Kubrick's best.

sir, no sir.. Full Metal Jacket Just like The Clockwork Orange, it takes too much time to prove a point and even though it is finely detailed and explicitly executed the journey for around 2 hours just doesn't seem worthy at the end. Stanley Kubrick's smart adaptation and perfect execution works on its level and won't disappoint the fans but fails to deliver anything beyond that as the mere far fetched idea fades off slowly before one's eyes where even lousy editing too, becomes responsible. Matthew Modine at the centre of it pulls it off swiftly and smoothly but is overpowered by a stunning performance by Vincent D'Onofrio despite of just being a supportive character. Full Metal Jacket resonates too much with The Clockwork Orange as it raises similar questions, offers enough doubts and thrills which becomes redundant at a certain point and as always lacks better editing.

As far as war films go, this is one of my favourites. I liked how it can be Funny at time's then changes to a really dark tone. I also really love the marine montage at the beginning.

The much-acclimated movie left me disjointed. The first half of the movie's storyline follows a platoon of U.S. Marines through their training, it's a laughter ride with its silly, stupid and vulgar jokes and I loved it. The second half focuses on the experience of one of the marines in the Vietnam War itself. This was boring, confusing and frustrating and I hated it. I had two very different experiences for two sides of the same storytelling.

Maybe not as good as it's been talked up to be, but still a solid war film. Based on Gustav Hasford's novel The Short Timers, the film's first half details the volunteers' harrowing boot-camp training under the profane, power-saw guidance of drill instructor Sgt. Hartman (R. Lee Ermey, a real-life drill instructor whose performance is one of the most terrifyingly realistic on record). Part two takes place in Nam, as seen through the eyes of the now thoroughly indoctrinated marines. Ironically, Full Metal Jacket was filmed almost entirely in England. "Full Metal Jacket" was one of the movies that was talked about when I praised films such as "Hacksaw Ridge". Apparently, this was the war film to behold, as it was just as good, if not better. I recently got the opportunity to view this movie and by that, it means I was in the mood for it and I saw it on Netflix. I really don't think this film is as good as its reputation suggests it is, but it's still solid. It's certainly the best film ever made, but it's certainly not bad. I guess it's just dated if anything. I'm not sure if this is a complaint or not, but this really did feel like two different films. The first hour of this film took place at boot camp. It felt repetitive, it dragged a bit, and even though it ended shockingly, it still wasn't enough for an A+ film. Then, when the second half came on, it became an entirely different film. In fact, all the weight the first half had became meaningless. So essentially, this was two different movies. I guess that really is a problem in the end, because by that point, why care about anything that happened in either half? The acting wasn't that great. The only real solid performance from here was Matthew Modine's performance. I actually thought he did a really good job. I thought his performance stood out amongst the rest, especially when other ones stood out negatively. A lot of the performances in this movie were less than adequate. They were either cheesy, cringe worthy, laughable, or just downright awkward. I don't think the best cast was chosen for this film, regardless of what the persona of their character was supposed to be. Although it's not the most visually grossing or hard hitting war film, it boasts these concepts and ideas that are pretty tough at times. The overall language and what was acceptable to say back then is completely different than it is today. I liked seeing that difference in past cultures and how we acted compared to how we do today. It also showed some things that did show that war is ugly. It's not pretty, it has its moments, and I think this film showed those aspects well. In the end, this isn't the best movie by any means. It's good, it has its fair share of problems. Maybe it's a bit dated, but maybe it was really good for its release year. In the end, I'm fairly neutral with it.

Full metal Jacket is an excellent war film directed by the legendary director Stanley Kubrick. Great performances are given from the whole cast and the true hell of war is shown. Although it isn't Stanley Kubrick's best film in my opinion, it still can show the audience how good he really is.
