A movie divided in two almost different parts, one focusing on a rather effectively funny and iconic set up, mocking the military training perspective, and the other, demonstrating a powerfully directed satire of the already harsh and visceral war, particularly centered in Vietnam, showing both, a strongly black humored flick, and an extremely effective war movie with all the great elements out of Kubrick's techniques, not to mention the show-stealer R. Lee Ermey in one of history's most iconic performances.

Full Metal Jacket is not just about war, but rather the psychology behind it. A smart move from the legend that was Stanley Kubrick. We've all seen many war films, a genre that is well explored from a variety of different conflicts. Full Metal Jacket however chooses to go behind the scenes and focus on the training process that changes well intentioned men into trained lethal killers. You could easily split this in half and have two separate films, the first half being more psychologically charged whereas the latter showcasing the brutality of warfare. A ridiculously serious drill sergeant practically bullying a trainee marine so harshly that it slowly turns him into an unstable psychopath. That right there, was some really good psychology and made the film so much more interesting. Sure the Vietnam War scenes were depicted with a substantial amount of fire, blood and guns but it was the first half that really captivated me. Vincent D'Onofrio was the stand out for me, both convincing and expressive through his face. Matthew Modine was good, probably his best performance. Lee Ermey deserves recognition just for somehow managing to not lose his voice from all the shouting. Characterisation was present, perhaps not fully fleshed out as I would like but was just enough for me to care about them. Yet again though, it's the technical marvel that wins...Stanley Kubrick. His directing style is so damn flawless. The nice clean long takes, actors looking directly into the camera, slow motion deaths (particularly in the sniper shootout)...he is just phenomenal. Script was sharp as well. A great section of dialogue where our lead character wears a peace badge and a helmet that says "born to kill" for which he describes represents the duality of man. That really stuck with me. So whilst it might feel like two separate films (due to that ridiculously quick transition), it's hard not to appreciate everything that's shown to us. Another hit from Mr. Kubrick.
It takes the idea of military training and the vietnam war, to turn into a great pretty funny, realistic drama showing how tough training can be on people, and how awful the Vietnam War was.
This movie was incredible. The 1st act was the best part of the movie, it dies down a big during the second half, but picks up again with action packed moments. This movie was fantastic.

I love this ending so much. The movie that introduced me to the greatest auteur to ever auteur. tanleyKubrick was one of kind. ullMetalJacket is one the greatest movies ever made, definitely in the top 5 in the War category. The first 45 minutes are riveting, then it lulls a bit but it's never dull. The last 40 minutes are can't even pause to pee good.

The film from 1987 marks something of another comeback for director Stanley Kubrick. It was released to positive reviews but I can see some chinks in the film. It focuses on raw recruits to the US Marines at the time of the Vietnam War. The psychological horrors it brought to some of these recruits is focused on. The film is split into two main acts. The first half of the film focuses on the training of a platoon of marines on Parris Island, in the U.S. One of the recruits Private Lenny Lawrence (Vincent D'Onofrio) struggles with army life and the loud rule of the Sergeant (Lee Ermey). For about an hour of the film we see the portly Lawrence be for want of a better word be bullied by his commanding officer and fellow recruits before he snaps. The warning signs are all there. The raised eye facial expressions that are a trademark of Kubrick films (A Clockwork Orange and The Shining spring to mind.) The recruits become competent users of killer weapons and are warned by the Sergeant himself in one scene how ruthless killers like Lee Harvey Oswald were trained to shoot by the US Marines. The second half of the film is set in Vietnam itself in a variety of locations. Here the film became confusing as it drifted from one set piece to another. However the overriding theme that 'normal' civilians become killers for want of a better word or witness killing is the main theme. A film that shows the real horrors of conventional wzrfare to recruits to the army 'conscripted'.
One of Kubrick's more concrete films, FMJ is perhaps my favorite of his due to each facet and character being so well developed and multi-dimensional. The film still resonates today because of this.
While the movie never quite lives up to its incredible first act, it more than simply passes with dazzling cinematography and daring wit, making it a great war film overall.

A strangely hypnotic film. The uniformity of boot camp and the lack of effect most of it has on actual warfare is on full, blunt display in "Full Metal Jacket," and it makes for an extremely intense experience. There's also quite a lot of humor throughout, but the further the film progresses, the dirtier the jokes feel. I know a lot of people consider this to be an anti-war movie, and I don't disagree. But instead of preaching the beliefs of the filmmakers throughout, events are simply shown and the audience is responsible for deciding how they feel about it all. I don't even know how I'd go about recommending this movie, because while I really like it, there's such a wide range of tones and atmospheres that I wouldn't know how to describe it as just one package. And it really should be quite jarring with all the tonal shifts, but all of it manages to flow together and feel coherent. A satirical war drama is how I imagine it could be most effectively described.

Kubrick excels in his use of appropriate music to improve a scene, better than Quentin Tarantino even. The confusion of war is well described in this thought-provoking film and the PT scenes were stellar in their attempts to describe the initiation that all military personnel go through. R. Lee Ermey steals the show and lifts it to a higher art form. A must-see for any war movie enthusiast.
Phenomenal, nearly perfect, first half. Vincent D'Onofrio and R. Lee Ermey make it impossible to look away. Quality dips slightly in the second half, but still outshines most other films of its type.
I believe it is my favorite war (or better yet, anti-war) movie of all time. There was and never will never be a film like this one.
Intense ,satirical and Ultra cool. Kubrick's take on The Vietnam war may not boast the most original of themes, but it is exceedingly effective at communicating them.9/10

Greedy, darkly funny, horrendous and scary, "Full Metal Jacket" might not had overcomed "Paths of Glory" with regard to the commentary on the nature of the war, but sure it was an important movie in the 80's in America. Kubrick remained relevant for a lot of years and he proved that he could make another equally disturbing war flick.

A great film, a good balance of story and action. The film does a good job showing the emotional and mental struggles soldiers face in both training for a war and fighting one. I also enjoy the music played in the film. I feel the music helps the era this film is based in and the music chosen for the scenes of which the music is played in fits really well. Overall I enjoy this film every time I watch it.

A typical Kubrick masterpiece, divided into two distinct plot areas. The first half of the film is set at U.S. Marine Corps Basic Training at Parris Island, South Carolina amidst the Vietnam War. The audience is introduced to a variety of draftees who are to be transformed from civilians into killers, at the hands of Drill Instructor Gunnery Sergeant Hartman ( R. Lee Ernst). The second half of the film follows Corporal "Joker" (Matthew Modine), one of the Marines from the first segment as he works as a military journalist for Stars and Stripes, following a Marine infantry squad during the Tet Offensive. The film is overwhelmingly "anti-war". A major theme in the first segment is the brainwashing of humans to become ruthless killers. The second half seems more disconnected but a strong sense of apathy towards winning the war and a lack of purpose in being there rounds off one of Stanley Kubrick's more overlooked films from his later career.

I don't know whether Kubrick has lost all his masterful skills or he just needed some more time on his "hiatus" to put up equally surpassing films about Vietnam war. The first half was far meatier than supposed to be sumptuous ending that' s rather insipid of his benchmarked standards.
The movie works better as a superficial social commentary on the Vietnam War than an actual movie story because there is no plot apparent at all.

The first act of Full Metal Jacket is basically perfection. It is pure genius as we get a feel for life in boot camp, and the damaging effects these difficult training techniques can have on recruits. While the quality of the film-making continued once Joker left boot camp, the story dropped off a little. There were still flashes of greatness, but it didn't gel into a complete story as well as I expected. However, the themes were effectively conveyed. You really get a feel for how damaging war can be on the men who must fight it, and what the military is compelled to do in order to keep those men fighting (even in a lost cause.) The final confrontation of the film is devastating and I love how it wraps things up and pays off on things foreshadowed up to that point. In fact, the more I reflect on the movie, the more I recognize its brilliance. I wonder if, upon further viewings, I might find that this is truly a 5-star classic. The only thing that makes me skeptical about the quality of Full Metal Jacket is Matthew Modine. I don't think he's the best actor for this role, and he doesn't really "become" the character. Everyone else seems perfectly fit to the film (particularly Lee Ermey as Gny. Sgt. Hartman) but he stands out as an actor delivering an uncomfortable performance that doesn't work as well as I would like. Despite that if you haven't seen Full Metal Jacket, and you have the stomach for war movies that feel gritty and realistic, then make watching it a priority.

The beginning is definitely the most gripping and enjoyable, and it seems to drag on in the second and third act. Joker isn't the most relatable character, and even borders on irritating. However, this movie does the job of showing the worst the Vietnam War had to offer and didn't hold back

The boot camp part of this movie is 5 stars, the 2nd half is just OK. Kubrik's decision to go with R.Lee Ermey as Gunnery Sergeant was pure genius! Ermey's ad hoc dialog was over-the-top hilarious and totally made the first half of this movie.

Probably the first Kubrick movie I've seen that could have been directed by someone else. It's not a bad movie by any stretch of the imagination, but it's lacks his signature style once you get past the boot camp segment. I think this is why a lot people say that the boot camp portion is better than the larger portion of the movie that actually takes place in Vietnam. Spoilers: It's not. There is a difference between being anti-military and anti-war, neither opinions are clearly right or wrong and that (among some other themes, masculinity being the other most obvious one) is what this movie is about. In boot camp we all want to be Joker. He's the intellectual, sarcastic one who understands "the duality of man" after all. But when you get on the ground Animal Mother starts to make a whole lot more sense. Overall I think it could have been a bit better if it had sunk into a more definitive style and the voice over could have been removed without losing almost anything of importance. But even if it is a weaker Kubrick film, it is still very much worth watching.
A classic for sure , 5th time seeing this one i think but nice to see again , funny drill-jogging songs and enough acting . Happy there was no 2 hour shootings ! SOMDVD

One of my least favorite Kubrick films, but not that bad as a movie. The film drags slightly towards the end, most of the great moments come from the first half of the film, and some of the scenes felt out of place and unimportant to the rest of the picture.

With a simple message and a simple structure, perhaps Full Metal Jacket wants to convey the experience of war as viscerally as possible. But it's hard to call this a war film, as there's no one to root for, or sympathize with, or identify with. This is certainly a Kubrick film: masterfully crafted and interesting with naturalistic performances and provocative images. But it's also something less: in its negativity and cynicism and dehuminization, it's more of a nihilist jaunt through violence and depravity than an artistic statement. There's no real tragedy, only the fate of poor Gomer Pyle, probably the unique spirit that can't survive in the army. Instead of hinting at his themes, Kubrick has his "Joker" shout them at you, informing his conversant that the peace symbol and "born to kill" on his helmet represents "the duality of man". Perhaps Full Metal Jacket is about nothing more than how humans can kill and be killed. Or perhaps it's a meandering and ultimately toothless attempt to satirize war by having monstrous men do monstrous things on camera. But what we'll never know is why Kubrick slowed down so suddenly, how the man who once wished to film Napoleon with 50,000 real soldiers settled for R Lee Ermey slinging violent language at young men. How can the same man who made 2001 make Full Metal Jacket after Apocalypse Now and The Deer Hunter already existed? What happened to the compelling and heroic humanity of Paths of Glory, or unstoppable craftsman of The Shining? It's safe to say we'll never know. But as for Full Metal Jacket, there's blood, there's yelling and there's death. There's men who are mere cartoons of men, foreigners who amount to nothing more than whores and cowardly snipers. Lacking the dynamism and sheer brilliance and beauty of every Kubrick film from Paths of Glory to The Shining, Full Metal Jacket just doesn't measure up. You'll laugh at first, until you realize that a man is being tortured on screen, and then you'll hate the rest of them, and you might just wish that they all die, or better, that they all get killed, which is apparently all that humans can do according to this movie.

Aside from having a terrific memory of catching this in the theaters on opening night (Snuck out of the house to meet my friends, got hammered like shit and then caught this at a midnight show), this is probably the best Vietnam movie that's not really a Vietnam movie. It had the misfortune of being released during the mid-80's/early-90's Vietnam movie wave so it got lumped in with middling-to-shitty movies like "Hamburger Hill" and "Casualties of War." Watching it separate from that period, it's Stanley Kubrick at the top of his game and a perfect bookend for his "Paths of Glory." The Parris Island sequence is so strong that absolutely nothing that comes after it, even the relative novelty of urban warfare in Hue City, can hope to top it, but the second half is more impressive on a purely technical level (tons of single-take sequences, somehow turning the Eastend of London into a pretty fair facsimile of Phu Bai and surrounding areas, a scarily mean performance from Adam Baldwin as a sort of proto-Jayne Cobb) while ramping up the black comedy to 11. We'll just ignore how "Me so horny" got perverted into every white and black asshole's opening comeon to Asian girls (these morons don't know that credit ratings aren't sexually transmitted), but it says something about Kubrick's greatness/genius/whatever as a director and writer that so many images, lines, and other snapshots from "FMJ," "2001," "A Clockwork Orange," and "The Shining" are forever ingrained into Western pop culture.

Apparently my general opinions on this movie are pretty common: I loved the first half and enjoyed the second half a little less. There's a number of reasons for why, but I think the main one is that the first half has this propulsive quality to it that the second half just lacks. Every scene in the first half just zips by because of the drill instructor Sgt. Hartman, who just never lets up, screaming constantly so it's impossible to look away even for a second (this is especially because R. Lee Ermey is so magnetic in the role). The pacing of the first half feels flawless; the audience still needs to feel small moments of reprieve out of necessity, and so those are provided for in the scenes between Pyle and Joker. You really feel for Pyle in those scenes, and get this sense that he's a gentle giant, this poor ignorant guy who just needs someone to be there for him when he's relentlessly tortured by Hartman. Joker provides that kind relief that Pyle (and the audience) needs in between exhausting scenes with Hartman. And then that all ends when Pyle is assaulted by his fellow Marine volunteers, and Joker reluctantly takes part. It's pretty tragic because Joker doesn't realize at the time that if he had stood up for Pyle, if he'd stuck by him in his hardest moments, maybe what inevitably happens wouldn't have happened. And yeah, we haven't even talked about that final scene, in which Pyle kills Hartman and then himself. Just crazy, man. I sort of saw it coming that he would go crazy, but I somehow thought the movie wouldn't go there, and it did. The second half has a lot of standout images and dialogue that make it far from pointless. Adam Baldwin's character, Animal Mother, is an interesting guy because it's pretty damn heartless until the end, when he vows to get revenge on the sniper who killed his friends, and then in the last scene, when he's disgusted by the thought of killing a little girl. There are some funny lines, like Joker's talk about the peace sign and the 'born to kill' writing representing the 'duality of man,' and there are some interesting, thematically strong interludes, like when one soldier reveals that the guy sitting next to him under a blanket is a dead Vietnamese soldier, brought back as some sort of sick prize. All of these moments of originality and thematic potency are especially powerful because of Stanley Kubrick's direction. He shoves you into all of these scenes and forces you to confront them; when Rafterman records the man with the pet Vietcong carcass on camera, we see it from the camera's point of view, so it's like the twisted soldier is telling us directly. There are a lot of moments like that in the movie, when people seem to be staring right at us, especially at the end, when the wounded sniper girl looks up at us and begs us to shoot her. And then there's the whole recurring idea of the 'thousand yard stare,' and Joker's final action in killing the young girl and achieving that stare. His choice to kill her, while merciful in a way, is dark because we've seen him resisting darkness the whole movie, and we've hoped that maybe he could make up for his role in Pyle's bullying. But finally he kills the girl, and it's ostensibly merciful, but it sure looks like execution to us. So there are a lot of images in the second half that are great and carry a lot of emotional and satirical heft, even if that meaning is as reductive as "war sucks," something that tons of movies, like Apocalypse Now, have already done. And the shapelessness that makes me not like the second half as much has been said to have a point. War, after all, is shapeless and confusing and chaotic and messy. Still, just because a movie's unpleasant (exaggerating for effect here) structure and pacing are that way for the express purpose of making a point doesn't mean they're enjoyable on a shallow level, and I like my movies to be at least somewhat entertaining on a shallow level. There's a ruthless efficiency to the first half that's inevitably missed in the second level, even if the formal elements continue to support the tone of the respective sections. Overall, this was a movie I really enjoyed, with a kickass, tragic first half with a unique setting in a boot camp, and a second half that was a little less enjoyable because of its slow-paced shapelessness and the absence of Ermey and Vincent D'Onofrio. Still, there were enough vivid images and nice dialogue throughout the second half that it made up for most of its shortcomings and delivered an adequate second half to an ambitious, dark story.

By 1987, numerous Vietnam films have arrived to the silver screen, the most notable example being Coppola´s "Apocalypse Now", "The Deer Hunter", and Stone´s "Platoon". So what could Kubrick offer? The answer: The polarizing "two films in one" movie "Full Metal Jacket". We follow the training and service of some young men who are eager to "fight the good fight" in Vietnam. Out of all the short list of Stanley Kubrick films, this is the film that I consider the most peculiar and experimental as I find the choices Kubrick made bizarre but extremely fascinating. "Full Metal Jacket" is this intriguing version of the Vietnam War that has solid acting with the best being R. Lee Ermey in an iconic role and Vincent D´Onofrio; the dialog is extremely sharp edge and vulgar but surprisingly is hilarious at times and mostly memorable, Kubrick´s most distinctive use of music as they are widely popular songs or highly irrelevant to the war setting, an uneven pacing that at times takes you out of the experience but at others it flawlessly works as it literally throws you into the scene, the cinematography is as gorgeous as most Kubrick films, a distant and omnipresent storytelling that creates this cynical style, the themes are executed extremely effectively, some of the visuals are haunting and realistic, and Kubrick provides his most experimental directing as most of the time it is fast and feels like the whole film is a montage. The biggest criticisms the film are that the first half is incredible but the second is dull and forgettable, of course the most iconic and memorable section is the first half and while the second half never reaches that level of quality it also has some memorable moments, particularly the climax of the film. The other criticism is the overall feel of the film (some Vietnam vets consider it extremely accurate but others consider it a fantasy take of the war) because it is not like other Vietnam films where they are set in a jungle and have more moral dilemmas; it is an odd way to present war but I believe that the film is not about Vietnam but about war in generally due to its dehumanization themes (actually the visuals are more reminiscent of urban warfare and the War on Terror, which is scary considering this is a film from the 80´s). "Full Metal Jacket" is an experimental take of the Vietnam War that feels like two great movies smashed together via montage. While it is by no means one of the Kubrick´s greatest, it is not one of the weakest. It is funny, haunting, heavy on themes, and the most interesting Kubrick film (directing wise).

Even though Full Metal Jacket was made in 1987, Director Stanley Kubrick had already been around for a long time--for example, he's known for filming the largely satirical Dr. Strangelove in the early 60s. His filming ingenuity only got better as time went on, and Full Metal Jacket is proof of this fact. In this movie, Kubrick relied heavily on a soundtrack to tell the narrative through the technique of satire. I believe that this soundtrack is used to establish an ironical relationship between the audience and the characters in the movie. In other words, Kubrick uses the soundtrack as an ironic plot device. For example, the choice to use "The Chapel of Love" while the men are at war serves to either make fun of or emphasize the desperate attitudes of some of the soldiers experiencing post-traumatic stress. In other words, the movie indirectly makes fun of steadfast patriotism when war instead really promises mental insanity.

Review In A Nutshell: When we think of war, the images that come to our head are the smoke that slowly breathes out of a fired rifle, the red blood that stains the green uniform, the flash of an exploding grenade; these are dark images that fill the puzzle of war's brutality and horror, but what these images do not show is the horrors that lurk underneath; the human spirit fractured in order to fulfil their duty as soldiers. Stanley Kubrick's Full Metal Jacket stands along with films like Apocalypse Now, The Thin Red Line, and Paths of Glory where war is seen through the eyes of the soldiers and how their experiences have affected them internally; the unseen soul. The film begins with the sight of men sitting down and having their hair shaved completely off with faces of both sadness and uncertainty. It is the U.S. Marine's first step in attempting to take what is most precious of them, their identities. It is the idea that each and every one of these soldiers will be identical fighting machines, despite the drill instructor denying this, to strip them completely of what they were and instil a new perspective on yourself, your brothers, and your enemies. The film then takes us to the intimidating introduction of their drill instructor, Sergeant Hartman, a man who response only to sheer volume and intensity, constantly searching for flaws and anomalies in the soldiers' systems and destroying them little by little. This is also where we get to see these soldiers further lose themselves, through the replacement of their names with nicknames that are far from who they really are, aside from maybe Joker, whom which probably impressed the Sergeant despite his disrespect. During this introduction is also the time where the audience is formally introduced to Leonard Lawrence, who is better known in the camp as Gomer Pyle, as a connection to his inherent dimwittedness and innocence; he becomes the Sergeant immediate target because he knows Gomes Pyle is not right for the corps but since he is already present and unlikely to quit, he has to do the best he can to push him to his highest limits. Gomer Pyle's journey through the training is one of the most terrifying experiences I have ever seen, showing how a fresh young face could fall so low in human spirit; a soul that has suffered psychological and emotional torment, betrayal from his once loyal and respected brothers, having to endure demanding and straining physical training, it all adds up in shaping what he would ultimately become, a soulless monster. The end of this half delivered one of the most gasping moments of the entire film, the bathroom massacre. A slow moving Joker flashes his light on Gomer Pyle, revealing him in possession of a live cartridge that is then locked and loaded into his rifle. It is clear that the training he has endured has pushed him too far, deprived of happiness and consciousness, knowing only his duty as a marine corps, to kill. It is the horrifying image of his wicked stare that shivers the audience's bones, not the loaded rifle itself; it is the idea that he has gone too far to find salvation, and it was only in the sound of his once precious name that a glimmer came to his eye and decides to end himself once and for all, sparing Joker's life. It is a moment that stays with you long after the film ends, reminding you of the many Gopher Pyles out there walking and causing pain to those undeserving of it. The second half of the film then turns to the big stage, Vietnam and the war that deeply affected everyone that took part in it. It still follows in the eyes of Joker who works as a correspondent for an American newspaper, Stars and Stripes, which aimed to report news, boost soldier morale, and sway the minds of those unconvinced of America's involvement in the war; it is an element that Kubrick only covers minimally, but hearing it spoke volumes to me; displaying more of what the war really is, without having to actually show it. It would have been fantastic if Kubrick further covered it. After a suicide squad attempting to infiltrate their base, Joker was assigned to the "shit" with his photographer Rafterman, and from there we experience the true nature of soldier warfare; the unpredictability, the paranoia, the destruction that surrounds them, all coming to together to slowly destroy the innocent mind of our protagonist; a person who had a sense of balance, surviving the war with killing in his head, "Born to Kill", and forgiveness in his heart, the peace symbol, retaining that part of himself that keeps him sane. The film subtly throughout this half, question the true agenda of the soldier's stay in Vietnam, told from the perspective of the soldiers themselves through documentary-like interviews that show honest and thoughtful responses. The film then leads to a gripping climax of a sniper picking off their platoon, one by one. It is a tense situation that ends with harrowing imagery. It is revealed that the sniper is just a young girl, and through this Kubrick scares us with the idea that children were raised and trained in order to fight for their causes, youth losing its innocence far too early, wanting her life to end rather than ask for medical attention; it is a frightening scene that shows just how damaged our world is. Ending the film, is a slightly touching scene of soldiers marching in the night, singing out loud a song from their beloved childhood; holding tight a piece of themselves in order to get through god-awful war. Full Metal Jacket may not be the most obvious film in regards to Kubrick's sense of visual and audible flair, but the film's grounded visual take on the war is meaningful and terrifying. During the film's first half, it captures the uniform and tightness of military training, a zone where anarchy and natural movements are absent. During interior scenes, we get a layer of darkness that connects with the gradual loss of the souls of its subjects, coming off more like a mental asylum rather than a barrack; very few films could capture this without becoming too stylish in its imagery. The second half of the film opens up with a larger canvas, displaying the destructive conditions of the war; with sights of crumbling buildings, flaming interiors, and abundance of dirt. The film still manages to be a spectacle without forgetting the film's most important subjects, the characters. The second half spends a fair amount of time with the camera closer to the ground, along the feet of the soldiers, like as if we were trying to take cover from enemy fire, a paranoia of having our heads stand too high; it maintains a sense of uneasiness that correlates with the emotions of its characters. Kubrick almost strips the whole film with vibrant colours, keeping the film feeling deathly and soul crushing; pushing dark greens and dusty browns, the colours that immediately bring to mind the conditions of war. The haunting score by Vivian Kubrick, under the alias of Abigail Mead, dominates the film's scenes through generating dark and atmospheric emotions that elevate the film's themes and tension; just listen to the rumbling seedy tones during the bathroom massacre. The same goes for the sniper sequence, with music that crawls under our skin and feeds dark and fracturing emotions. The combination of Kubrick's score and Americana soundtrack gave the film that sense of balance and flavour, coming off as different from the other films that cover the same ground; it never tries to over-dramatize its scenes, instead the score reaches for the darker depths of the film's characters without drama elevation, while the soundtracks are present to create a hilarious satire of America's presence in the war. Matthew Modine is the film's protagonist, Private Joker, but I felt his performance was a bit underwhelming as compared to others that have led in a Kubrick film; the writing certainly makes his role feel interesting but his performance rarely ever elevates it. The shining star in this film is an actor who only appears during the first half of the film, and that is Vincent D'Onofrio playing as Gomer Pyle; a transformational performance that captures the essence of his character perfectly. Full Metal Jacket is an example of a war film attempting to be more than what it plainly is; it showcases the inherent nature of war and its effects on the human mind and soul. It tells a story that is not restricted by a conventional three act approach, and it features a stand out performance from D'Onofrio as the lovable turned deadly, Gomer Pyle. I think I'm going to love this film for a long time.

Director Stanley Kubrick done some nice explorations in his projects. He'd explored space with systematic corruption and boredom, and the insane, hysteric horror of a human mind and condition. Both of those are his 3.5-star masterpieces. His best work belongs to the battlefield of the war genre. In that field he'd explored the consequences of stopping yourself from following commands and get framed and shot for cowering, and the satiric reason why we need to learn to "stop worrying and love the bomb." Now before his final project of "Eyes Wide Shut," he returned to the battlefield one more time to add another the story to the chronicles of the Vietnam War, and it'd resulted to be his best masterpiece. "Full Metal Jacket" explores the process of a new recruit entering from boot camp to the battlefields in the U.S. Marine Corps. The first 20 minutes were the recruits' training period. It was a masterful exposition with the cast only saying things that are around under the category of "Sir, yes sir!" to R. Lee Ermey's not-so fictional character when he was a drill instructor at that time the film takes place. He stands out and shines the most out of the cast when his performance is so good that it's probably the best of the film. He was also expressing a theme with a message to be analyzed and he had Vincent D'Onofrio as his volunteer to help out that message to the unfortunate outcome: D'Onofrio's character was mirroring a bit of how Jack Nicholson's character gone through in "The Shining," but by the subject of the expressed theme of hypocrite bullying. Now for the main story that'd took the next 93 minutes was the main setting: fighting in the war on tour. Matthew Modine's character James Davis is the story's narrator going over how haunting and violent the Vietnam War can from what he'd experienced from commander of the recruits with a thirst to see combat to "later becomes an independent-minded combat correspondent." We'll be soon get in combat side-by-side with his old comrades from Sergeant Hartman's (R. Lee Ermey) boot camp, when he's nicknamed the Joker - representing some of the film's occasional light-hearted humor. The way how Davis's experiences in the war were constructed in the film was nicely done as usual in the war genre. The effects of combat, including the power and energy from the actors pretending/acting like they're in the war, and the performances are what a war flick reload to keep the power going. "Full Metal Jacket" is a nice addition to the Vietnam War chronicles with the usual qualities at their efforts to match the pounding of a war's battlefield, making this war drama Kubrick's best masterful work in exploring more in the process of serving a war while at the same time rarely reminiscing few of his past explorations, with stuff to express. (B+)

It is excellently filmed and superbly crafted technically, but the deliberate narrative shift in the middle is jarring and gives a horribly overbearing feeling of disjointedness to the film. That said the first 45 minutes or so contain some of the most powerful psycho-analytical scenes ever committed to celluloid.

It's first half is definitely stronger than its second half, Kubrick clearly a bit out of his element filming combat zones encumbered by some awkward dialogue, but the entire film is a remarkably effective indictment of the Vietnam War and the destruction of youth by the U.S. military industrial complex. The hoo-rah Marine Corps mystique comes under fire in particular, with a stunning analysis of the mental and emotional breakdown of recruits at Paris Island, with some harrowing twists and turns (fired by a remarkable depiction of drill sergeants). The Vietnam act suffers from Kubrick's obvious struggle in effectively filming combat zones and firefights, but his narrative is constructed so well in its bleakness and despair that it doesn't matter too much. Juxtaposition of period rock music is unsettling as well. An excellent example of an anti-war-film-film, it may not quite reach the heights of "The Thin Red Line" in deconstruction of the genre, but it doesn't fall short by that much. Necessary viewing for those who seriously want to consider the dehumanizing nature of war.

Kubrick always had a cold detachment. Whether it be focusing on the exploitation of soldiers from their peers in "Paths of Glory" or laughing to the nuclear gallows with "Dr. Strangelove," it was obvious that Kubrick preferred cynicism over warmth. 'Full Metal Jacket' most certainly follows Kubrick's cynical perception, a movie that reflects the Marine Corps deconstruction of the human being to become a natural born killer. Thematically, Kubrick's anti-war message is one that has been told time and time again. However, and with the help of the hilarious Sergeant Hartman (Ermey) - a character that continually shouts disgusting simile's and metaphors that creates an enjoyable balance of dark humour - Kubrick's deliverance of this recycled message is undeniably riveting. Besides Ermey's performance, Kubrick's ability as craftsman most certainly elevates the somewhat tiresome material. Not only is the direction spot on but also the meticulous touches to the lighting and music that contribute to overall harrowing affect (especially during the sequence where Pyle commits suicide; the lighting, the direction and music all combine perfectly to reflect the descent into violent madness). However, while these themes are portrayed with power, there are times where you feel Kubrick is being too cynical or simply too simplistic. Surely all Marine Corps are not systematic to point that there is no room for some gesture of humour or characterization? I know Kubrick is representing the deconstruction of humane qualities contributed from war, but such a focus makes the story at times rather dull (this is quite noticeable in the second half with the spark of the Ermey missing and the audience are left with a group of uninteresting cold-blooded killing machines). Besides these shortcomings in the second half, Kubrick's direction of Nam's battlefields are once again riveting. Revisiting the tracking shots he adopted in 'Paths of Glory,' Kubrick places the camera in a position so the audience are invited into the films battle depictions against the backdrop of the beautiful destructive scenery. Rather than giving the audience the benefit of an omnipresent vision, Kubrick situates the audience in the soldiers position which creates a realistic feel that many war films seem to lack. Fundamentally, while Kubrick's vision at times is too cynical, "Full Metal Jacket" features a great amount of enjoyable black humour and a craftsman at the top of his game.

Darkly comic, nihilistic, Violent. Full Metal Jacket is a war film that shows the darker side of war. That some soldiers get a thrill from killing another human being. It's easily the most nihilistic war film ever made, and made by none other then the legend Stanley Kubrick.

Although I've seen a lot of war movies, its not a genre I enjoy watching. However , Stanley Kubrick's Full Metal Jacket is certainly one of my fav. war movies along with The Hurt Locker and probably The Pianist. What all these movies have in common is that, although they show a broad perspective of war, they have memorable characters who really bring emotions to this movie. But even setting these aside, Full Metal Jacket never really starts from a war perspective. It starts with the scrutinizing life under a drill sergeant(incredible performance by R. Lee Ermey) and slowly eases into the war scene. However even during war, the scenes slowly eases into the heart of the war. The cinematography is beautiful and if you notice, most of the shots have been taken during the golden hour where the best lighting for films are possible. This style really contrasts with the themes in the film which really brings up new emotions under this genre. Its something which only someone like Kubrick could bring about. Second only to Coppola's masterful "Apocalypse Now", Kubrick's examination of the Vietnam war chronicals the lifespan of a killer manufactured by a government and an army that, under all its swagger and bravado and iconography, is simply engaged in a systemic indoctrination of human beings into the cult of death, blind patriotism, brutality, violence, and horror resulting in inhuman insanity to protect its own interests. The fact that it's hilarious is just icing on the cake.

Full Metal Jacket is a simple film. Easy to follow with no heavy narrative involved, this Kubrick war drama opens your eyes to what war is really like. The film is separated into two acts. The first act shows the U.S. Marines going through boot camp with an amazing ad-libbed performance by R. Lee Ermey that has to be seen to be believed. Following the shocking conclusion to this part, you are taken into battle with Pvt. 'Joker' Davis, played here well by Matthew Modine. There is no real major story featured. It simply shows you what a normal (and bloody) day these men went through during the Vietnam war. This is what makes it enjoyable. With nothing to try and work out, you can simply sit back and enjoy it. What also adds to the experience is the recreation of the Vietnam war zone. Surprisingly filmed completely in England, so much work has been put into making it look perfect that you would actually wonder at times if they shipped their actors out to Vietnam. A good cast, a good soundtrack and a fun time makes this a film worth watching.

"THE VIETNAM WAR" - 'Full Metal Jacket' is a 1987 war film directed and produced by Stanley Kubrick (The Shining, Eyes Wide Shut). The film is based on the novel 'The Short Timers' by Gustaph Hasford and portraits the training and actual combat action of some young marines during the Vietnam War. Kubrick is a master in storytelling by showing hard facts mixed with well-chosen music. A couple of scenes will be glued to your memory. This 'Full Metal Jacket' is a must-see classic. Starring Matthew Modine (The Transporter 2, Weeds), Adam Baldwin (Predator 2, Independence Day), Vincint D'Onofrio (Men in Black, The Cell) and R. Lee Ermey (The Texas Chainsaw remakes, Willard). 1967, Senior Drill Instructor Gunnery Sergeant Hartman (Ermey) trains a load of U.S. Marine Corps recruits in their boot camp. His iron fist will discipline the boys. One of them is James Davis (Modine), who is given the nickname 'Joker'. He dares to take a stand and considered to be in charge of his fellow recruits. Another is the clumsy overweight Leonard Lawrence (D'Onofrio) who earns the nickname 'Gomer Pyle'. He suffers the most from Hartman's boot camp training. With some help from 'Joker', he does seem to improve. But when Hartman discovers that 'Gomer Pyle' has stashed away a jelly doughnut: the whole squad is punished for his deeds... The following year, 'Joker' has become a war correspondent at the Vietnam War. When the Tet Offensive kicks in, he joins a platoon of Marines on a deadly mission. There he sees one of his of boot camp mates and meets machine gunner 'Animal Mother' (Baldwin). Will they live to tell the tale?

Full Metal Jacket was one of the last films directed by Stanley Kubrick, and while it isn't his greatest, it has definitely earned it's praise. The film takes place during the Vietnam War, with the first half focusing on basic training and the second half on the soldier's experiences in Vietnam. The first half is really where the film shines, having a clear message with so very humorous insults from R. Lee Ermey (who was a real-life drill instructor). When the film switches over to Vietnam, however, the film gradually goes downhill. There are a bunch of little short segments, most of them not being important to the story at all, but there are so truly great moments, especially the helicopter scene. Also, alll of the battle scenes are extremely well done, especially the final battle between the soldiers and the sniper. Full Metal Jacket isn't a perfect film, especially with it's disappointing second half, but it's truly great scenes mostly make up for this.

Stanley Kubrick's classic war movie has resonating and thought provoking ideas and has a realistic vibe that makes it worthy of a recommendation. It also has gritty moments and impressive performances that are very impressive. There are slow parts in the middle that seem to drag on but it somewhat adds to the realism of the film. This Film May Not Be The Greatest Kubrick Film But It Certainly Is The Only Vietnam Film To Go All Comic On Us Thats A Really Hard Job To Do And Kubrick Pulled It Off Nicely Its Also Makes Me Forget That Im Watching A Kubrick Film And Watching Something That Francis Ford Coppola Would Make But He Did Another Vietnam Film That Didn't Have Any Dark Humor And Was Way More Darker And Brutally Honest, But This Film Still Has Its Own Style With The Amazing Direction Of Stanley Kubrick!

Second half isn't that interesting, but this is undoubtedly a Stanley Kubrick masterpiece. Based off The Short-Timers, a semi-autobiographical book by Gustav Hasford, Full Metal Jacket follows a US Marine platoon going through training, later transitioning its focus to two Marines of the platoon in the Tet Offensive during the Vietnam War. The film does tons of detail exploring the steps that are taken into becoming a Marine, including following orders correctly, moving through obstacles quickly and flawlessly, remaining organized, preparing weapons correctly, and remaining close to the squad the soldier is assigned to. The film, like many masterful war films, uses tons of graphic violence and personal conflict in order to add realism and humanity to the story in order to prevent Full Metal Jacket from going into generic war film territory. Stanley Kubrick uses his unbelievable genius to craft a film that says "war". He does an incredible job by giving audiences heart breaking battle sequences that also shock them rather than entertain them (thank God, because war is disgraceful). Kubrick, Michael Herr, and author Hasford craft a script that expands Part I, and contains elements of Part II and III, yet omits Part III. Part II isn't that engaging or as interesting or psychologically disturbing as Part I, but is still a key element to the story, even if it's message isn't that great. The acting is stellar, most particularly R. Lee Ermey as Gunnery Sergeant Hartman, a ruthless, mean, foul-mouthed drill instructor who actually was played by a US Marine drill instructor who was in service during the Vietnam War, and Vincent D'Onofrio as Private Leonard "Gomer Pyle" Lawrence, an overweight, clumsy, incompetent, slow-witted recruit who in fact becomes the focus for Sergeant Hartman for his flaws. In fact, R. Lee Ermey's scene where he chewed out the new recruits was mostly improvised, despite the fact that Kubrick never allowed his actors to improvise, although he allowed a few to do that, R. Lee Ermey's being one of them, which helped show off the brutality of his character, especially to D'Onofrio's Pyle. In fact, this scene should've gotten him an Oscar nod, same goes for D'Onofrio. Vincent is able to capture the recruit going from a troubled man, to an insane, creepy, and flawless recruit whose unpredictable in every corner. The change in D'Onofrio's character shows that people can change even before they go to war (nonviolence anyone?), and that training can have negative implications in them and/or their platoon. A must-see, especially for anyone who's against war.

Full Metal Jacket is a brutal, intense, bloody, disturbing and occasionally comedic movie. It's not the greatest war film or the most original, but it's one of the darkest and most frightening of them all.
Kubrick's best film in my opinion, FMJ delivers the goods: it has action, war, drama, and a verbally abusive drill sergeant whose lines will remain as some of the best movie quotes of all time.

The story follows a few recruits at camp before they are shipped out to war. The first part is almost a comedy of sorts until it takes a dark turn late and they get shipped out to war. The tone changes a bit and it feels more like a documentary of sorts where the soldiers don't really know why they are there, but do it anyways. They go on a mission where they find a sniper who pins them down so they must find a way to survive before they are all killed. I did enjoy it, but not as much as I thought given the film's recommendations.

The entire movie is fantastic, but the first forty five minutes are legendary!!! THIS IS MY RIFLE THIS IS MY GUN, THIS IS FIGHTING THIS IS FOR FUN!!!

As Kubrick made his way toward the 90's, it became clear that he was attempting to alternate between genres of source material. Full Metal Jacket proves this maneuver successful. Kubrick's ability to blend moods, specifically within the first 40 minutes, is at an all time high, presenting to us some hilarious yet intense drill instructing from the one and only R. Lee Ermey. On a deeper level, it illustrates the complete deterioration of the troops in the Marine corps to the point of losing their last remaining shreds of humanity, leaving them lifeless, killer husks. This is displayed by Kubrick in his signature intensity and terror that no other horror flick can bring to the script and screen.

Great anti war film about the Vietnam war. It follows the Vietnam war theme of the time and compares favorably with the rest, but it isn't the best one. It shows how inhumane war turns soldiers, and is graphic and suspenseful. But the acting isn't great, some lines are poorly written and some things are overdone. Also I didn't like the scenes where they shoot at the buildings because of how the whole 4 story wall of the building would seem to explode in dust and exploding shells. My favorite war movie and favorite movie up there with the first three Die Hard's and A Nightmare on Elm Street. It's Stanley Kubrick's best movie as well. Full Metal Jacket is one of the greatest war films ever made, period. While exploring the horrors of war is nothing new, this film takes that simple idea and goes above and beyond that. Gladiator is a timeless epic that balances grandeur with raw emotion. Ridley Scott delivers a sweeping vision of ancient Rome, crafting battles that are both massive in scale and deeply personal. Russell Crowe gives one of his most iconic performances as Maximus, a tragic hero whose journey of vengeance and honor resonates just as powerfully today. Joaquin Phoenix’s Commodus is equally unforgettable, bringing menace and fragility to the role of a desperate emperor. Hans Zimmer’s haunting score lingers long after the credits, amplifying both the spectacle and the sorrow. While the pacing occasionally slows, the film’s emotional weight and visual mastery more than make up for it. For some, it’s a near-perfect film, for others, an untouchable masterpiece. Either way, Gladiator stands as one of cinema’s greatest achievements a film that redefined the modern epic and continues to captivate audiences decades later.

Quite simply one of the best movies ever made. Acting: flawless. Story: superbe. Action scenes: edge-of-seat. Plot: instantly hooking. Characters: each and every single one has a clear function; each has their own clearly defined and complex personality. Music: hypnotising. Nothing left to chance. No loose ends. Just perfect story-telling. You will come back to this film again and again because of how it stays with you through sheer movie magic.

Maximus Decimus Meridius is one of the great movie characters because he embodies dignity in the face of betrayal. Russell Crowe gives him a commanding presence without ever overplaying it. He’s a general who becomes a slave, a slave who becomes a gladiator, and a gladiator who challenges an empire. He doesn’t seek revenge for its own sake. He acts out of loyalty to a murdered emperor and love for a family he’s lost. That combination of personal grief and unshakable honor gives Maximus a quiet power that defines every scene he’s in.

This is my favorite movie of all time. I love everything about this classic from start to finish. Saw it in the theatre twice when it was first released and watch it multiple times every year. Maybe another movie will beat it out as my favorite one day but not yet, not yet.

In 2025, I decided to fill one of the gaps in my life as a movie buff: watch the film Gladiator, directed by Ridley Scott and starring Russell Crowe. I finally understood the critical and commercial acclaim the film garnered, in addition to, of course, its Oscar wins. The film's script is extremely well-constructed and makes us care about all the characters, especially the protagonist, whose development is one of the best I've ever seen. Ridley's direction is inspired, with memorable scenes in the Roman Colosseum. The cinematography is also a highlight, with scenes that resemble a painting, especially those highlighting the green fields, the mountainous landscape, and the blue sky. The soundtrack is memorable, and through it, we can sense the grandeur of the action and battles throughout the film. Joaquin Phoenix delivers a dangerous and multifaceted villain, who murdered his own father to declare himself Emperor of Rome and who courts his own sister in his desperate search for attention and devotion. I regret it took me so long to see this film, but no more so than not seeing it in theaters. In 2000, I was just a kid, and my film tastes were limited to Disney, Jurassic Park, and superhero movies. Those who were lucky enough, however, must have had an epic cinematic experience, which is what this film provides.

Gladiator is pure entertainment from start to finish. In a quintessential movie star performance, Russell Crowe brings charisma, sparkle, and depth to the stoic Maximus. He plays opposite an equally brilliant and disturbing Joaquin Phoenix. This film is a popcorn classic—a period piece featuring an impressive budget, elaborate sets, and outstanding stars.

Gladiator is more than just a historical epic — it’s a deeply human story about honor, vengeance, and legacy, brought to life through unforgettable performances and stunning craftsmanship. Ridley Scott’s direction is grand yet intimate, balancing sweeping battle sequences with quieter, emotional moments that give the film its soul. Russell Crowe delivers a commanding and heartfelt performance as Maximus, portraying a character driven by pain, principle, and purpose. Joaquin Phoenix, equally compelling, gives a chilling portrayal of corruption and weakness beneath power. The cinematography is gorgeous, the score by Hans Zimmer is iconic, and the storytelling is tight, immersive, and emotionally resonant. Even after all these years, Gladiator still feels fresh and relevant — a reminder of how powerful great filmmaking can be. Whether you’re watching it for the first time or the tenth, Gladiator never loses its impact. It earns its place as one of the greatest films of its genre.
Absolutely loved it! And the best part? I got to experience it on the big screen for the very first time! What an epic way to watch a classic!

How can you not be entertained?! Ridley Scott’s sword-and-sandal epic is the catalyst that led to a majority of modern men’s obsession with the Roman Empire. The timeless, spectacular action combined with a simple yet poignant story makes this one of the prime examples of a blockbuster film at its best. Russell Crowe delivers a peak performance as the honorable hero, Maximus. Joaquin Phoenix matches Crowe’s excellence, playing the villainous foil, Commodus, a role that would launch him into stardom as well. While the gladiator combat is a major draw of the film, it’s the film’s exploration of societal power and the resilience of the human spirit that sets “Gladiator” apart from its many imitations.

An instant classic. I've watched it countless times over the years, ever since its release. This FILM echoes in eternity... EPIC - GRITTY - INSPIRING - MAGNIFICENT Gladiator is every man's appropriate response to such loss. I'd wake up a gladiator too if I were Maximus. The sheer scale of this film has me in awe. For 2000? Oh yeah. Production design is on another level... can we please make movies like this again??? The visual effects aren't my favorite though. The color grading for the afterlife sequences is too dull, and between the floating heads and the glitchy slow-motion shots feel cheesy, but it's not enough to derail the film. Apparently the Academy loved it though... None of that pulls from the magnificent performances of the cast, notably Crowe. Just... wow. Seeing this, I understand where he pulls that stoic energy from for some of his other roles (Robin Hood, The Water Diviner, Man of Steel, Master and Commander). It's the story and script that are the muscle of this film (though it seems the Academy disagrees on this point as well...). A man... who has lost everything... wife, son, honor, status... and all so horrifically... tossed to the gladiators of Rome to be slaughtered for sport... and we are on the very EDGE of our seats to see... what does he do next? Will he give up? Will he give in to the overwhelming grief that even we can seem to taste... or will he rise up, in the face of every adversity... and fight the very emperor himself to regain his lost honor and restore justice to a corrupt nation? That is the story in every man, even at the simplest level. There is nothing more inspiring than that. The script sets up everything so well to come crashing down, slowly builds up again, sparks hope, then all is lost... creating the perfect conditions to forge a hero. Trust me. You'll understand when you see it. While being heavily masculine, it doesn't lose a single drop of emotion. It's a rollercoaster. Great lines bring some enthusiastic "oh yeah!!!"-moments, while Maximus' loss stabs your heart strings, and victories throughout leave you cheering. Just for laughs...... I saw many other films before seeing Gladiator... so my initial reaction is through this lens: Dumbledore and Robin Hood try to overthrow the Joker as emperor of the Roman Empire.

First of all, you're reading this review from someone who has just seen this for the first time before seeing the sequel. I was ten when this came out and could never see this due to being raised differently. But seeing this for the first time, I do see why folks consider this a masterpiece. However, this isn't as much of a masterpiece to me. I was entertained, though. So the story is a bit simple from a revenge story to overthrowing a usurper who murdered his own father. I do get behind with it as it was built okay. Just wish the beginning needed a little more time to develop. Though it would make the movie a little longer, but that might be me. In the second and last third is where it gets better between the interactions with the characters, the action in the colosseum and the ending, which I will keep that a secret. The best that I could give out of this are the music score with both Hans Zimmer and Lisa Gerrard, the setting of the movie along with their costumes and the action like I'm watching an actual gladiator fight. Sure, I will admit, this is like a dad film, but still worth it to see the actors play it out. In my personal opinion, I didn't think too much of the Commodus, played by Joaquin Pheonix, being that much of a threat until the third act when he gets better until he gets his just desserts at the end. Granted, he is played as a corrupted politician, yet I can believe him being similar to the usual "big, bad, businessman" troupe that I was never too fond of in movies. Fortunately, he does get better by the third act of the film. Everyone else does great from Russel Crowe as the main lead to work his way back up to the ranks to entertain the crowd along with his interactions through his life as a slave to gladiator. Connie Nielson, Oliver Reed and Djimon Hounsou were also great in their roles when interacting with Maximus as the story goes. The other characters did well in their given roles, too. Simple, yes, but was still entertained as a whole when seeing this film for the first time. Even to see Ridley Scott's work in his prime. For this, I give this eight Russel Crowe yelling to the crowd, "Are you not entertained," out of ten. 8/10.

This film provided a deeply nostalgic experience, bringing me back to my childhood when I first watched the original and was captivated by it. Now, as an adult, watching this sequel, it’s incredible to see the evolution of the story, the characters, and the production values. The storyline effectively blends historical elements with modern sensibilities, and as someone with a strong appreciation for history, I found it particularly engaging. It’s a stark reminder of how much the world and our technology have evolved. While the original film, released in 2000, still holds up visually, this latest installment takes things to another level in terms of beauty and innovation. It’s truly remarkable to witness. The performances across the board were outstanding. From Denzel Washington to Pedro Pascal, each actor fully embraced their role, creating a sense of authenticity and depth. However, Paul Mescal deserves special recognition. His performance was exceptional, demonstrating impressive range and emotional depth that significantly elevated the film. Every actor brought something unique to their role, contributing to a compelling and immersive experience. The cinematography was also a standout. The shots, camera angles, and color gradients were all meticulously crafted to enhance the story visually. The director clearly had a strong vision for the film, and it was executed brilliantly. As someone with a background in film studies, I greatly appreciated the attention to detail in every frame. What I particularly appreciated about this sequel is how it provided closure for fans of the original film. In an era where many sequels feel like cash grabs, this one felt like a true continuation of the story, with genuine care and respect for the source material. It was a refreshing change, and the filmmakers succeeded in preserving what made the first film special while expanding the narrative in a satisfying way. The pacing was another strength. At no point did I find myself disengaged or bored; the film maintained a steady rhythm that kept me invested from beginning to end. Overall, I would rate this film a solid 10/10. I have no complaints and am extremely satisfied with the final product. It’s a rare sequel that truly honors its predecessor while delivering something new and exciting.

From the timeline of introducing the plot of the movie to the eclipse of the conclusion of the movie, this is truly a masterpiece. If you love action mixed with suspense, drama and a yearn for emotion, this is your movie to watch.

The original film "Gladiator," featuring Russell Crowe, is an exhilarating ride full of entertainment and suspense. It immerses viewers in a journey reminiscent of Greek mythology, where fierce battles unfold in the grand arena. The film begins in a chaotic war setting, leaving audiences disoriented as they try to grasp the direction of the story. However, it soon settles into a gripping tale of conflict, chaos, and combat. The action sequences are nothing short of spectacular, showcasing exceptional craftsmanship throughout the film. The character development is compelling, allowing viewers to connect with the protagonists and understand their motivations and the path they are on. The overall experience is remarkable, and I strongly recommend watching this film before diving into its sequel. While I generally don't gravitate towards this genre, I found "Gladiator" to be a worthwhile one-time experience. Its length is a bit daunting for me to consider a repeat viewing, but the storytelling and concept are commendable. One aspect that strikes me as peculiar is seeing Russell Crowe as the leading character in "Gladiator," especially when he portrays Zeus in the Marvel Cinematic Universe. "Gladiator": The Glory and Elegy of a Hero The film "Gladiator" is unforgettable for its grand narrative and profound connotations. At the beginning of the film, the magnificence of the Roman Empire stands in sharp contrast to the cruelty of the gladiatorial arena. Maximus, originally a renowned general with numerous military exploits, was reduced to a gladiator due to a court conspiracy. In the gladiatorial arena, he demonstrated unparalleled courage and combat wisdom, and each battle was thrilling. The scenes of the yellow sand filling the air and the earth-shattering shouts made the audience feel as if they were right there. Russell Crowe vividly portrayed Maximus' firmness, pain, and longing for his family. In the face of hardships, he remained unyielding, and his determined eyes conveyed his persistent pursuit of justice and freedom. Meanwhile, the madness and cruelty of the villain Commodus were also depicted incisively and vividly, forming a sharp contrast with Maximus. The theme of the film is profound. It not only sings the praises of heroism but also reflects on power, desire, and human nature. The gladiatorial arena is a stage of life and death as well as a place where human nature is laid bare. Maximus finally won glory in the gladiatorial arena and avenged his family. His legend has become a brilliant yet tragic chapter in the long history of Rome, leaving the audience immersed in that world full of passion and legend long after watching the film, feeling the glory and sorrow of the hero. The contradictions and conflicts between Maximus and Commodus are important clues that drive the development of the plot. Commodus' jealousy, ambition, and madness make him a highly charismatic villain. He is eager to obtain his father's recognition, but due to his own character flaws, he has embarked on a path of no return. Meanwhile, Maximus' longing for his family and his obsession with revenge enable him to maintain a firm belief in difficult situations. The friendship he has established with other gladiators, such as the mutual admiration with Juba, also adds a touch of warmth to this bloody and violent movie. The incorporation of these emotional elements allows the audience to gain a deeper understanding of the inner worlds of the characters, thus generating a strong emotional resonance. “Gladiator” delivers entertainment and spectacles that are as raw and visually engaging as an actual gladiator match. When it comes to storytelling, its originality was buried beneath the sands by its formulaic and bloated narrative and grim tone. However, the film is another example of utilizing its style, visual grandeur, and emotional core to elevate most of the narrative shortcomings. As mentioned earlier, Ridley Scott is seen as a visual storyteller attempting to balance the seemingly straightforward plots with the splendor of the cinematic scales, gloomy atmospheres, action set pieces, and character-driven drama. While most of his films aren’t as great as others, Scott has repeatedly proven that his presentation shines the most in balancing blockbuster aesthetics with an authentic and down-to-earth atmosphere, with “Gladiator” being one of those examples. With its stellar cast, compelling direction, suitable screenplay, and outstanding technical aspects, the movie has enough bloodshed and appeal to entertain plenty of fans of Scott’s works.

Para empezar con el nuevo milenio, Ridley Scott presento una de sus mejores películas después de Alien y una estupenda historia épica de honor y venganza. Gladiator es una película épica del cine moderno que hasta a la altura de muchos clásicos del cine épico. Russell Crowe ofrece lo mejor de su carrera cinematográfica como Maximus en su búsqueda por vengar la muerte de su familia y la del honorable Marcus Aurelius tras ser traicionado por su propio hijo Commodus. Es una de esas historias donde el imperio romano tenía a un gobernador que consiguió poder por medio de la traición y la muerte de sus seres más confiables. Commodus ansiaba ser el nuevo Cesar después de que su padre falleciera y estaba dispuesto a conservar ese poder aun si debía eliminar a sus obstáculos. Maximus era la persona ideal para liderar roma, pero termino siendo traicionado por Commodus y eso desata todo el argumento de la película. Vemos como Maximus pasa de ser un esclavo a un admirable gladiador y así obtener la oportunidad de encontrarse nuevamente con Commodus y liberar a Roma de un emperador tirano. Es una historia que está muy bien relatada y la buena producción hace de esta película una agradable experiencia. Las escenas de combate, la banda sonora de Hans Zimmer y el vestuario son dignos de este tipo de películas. Ridley Scott logró hacer una película que le hace honor al cine épico y eso hace que Gladiator sea otra de las mejores películas que se hayan hecho. Mi calificación final para esta película es un 10/10.

I would put Gladiator on the Top 100 Greatest Films of All-Time List and don’t hesitate to add it to my own personal Top 10 List. It is less of a revenge story, as some suggest, and is more of a graphic saga about why words like justice, strength, and honor ought to prevail over greed, envy, and corruption. From a technical standpoint, I don’t think there is a single poorly casted actor, stunt, costume, score piece, set, or scripting that falters throughout the film, with one of the most quotable lines in cinematic history, “Are you not entertained?!” If there are historical inaccuracies, so be it. Crowe’s performance is second to none portraying an honorable soldier and a humble, non-greedy husband who must overcome a coup attempt of murder on his life after he just won a last war for Rome, and then the incredibly tragic scene of betrayal towards his beloved family and home. Apart from Heath Ledger’s Joker performance and Gollum in the Lord of the Ring’s, I often put Phoenix’s portrayal of Commodus as the third best villain of all time in cinematic history, and have struggled to see him as anything else ever since his role in the movie. There are many parallels throughout the film that can be applied to modern life and politics making it a relevant film adding social commentary on current affairs. After visiting Rome, the Colosseum was one of the first sites I visited along with the Pantheon. The Colosseum didn’t appear quite as large as the film makes it out to be.

"Gladiator" is an extraordinary film that transcends the boundaries of epic storytelling and cinematic artistry. Directed by Ridley Scott, this masterpiece takes viewers on a gripping journey through ancient Rome, weaving a tale of revenge, honor, and redemption that leaves an indelible mark on the heart and mind. Russell Crowe delivers a powerful performance as Maximus Decimus Meridius, a once-noble general turned slave who seeks vengeance against the corrupt emperor, Commodus, played brilliantly by Joaquin Phoenix. Crowe's portrayal is both fierce and vulnerable, capturing the essence of a man stripped of everything yet fueled by an unyielding desire for justice. The dynamic between Maximus and Commodus is electric, showcasing the stark contrast between integrity and moral decay. The cinematography is breathtaking, with sweeping landscapes and meticulously crafted battle scenes that immerse the audience in the grandeur of the Roman Empire. The film's visual richness is complemented by Hans Zimmer's haunting score, which elevates every moment, enhancing the emotional depth and intensity of the narrative. Scott’s direction is masterful, balancing epic scale with intimate character moments, making each victory and loss resonate deeply. The screenplay is tight and impactful, filled with memorable quotes and poignant themes that explore the complexities of power, loyalty, and the human spirit. "Gladiator" is more than just a historical epic; it’s a timeless tale that explores the struggles of the individual against tyranny and the quest for personal redemption. It’s a film that inspires and captivates, leaving viewers both exhilarated and reflective. In summary, "Gladiator" is a flawless blend of compelling storytelling, stellar performances, and breathtaking visuals. It is, without a doubt, a must-see cinematic experience that solidifies its place as one of the greatest films of all time.

Russell Crowe as Maximus Decimus Meridius intends to return home after he leads the Roman army to victory against the Germanic tribes. Emperor Marcus Aurelius played by Richard Harris, tells him that his brother, Commodus played by Joaquin Phoenix, will not rule as emperor and that he wishes Maximus to succeed him, as regent, to restore the Roman Republic. Marcus informs Commodus of his decision; but in response, he murders his father. He proclaims himself as the new emperor and requests loyalty from Maximus, who refuses. Maximus is arrested and is told that he and his family will die. He kills his captors and is wounded, rides for his home near Turgalium, where he finds his wife and child crucified. Slavers find him and take him to the city of Zucchabar in the Roman province of Mauretania Caesariensis, where he is sold to gladiator trainer Proximo. Gladiator is the epic story of a general who is enslaved and forced to fight in the Coliseum in a low fantasy world loosely based on the Roman Empire. Jokes about the complete lack of historical accuracy aside, Gladiator has some strong points - Commodus (Joaquin Phoenix) makes for a decent villain, the camerawork is strong, and the action, while occasionally spoiled by the dated slow-motion effects, is satisfying. Unfortunately, the screenplay is entirely unbefitting a Best Picture winner. It is full of pseudo-profundities and is unnecessarily depressing, fridging the main character's family almost immediately in the most horrific way possible. Worse, the awful events Maximus experiences provoke little character development beyond making him a bit bitter. He is not the only one with vague characterization: the screenplay provides little in the way of coherent character motivations for the actors (save perhaps Phoenix) to work with, and perhaps consequently, almost every line is delivered like a speech or soliloquy even when this is inappropriate for the context. Gladiator is an alright film if you want to turn your brain off and enjoy the sights, but critics often present the film as intellectually-engaging art, a modern Spartacus, which it most definitely is not.

Looking back, it's been a pretty violent week in terms of film watching for me. I hadn't seen Gladiator for seventeen years, and I've wondered for a long time whether I would hold it in the same high regard I did as a fourteen year old. Especially as the last Ridley Scott film I saw was another of his historical epics, the directors cut of Kingdom Of Heaven (2005), which was boring bordering on insulting. Orlando Bloom sank the film like one of the many boulders falling to the ground in the films' action sequences, which served as a far too infrequent alarm clock for me throughout its seeming three day run time. Gladiator, thankfully, is every bit as impressive the second time round. Ridley Scott has always been a fabulous world builder, (that includes Kingdom Of Heaven) and his vision of Rome is staggering. Russell Crowe can be a figure of ridicule at times, but is on mellowed, low key, Oscar winning form here, and he is terrific. It's not often that a film with so many action fight sequences can hold you on the edge of your seat for all of them, but Gladiator achieves this in spades, and is genuinely thrilling. Joaquin Phoenix is pitifully creepy and superbly effective as the villainous Commodus, and Connie Nielsen provides excellent support, alongside the late Richard Harris in a small role. Apart from perhaps The Martian (2015), it's a long time since Scott has been on top form, and Gladiator reminds you of how good he can be.
