A massive project with Ridley Scott's revival of the Sword & Sandal genre with Gladiator. This was Ridley Scott at the start of the digital age and his first colossal success since Thelma and Louise. Even then it managed to top that. It carried expectations with its overall marketing, starring one of the biggest stars in the world at that point Russell Crowe and would be the first of a handful of collaborations between Crowe and Scott. Pretty much putting Scott back on form after several financial misfires. At the height of the Roman Empire under the rule of Marcus Aurelius, his general Maximus, played by Crowe, leads his army to conquer and secure the nation of Germania with great success. Emperor Aurelius, nearing the end of his life, believes the political state of Rome has been corrupted. Primarily by morally backwards senators and his own son and heir to be, Commodus played by Joaquin Phoenix. Aurelius entrusts Maximus with leading the city of Rome because of his loyalty, but Maximus instead seeks to return to his family after time in battle. Commodus gets wind of this and in his madness becomes upset and kills Aurelius in an embrace and frames Maximus for the crime – sentencing him to be executed. Maximus escapes with his life and rides to find his family brutally murdered by Commodus's men. Left bereft, his wounded self is captured by slave traders. Who sell him to a head gladiator trainer, Proximus played by Oliver Reed who reluctantly trains him to survive in the Gladiator Arena. Proving himself popular with the crowd, they move to the colosseum in Rome where the now Commodus reins emperor to little appeal amongst the senators. Maximus confronts Commodus in the arena and declares he will use what he can to avenge his family, no matter what. Even with the first scene of the battle to conquer Germania, you can get a real feeling of what you're in for. The sequence alone has plenty of sword cleaving, heads rolling, plenty of Braveheart-esque action that it's hard to look away. All the battle sequences - whether here or in the arena are particularly brutal. Choreographed in a way that genuinely makes them authentic and genuine of the period. Backed by the spectacle on-screen is a barnstorming central performance from Russell Crowe. Who really made his name across the world with this film and clearly seeks to take centre stage amongst the rest of the cast and the drama unfolding. With Joaquin Phoenix playing the central antagonist as effectively foolhardy. He plays him as the most exceptional combination of mad and pathetic that I ever have seen and for that, it's entertaining. The film went through several re-writes and production problems, and because of that, the film is far from perfect. There is the dialogue in this film such as the trailer line from earlier like, "Father to a murdered son, husband to a murdered wife. And I will have my revenge, in this life or the next" or "There was a dream that was Rome. It shall be released" that I can't tell if they're genius or plain silly – so I'm settling for both. There are notably CGI inputs within the film. Clearly, are added due to time or unfortunate circumstances that occurred during the production such as Oliver Reed's untimely death halfway through shooting or the remodelling of the Coliseum. With that and Reed's computer-generated death scene, it stands out as jarring. There is a lot of Roman political discussions behind the scenes and does get bogged down with the major plot with Maximus and his revenge. There is a subplot involving Derek Jacobi's senator Gracchus who wants to overthrow Commodus to restore order. However, it primarily takes a step back and is used to move the plot forward through its three hour running time. While there are noticeable flaws that do question its best picture win at the Oscars. Gladiator has enough spectacle, breathtaking scenes of brutal pathos, battle choreography and style that recalls the most influential films of the classic Sword & Sandal genre. It has performers that either act to the point of the camp and those that give the film a really epic and dramatic scope. I really enjoyed this film; while there is enough to take issue with it, the film is so grand on many feats. With Russell Crowe happily taking the challenge of centre stage and leading the proceedings under Ridley Scott's firm direction.

Se dice que el cerebro humano es una máquina y siendo así el caso, toda máquina siempre tiene a alguien o algo que la controla o la guía. Muchas veces pensamos que es nuestra capacidad de razonar lo que permite controlar nuestra voluntad, pero la capacidad de razonar es solo una herramienta que rara vez usamos y se vincula más con las ideas. Lo que realmente llega a controlar nuestra voluntad no siempre es la razón o nuestra consciencia, sino las emociones que suelen ser un estímulo vinculado a nuestro cerebro. Las emociones son un medio que detona muchas cosas que yacen en nuestro cerebro, como el instinto, la razón o la consciencia. Esto a veces da lugar a la ilusión de que tenemos consciencia de lo que hacemos y que tenemos la capacidad de decidir por nosotros mismos. Pero así como los animales siempre se guían por el instinto, con los humanos pasa lo mismo y son las emociones las que nos hacen actuar de forma consciente o inconsciente. Es todo un tema debido a que las emociones pueden hacernos reflexionar sobre nuestras acciones o nublar nuestra capacidad de pensar con lógica. Lo cierto es que las emociones son un arma de doble filo y estas se nutren de experiencias o estímulos externos para ir moldeando lo que sería la personalidad de cada individuo. Inside Out es una película asombrosa que retrata eso a la perfección y es un ejemplo muy claro sobre la psicología infantil. Aunque el número de emociones que yacen en la mente humana son muchas, la película solo utiliza las que son más relevantes. Las emociones escogidas se ven representadas en Joy, Sadness, Fear, Disgust y Anger. Son emociones que tienen bastante peso en la mente de un niño y son la elección ideal para explorar la mente de Riley. Joy es la emoción con más importancia debido a la alegre infancia que Riley ha tenido. Esta niña fue criada con amor y cariño en el ambiente más feliz y sano que los niños más afortunados podrían tener. Esa agradable experiencia es lo que forja las islas que definen la personalidad establecida de Riley y Joy tiene un liderazgo estable debido a que ella se vuelve parte fundamental de la personalidad de Riley. Las cosas se salen de control cuando la familia se muda y Riley trata de adaptarse a un entorno que desconoce. Aquí vemos como sus emociones comienzan a entrar en conflicto, principalmente Joy y Sadness. Joy hace un esfuerzo para mantener a Riley estable debido a que es una emoción muy enfocada al optimismo. Trata de mantener a Sadness a distancia para evitar que afecte de forma negativa a Riley. Pero Joy va entendiendo después que la tristeza es una emoción inevitable porque cuando sentimos un dolor emocional, no se puede evitar los deseos de llorar. Cuando Sadness toca los recuerdos alegres de Riley y se tornan azul, es un claro significado de como nuestros recuerdos más felices pueden hacernos llorar por la nostalgia que provocan. Joy y Sadness son como las dos caras de la misma moneda y es que no puede haber alegría sin tristeza o viceversa. Este conflicto entre ambas hacen que queden de lado al quedar fuera del centro de comando y sin Joy estando presente, Riley debe lidiar con las demás emociones. Fear, Anger y Disgust no pueden replicar la alegría que Joy transmitía y ahí se complica todo. Aquí vemos muy claramente lo que un niño siente cuando es alejado de su hogar al que tanto estaba aferrado. El miedo, la ira y el disgusto son las emociones que más se manifiestan y por eso estas son las que terminan al mando de la mente de Riley. Al no tener una pizca de alegría presente que la ayude a lidiar con su nuevo entorno, Riley se va sucumbiendo más a la decepción. Literalmente su mundo se viene abajo y eso provoca que las islas que definen su personalidad se vayan derrumbando. La película hace una fiel representación del derrumbe mental que puede sufrir un niño tras irse del hogar donde fue feliz. La película tiene muchos elementos cargados de significados psicológicos que la hacen bastante profunda. Uno de esos elementos son los recuerdos como grabaciones que quedan archivadas en nuestro cerebro y que también contribuyen a la construcción de la personalidad. También hay elementos como los sueños, la imaginación o los miedos profundos que también juegan un papel en la psicología. Más allá de ser una película infantil con momentos de comedia, tiene un ingenioso concepto que sirve para entender más a fondo la psicología de un niño que pasa por un momento de infelicidad. Lo que hace al final es dar a entender que la tristeza no es algo que se pueda evadir o remediar al instante. Las acciones de Joy son iguales a las de una madre o una amiga que trata de animar a alguien que está triste. La solución no es intentar hacer reír al niño triste, sino comprenderlo y consolarlo. Joy comienza a darse cuenta de eso cuando Sadness consola a Bing Bong. Entiende que la tristeza es parte de la mente de Riley y no puede dejarse de lado así como si nada. La tristeza puede ser algo doloroso de sentir, pero es algo que todos sentimos en algún momento. Eso es lo que activa esa sensibilidad que nos define como seres sintientes. No sentir tristeza no es del todo posible porque siempre hay aunque sea una pequeña pizca de ella en nuestro interior. No sentir tristeza significaría no tener ninguna otra emoción y eso nos haría seres vacíos. Tanto las emociones positivas como negativas son parte de la programación de nuestro cerebro y sin ellas, solo quedaría la lógica que actúa de una manera más fría y neutral. Al final, el comportamiento humano no es tan complejo una vez entendiendo la maquinaria del cerebro, es solo que actúa diferente según cada individuo y por eso las posibilidades son variadas. Pero Inside Out toma algo básico que requiere de bastante explicación y lo muestra de una manera bastante fácil de entender. Eso hace que Inside Out sea una de las mejores películas que abordan el terreno psicológico. Su mundo caricaturesco de la mente de Riley es una muy buena representación de la mente de un niño y la animación jamás decepciona al momento de crear una experiencia visual asombrosa. Pixar siguió manteniendo intacto su capacidad de crear una obra de arte animada con una historia profunda. Inside Out es otro logro que está a la altura de muchas de las grandes películas que Pixar ha producido. Es recomendable tanto como película para toda la familia como un ejercicio de psicología infantil. Mi calificación final para esta película es un 10/10.

"Inside Out" is a vibrant, imaginative journey into the mind of an 11-year-old girl, where emotions take center stage. The film's unique concept and stunning animation are matched by its heartfelt storytelling. Joy, Sadness, Anger, Fear, and Disgust, each with their own distinct personalities, guide us through Riley's emotional landscape as she navigates a life-changing move. The film deftly balances humor and poignancy, exploring complex themes of loss, change, and the importance of embracing all emotions. "Inside Out" is a must-see for all ages, a touching reminder that even in the darkest of times, there is always a glimmer of hope.

Overall, it is a heartwarming and thought-provoking film that is sure to become a new all-time favorite for many.

Inside Out, the 2015 animated film from Pixar, is an absolute cinematic masterpiece that captures the complexities of human emotions in a visually stunning and emotionally resonant way. Directed by Pete Docter, the film takes viewers on a journey through the mind of an 11-year-old girl named Riley, as her emotions - Joy, Sadness, Anger, Fear, and Disgust - navigate her life during a challenging period of transition. Here are several reasons why Inside Out is a masterpiece: Groundbreaking Concept: Inside Out presents a fresh and groundbreaking concept that delves into the inner workings of the human mind and explores the intricate world of emotions. The film personifies emotions as characters who operate in a control center, known as Headquarters, and their interactions and dynamics are brilliantly portrayed. The film's unique concept challenges conventional storytelling and provides an innovative and thought-provoking approach to depicting emotions on screen. Emotional Depth: Inside Out delves into the complexity of human emotions with remarkable depth and authenticity. It portrays how emotions are intertwined and how they shape our thoughts, memories, and actions. The film masterfully depicts the interplay of emotions, showing how Joy and Sadness are not mutually exclusive, but rather essential for each other's existence. The exploration of Sadness as a crucial emotion, often overlooked in society, is a groundbreaking approach that highlights the importance of embracing all emotions as part of the human experience. Visual Brilliance: The animation in Inside Out is visually breathtaking. Pixar's attention to detail is evident in every frame, creating a vibrant and immersive world that represents the inner workings of the mind. The creative use of color, lighting, and visual cues to represent different emotions and memories adds depth and richness to the storytelling. The stunning visuals enhance the emotional impact of the film, making it a truly cinematic experience. Relatable Storytelling: Inside Out tells a universal story that resonates with audiences of all ages. The film depicts the challenges of growing up, dealing with change, and navigating complex emotions in a relatable and heartfelt manner. It explores the struggles of adolescence, the importance of family and friendships, and the emotional journey we all go through as we mature. The story is presented in a way that is accessible to both children and adults, making it a film that can be appreciated by audiences of all generations. Memorable Characters: The characters in Inside Out are lovable, relatable, and memorable. Joy, Sadness, Anger, Fear, and Disgust are not just caricatures of emotions, but fully fleshed-out characters with their own personalities and motivations. Their interactions are both humorous and poignant, creating a deep emotional connection with the audience. The film's endearing characters are a testament to Pixar's ability to create multi-dimensional characters that resonate with audiences long after the credits roll. Impactful Themes: Inside Out delves into meaningful and impactful themes that are relevant to everyone. The film explores the importance of emotional intelligence, the need to acknowledge and embrace all emotions, and the value of memories and experiences in shaping our identities. It also delves into the complexity of mental health, highlighting the importance of taking care of our emotional well-being. These themes are handled with sensitivity and depth, making Inside Out a thought-provoking and introspective film that prompts meaningful conversations. Finally, Inside Out is a cinematic masterpiece that pushes the boundaries of storytelling and animation. Its groundbreaking concept, emotional depth, visual brilliance, relatable storytelling, memorable characters, and impactful themes make it a film that resonates with audiences on multiple levels. It is a testament to Pixar's storytelling prowess and their ability to create films that are not only entertaining but also thought-provoking and emotionally resonant. Inside Out is a must-watch for anyone!

Pixar's "Inside Out" is an original and emotionally gripping film that captivated audiences before its sequel. The movie offers a unique perspective by delving into the inner workings of a young girl's mind, personifying her emotions as characters. The relationship between Joy and Sadness is a central focus, as they embark on a journey together to not only comprehend each other but also to safeguard Riley from losing herself and her connections. The emotional rollercoaster they navigate, alongside Fear, Disgust, and Anger, provides a compelling exploration of the complexities of human emotions. The film skillfully portrays how memories are stored and the poignant adventure with Bing Bong adds depth to the storytelling. "Inside Out" is a heartwarming and entertaining experience suitable for families and children alike. It encourages collective engagement and fosters an understanding that it is natural to experience a range of emotions. Ultimately, the film conveys a powerful message that resonates with viewers of all ages - that it is acceptable to feel a variety of emotions, including anger and fear. "Inside Out" is a delightful and touching cinematic masterpiece that showcases the universality of human feelings.

A film created both for children and adults, which approaches psychological concepts in an outstandingly creative and accessible manner. The Fantasy, Animation, Comedy, Kids & Family movie ‘Inside Out' (2015), directed by Pete Docter, finds an original way of depicting the processes our mind goes through during the times it is taken over by different emotions and memories. After freshly moving out with her family to San Francisco, 11-year-old protagonist Riley Andersen, whose mind is controlled by 5 basic emotions: Joy, Sadness, Fear, Disgust, and Anger, is having a hard time getting accustomed to the new environment, thus longing for the old days and bringing back the bittersweet memories of her birthplace. This, however, means that the lead in the Brain Headquarters would be taken by Sadness, which is seen negatively by the other emotions, especially Joy, who took the leader role. In her attempt of getting Sadness to step back from the control panel, the both end up sucked out of the Headquarters, accompanying Riley's core memories, which they now have to find a way to restore, in order to keep Riley's personality, all while Anger, Fear, and Disgust are forced to take charge of Riley's life, with disastrous results. What I mostly liked about the movie was the writing, which was done very accurately to portray how emotions and memories help make us who we are. The team managed to illustrate Joy as the most complex emotion, envisioning her as vulnerable and intangible because she was "unapologetically positive". They had the idea about Joy's potential to excessively manipulate youth, creating Riley's "social storms", which is an excellent way of addressing toxic positivity. The key-message that is highlighted throughout the events in the film is that happiness implies feeling sadness as well. Loving someone intrinsically means feeling hurt when we lose them. We NEED sadness in our lives, in order to fully experience joy. We need to cope with painful situations from time to time, in order to grow and become better as a person. ("Crying Helps Me Slow Down And Obsess Over The Weight Of Life's Problems." - Sadness) Another great aspect of the movie is its animation, particularly the character design. The team had been assigned a hard job of visualising and turning abstract concepts into understandable for kids animated characters. Not only have they given every character a unique colour and shape pattern (with Anger being shaped like a brick, Joy - a star, Sadness - a teardrop and Fear being tall and thin like a nerve), but they totally moulded each of the emotions from different textures, as well as even making their moves different, accordingly to their personalities (making Fear to be all floppy and dangling all the time and Anger to always keep his stiff, still posture). On top of that, they even went as far as making Joy glow from within, by creating a "sparkly" aura for her, which took a lot of time and efforts. All in all, I can admit that having watched the animation more than 3 times doesn't make rewatching it every time any less of a tear-jerker. It is hands down a brilliant production, put together for both children and their parents to enjoy. I absolutely recommend it for a family movie night, not only because it's a much simple way of teaching a child about how their mind works, but also because it's a great tool to help people of any age understand themselves more and learn how to figure out their emotions and besides, it offers some great insight into psychology and neuroscience in a highly uncomplicated way.

Pixar has made movies of all kinds - What if toys had feelings, what if insects had feelings, what if monsters had feelings, what if cars had feelings, what if fishes had feelings, what if rats had feelings. And now they have made Inside Out - what if feelings had feelings? Inside Out is probably one of the most underrated movies that Pixar has made. It was the first original Pixar movie which I didn't get to know about when it released (the first such one was a sequel, Monsters University), and I'm really surprised how this movie gets overlooked so easily. The way I see it, this movie is a social commentary about how we perceive life with our emotions. Riley here is a metaphor of us, how we feel when we move to a new place and are unable to handle the new life. In such situations we either feel scared, angry or depressed. When Riley starts crying in class, Joy tries to stop Sadness from ruining her memory with a vacuum but ends up destroying all her other memories. This is another metaphor from our lives, where we end up forgetting all our happy memories in times of desperation. Later on Joy and Sadness are in her memories, where they see Riley's childhood drawing of Bing Bong whom she considered her friend. The plot has been made with a complete sense of nostalgia. When we feel nostalgic, we feel both happiness and sadness at the same time. We are happy because we got to live those times, the time which was better than what we are living at the moment. We are sad because we know that time never stops, and so everyday we are straying further away from when it happened. We will never be able to live the day again, and it shall only stay in our memory. While Joy and Sadness are not present Fear, Anger and Disgust control her. I don't think I need to explain this. Riley has lost all her happiness and does not feel any sadness. Keep in mind she had previously cried in class, which is something very embarrassing for a ten year old child. As a result she does not want to show her sorrow in front of everyone since she fears people will laugh at her, so instead she tries to cover it with anger and disgust. This is just like how we behave when we are depressed but are also too afraid of what others might think if they learn about it. And then there is the memory dump, the place where the old memories are forgotten. This is one of the deepest messages that the movie gave us. To save Joy and Sadness and allow them to get out of the pit, Bing Bong readily sacrifices himself. This is because he had always considered himself and Riley friends, and he was ready to sacrifice his own life for this. It also shows how Riley has now lost the memory of Bing Bong due to her depression and frustration, and it is something she will never remember again. This is a metaphor of how we forget the small details from our childhood which gave us joy once we grow out of the phase. It also symbolises that although Bing Bong has been lost forever, Riley's joy and sadness will always remember him. This is similar to how we get nostalgic whenever we see our childhood writings and drawings. And finally when Joy and Sadness do make it back, then Joy chooses to let Sadness guide Riley. If she wanted she could have guided Riley and make her feel happy about reuniting with her parents. But in that case the moment would have completely lost the impact. So instead Sadness did it, which is why Riley started crying, something she had not done for a long time. This is yet another metaphor of when we are unable to hold our sorrow for too long and burst out crying. As a result her parents are finally able to understand the situation she is in and give her more love. In the end Riley starts feeling happy, since everyone has understood the value of Joy. She was the first emotion that Riley felt, and the one who guided them all in the time of desperation. All the other emotions came to her afterwards, which is why they are not as emotionally attached to Riley as Joy does. Joy knows what is the best for her, just like how we feel the best thing for our life is what makes us happy.
This film was a massive achievement and gave Pixar's first Animated Feature win since Toy Story 3. One Of The Best Movies Of The 2010's.

Summary: Five emotions—Joy, Anger, Fear, Disgust, and Sadness—live in Riley's mind and help her navigate her pre-teen world. Having just moved from Minnesota to San Francisco, she has a lot of changes ahead! Takeaways: Incredible representation and teaching moment for children about our emotions.

Just….how? How did Pixar make another flawless film after three films that I would either consider meh or bad? I just don't get it! Let's just make sure Pete Doctor directs every Pixar movie ever and we will be a-ok. I don't want to talk about all the good things with this movie, because let's face it: everyone has done that. Instead, I want to talk about all the things that this Pixar movie does better than all the others. First, I think this is the best voice cast for any Pixar movies prior or after this. The only one that kind of comes close for me is Toy Story 4, but that's for a different review. Biggest highlight is of course the great work of Amy Phoeler as Joy, it was just spot on. Next, comedy. Seeing how the main character is literally the concept of Joy, I would like to think that this movie was going to be funny. And I was right with this being, in my personal opinion, the funniest Pixar movie. Lewis Black as Anger is just a laughing riot to me. He was hilarious! Finally, how can you not talk about this movie without mentioning the ending, with two big emotional parts that really leave a huge impact. The first being the death of Bing Bong, which feels a little like it comes out of nowhere, but you're going to remember it. And, of course, when Riley comes home from running away and the parents also say that they miss the old home….OMG it's so good! The only kind of problem is that Anger is mainly the reason all the islands get destroyed, and no one addresses it at any moment. But that's minor, and no one is going to be thinking that in their first viewing, I only noticed it in my most previous viewing of the movie anyway. I really think someone should do a deeper dive into this movie, cause it really deserves it. However, I can only praise it for so long. Go to Disney+ and watch this flawless film and to see the best Pixar has to offer!

Inside Out review A heartfelt animated movie, "Inside Out", takes you on a rollercoaster of emotions with creative imagination and a look back at some nostalgic moments we might have had in our childhood. Unlike any other, Pixar studios created an original movie of the emotions that go behind a person's mind and made them into having their own personalities. Focused on the mind of a little girl ,Riley her life is shown as typically any perfect childhood. With the presence of the emotion joy it shows her story of her two loving parents raising her and living the life with many moments that one child creates. Including the building of humor, friendship and playing your favorite sport. But as all children go through the other emotions such as sadness, fear ,disgust and anger it will include her experiences. However, her life takes a sudden turn when she has to move with her parents from their hometown Minnesota to San Francisco. Her emotions will be put to the test in adapting to a new lifestyle they're typically unused to. To start off , it shows the beginning of the first years in Riley's life. Transitioning from stages to the preteens years of her life. This is where she experiences many emotions and personal likeness and dislikeness. Riley is seen on her journey as she experiences all typical childhood memories. From learning how to walk to talking your first new words. Discovering your least favorite meal to favorite toy to take with you everywhere. The laughter you create and the sad moments you experience. The rewarding moments of receiving a good grade to being upset for losing an important game. As Riley is growing she has experienced majority exciting emotions until a certain news comes to her attention. She will be moving from her childhood home Minnesota, where she was born, raised, and grew up to miles away into the city of San Francisco. Despite the change , her emotion Joy makes Riley see all this in a positive way. Meeting new friends, decorating a new room and many more ideas. Arriving at the new location, Riley is quick to notice the drastic change in seeing her new home. Adapting to the city and less outdoor activity is one of the unfortunate changes making her find new adventures. On her first day of school, she is introduced to her classmates and told to talk a bit more from her time back home. As she recalls some of her favorite memories, the emotion sadness touches her favorite memory, changing Riley's memory to a sad moment and turning it into a sorrowful memory. Joy continues to try and make Riley enjoy the new memories. After they had another similar disagreement Joy and Sadness cause the core memories to be knocked from their containers and accidentally vacuumed along with them into Riley's emotional interior. With this problem, it leaves the other emotions Fear, Disgust and Anger to run the emotions until the others return changing RIleys behavior. Throughout the film it shows the many obstacles and challenges Joy and Sadness must go through to reach the headquarters. Following with revisiting old memories and lifelong imaginary friends. It will take a spin through some future glimpse some being Riley's future boyfriend and many more. Overall this unfortunate event turned out to be a better lesson. The emotions appreciating each other's teamwork to help Riley have the best life she could as she grows up. Enjoying the moments one creates as living life with a positive attitude.

Poehler is always great. Smart choice in casting Smith as Sadness. She knows her way around some sad, as she clearly showed on The Office. Kind was a great Bing Bong. Kaling was all over Disgust. And Hader was....well...Hader; which means brilliant and funny and just unbeatable. The movie does tread a bit close to overly sweet at moments, but it never gets too saccharine, sentimental or dark. The personality islands stretched my suspension of disbelief a bit & I can imagine retrospectively them going a different direction with the screenplay in the form of the emotions conquering some sort of antagonist made up of the outburst Riley seemed destined for over the move, but I digress. The movie was still very good viewing material exactly how it was. Kudos!

Inside Out, originated by Pete Docter & Ronnie del Carmen, put out the most unique & fresh story premise since Toy Story in 1995! With Docter directing, del Carmen screenwriting, & Andrew Stanton & John Lasseter producing, they brought back the Pixar hype, coming off the mediocre titles in Brave, Monsters University & The Good Dinosaur. The concept is very creative & original, with a very clever narrative. The story was very well paced, touching up on real world problems, hitting many emotional notes. For a children's film, it is very mature, while still having great family fun. For a fictional tale, this film really made you think after the movie; I'd be lying if I said I never thought about this in my head. The characters were just a blast of fun, with everyone having their own definitive personalities, of course. Our master child if you will, had great real life problems. Her character really reflects on what it's like at that age, and what your emotions feel at most times. If Pete Docter & Ronnie del Carmen wanted to get real crazy, they could've added emotions like, love, loyalty, caring, etc, but they would've had to re-write the whole narrative for that to work. I got myself so invested into Sadness, that I built this real-life hate for her. The screenplay by Ronnie del Carmen, Josh Cooley & Meg LeFauve had plenty of solid laughs, incorporating deep dialogues, speaking about mature, real world issues. It truly goes without say, the cinematography & animations are just as close to flawless as it gets. Everything had amazing detail, being either vibrant or dull while showing great texture. The production designer in Ralph Eggleston created this outside the box world, incorporating terrific set pieces. Overall, I didn't really find to much wrong with this film, other than it being a little slower at times, and it kind of copied that Toy Story feel a little; nevertheless very solid Pixar film, to show that they're back in action, while winning an Academy Award for Best Animated Feature Film.

The question of whether an animated film ostensibly made for an audience of children can gain legitimacy on the level of a dramatic film made for an audience of adults was essentially answered by this film which was a resounding critical and commercial success. It is heartwarming without pushing emotional responses on the audience and provides children and adults with an important message about the nature of our emotions and the need to balance them. Like most Pixar films it has the added benefit of looking great and featuring voice performances from famous movie stars who would actually seem to be trying. Any parent looking to entertain their child for an hour and a half could do much worse than this lovely film that blended mass appeal with deeply personal touches. What really helps the film is that the emotional arc that our apparently perfect main character Joy, Amy Poehler, goes on is effective and ends in a climax that makes her entire journey feel necessary. The realization that experiencing the highs and the lows is important so we can appreciate how special it is to be happy and learn from moments in which we felt sad. Our feelings mirror Joy's feelings as Sadness,, does come across as incredibly annoying at the beginning of the film but we come to realize that she is necessary by the end of the film and her acceptance is a nice moment. Ladies and gentlemen, today I stand before you not to praise a film, but to celebrate a monument. Interstellar is not merely a movie — it is a cathedral of cinema, a towering symphony of sight, sound, and soul. Christopher Nolan did not just direct; he summoned an experience that transcends the screen. The visuals are not special effects, they are visions of infinity itself. The score is not music, it is the heartbeat of the cosmos, shaking us to our very core with every organ note Hans Zimmer unleashes. This is a film that dares to wrestle with the largest questions humanity has ever faced: time, gravity, love, destiny. And it does not whisper — it roars. It drags us into the black hole of despair and hurls us back out into the blinding supernova of hope. At its core, Interstellar is not about space — it is about us. About the fire that keeps humanity alive, about the unbreakable threads of love that outlast galaxies, about the courage to leave the known and step into eternity. Matthew McConaughey’s Cooper is not just a character — he is every parent, every dreamer, every soul that has ever dared to hope for tomorrow. Other films entertain. Interstellar enlightens. Other films tell stories. Interstellar forges myths that feel eternal. Other films end when the credits roll. Interstellar lingers in your bones, in your breath, in your very blood. This movie is not the best of its decade. It is not the best of its century. It is the best ever — because it reminds us of the most essential truth: we are small, yes, but our love, our courage, our will to survive, make us infinite. So when we speak of cinema at its peak, let us not hesitate, let us not falter. The answer is clear, the answer is certain, the answer is eternal: Interstellar is the greatest film ever crafted by human hands. Thank you.

A Journey Through Time, Love, and Memory. I don’t exactly remember the first time I watched Interstellar, but it was probably in 2014 or 2015. I also couldn’t say how many times I’ve seen it because it’s probably too many to count. Today, after almost a decade of loving it, I’m going to watch it for the first time in IMAX, celebrating the tenth anniversary of its release. The movie tells the story of Cooper, who, with the help of his daughter, embarks on an adventure where he becomes the one chosen to save humanity. More than just a simple story based on the typical “hero’s journey,” Interstellar offers a wide range of complex themes to reflect on. It is a movie deeply influenced by science. Since it’s about space travel, the filmmakers made sure everything shown on screen was as realistic as possible. This wouldn’t have been achievable without the work of Kip Thorne. Not only did he manage to bring a realistic black hole to life for the first time, but he also contributed to making other scenes iconic, such as the journey through a wormhole, the visit to Miller’s planet, or the enigmatic Tesseract. I understand that for many people, the ending—or more specifically, the Tesseract scene—can be confusing or even nonsensical. I’ve read many critiques about how love ends up being the key to this story. However, for me, the Tesseract scene and everything related to love in this movie are entirely necessary. I feel it gives the film a touch that is perhaps out of the ordinary or unexpected, something only Interstellar could achieve. Yes, I acknowledge it’s an ambitious story, but connecting the entire narrative through time in Murph’s room, represented as a Tesseract, is simply ingenious. To all this scientific accuracy, a deeply emotional story is added, especially the relationship between a father and his daughter, which is the emotional core of the film. And here lies one of the movie’s most powerful messages: "Love is the one thing that we’re capable of perceiving that transcends dimensions of time and space." This phrase perfectly encapsulates the essence of Interstellar. The powerful score by Hans Zimmer elevates the experience, creating compositions that not only accompany the film but transcend it, becoming a part of popular culture, much like 2001: A Space Odyssey. It’s impossible not to highlight the screenplay by Jonathan Nolan and the direction by Christopher Nolan. Together, they created a masterpiece that, at least for me, wouldn’t have had the same impact without their impeccable vision. In 2014, my father passed away. It was a devastating experience that not only marked my life but also forced me to grow up and see the world from a completely different perspective. When I first watched Interstellar, whether it was that same year or the next, I couldn’t help but relate it to my loss. The story of a father who leaves with the heartbreaking possibility of never seeing his daughter again touched me deeply. The scene where Cooper reunites with his daughter impacted me in a way I had never experienced in cinema before. It was as if, for a moment, I could relive the connection I had lost. Every time I watch it again, those emotions resurface with the same intensity, making Interstellar more than just a movie for me: it’s a reflection of my feelings and memories. Interstellar isn’t simply my favorite movie because I think it’s good; it’s my favorite because of everything it represents for me and the way it marked an important stage in my life. I love the way time is used in this film. So much so that after watching it, time became something I think about constantly to this day. As Professor Brand says: "I'm not afraid of death. I'm an old physicist - I'm afraid of time." If someone like me is looking for movies that blend science, emotion, and a deep message, I can’t recommend this masterpiece enough. It’s a unique experience that not only invites reflection but also leaves a mark in the deepest parts of the heart. I’m sure that, like me, those who watch it will find something special that makes it unforgettable.

I can see why it has a 73%, due to stilted or overly sentimental dialogue, huge chunks of it that don’t make much sense to science, heavy exposition and overall a shitty script. However, it has groundbreaking visual effects that still look good today and are the best practical effects since 2001: A Space Odyssey. Speaking of 2001, Interstellar has been heavily influenced by it. For example: the wormhole, the designs, the blow the bolts part, and the AI. In fact, it’s so influenced that it loses originality. Now, back to the pros. The film is very well acted and the character bond scenes between Cooper and his daughter Murphy are (mostly) when the script doesn’t’t screw up. It also has good tension, a good start and end as well. It also has good scientific accuracy when it makes sense. That’s about all the pros, but there are a couple of last few cons. The film is so damn long and it drags, and by the climax you are so exhausted by emotion tension that it hard is a climax. In fact, it feels like a trilogy, and it’s almost long enough to be a trilogy. It’s already long enough to be 2 films. Overall, it’s fine, but it’s flaws are still massive as hell. At least 2001 had minimal plot holes and made sense if you watched it several times, but this can’t and never will live up to the cinematic masterpiece that changed cinema forever, but it is not bad by any means.

Interstellar is more than just a science fiction film — it’s a deeply emotional exploration of love, sacrifice, and the human spirit. Christopher Nolan delivers a visually stunning and intellectually ambitious masterpiece that reaches for the stars while staying grounded in heart and humanity. The performances are outstanding, with Matthew McConaughey delivering one of his most powerful roles. Hans Zimmer’s score is a force of its own — haunting, beautiful, and unforgettable. Interstellar is another movie where Christopher Nolan hits the ball out of the park. Between the absolute beauty that is the music by Hans Zimmer, and the absolute top-tier acting performance that Matthew McConaughey delivers (especially those yells and cries my god), it is a must-watch for any fan of space exploration. Christopher Nolan's Sci-fi adventure is also surprisingly more science than fiction. The way he uses no sound when you're looking at the movie from space is peak genius. My only real negative is that the movie's length is a bit tedious, and while watching it the first hour is definitely the hardest to get through due to massive exposition dumps. But when you finish the movie, it does feel very complete and everything comes full circle. The pacing is near exceptional, however, do pay attention to details the movie drops because like my algebra class, this story flies like a rocket. Now onto spoiler territory, the concept of wormholes and time dilation is stellar, not pun intended. The way Cooper just sacrifices himself by going into the tesseract felt like the scene was shooting bullets at my heart. And the pure emotion Matthew McConaughey is putting into his voice when he's telling Murphy to stay could make the toughest grown men cry, I'm sure of it. Overall, if you're looking for an emotional space movie, and you're willing to sit through nearly 3 hours of adventure, Interstellar is the perfect watch.

Let me get this straight-this movie is a cinematic MASTERPIECE. The story, the music and score, the acting...everything is SO WELL DONE. In my personal opinion Matthew McConaughey completely carried this movie. He delivered such a remarkable and jaw dropping performance that left me speechless at the end. Are we even going to talk about the scene where he watches the videos from his kids?! I was in awe-and honestly a little unsettled-the whole scene because of how real his performance felt, as if he truly was a father mourning the lost years of his kids' lives, like Cooper. The way he could tap into such raw emotion, make himself cry, and deliver such an eerily authentic portrayal was almost frightening in its realism. He also had such a great onscreen bond with Mckenzie Foy that even left me in tears as we watched their relationship and bond unfold and eventually save humanity. There were many aha! Moments and the adrenaline was indeed pumping as I was mesmerized and pulled deeply into concentration on the movie. So why is this movie missing two stars? Don't get me wrong Christopher Nolan completely delivered and made me feel all the emotions he wanted viewers to feel, and while I did enjoy it, it is not a movie to take lightly. There is a lot of informational thrown at you and a lot of words the average movie watcher might not understand. I get it, it's a sci-fi movie, and a great one at that, but the end completely messed with my brain and had me scavaging the internet and Youtube for explanations. Because of this, I feel like this movie is one that you really can't talk to your friends while watching or get up to go to the bathroom since you will miss critical information. Also, there were some scenes and monologues that felt a little too long and didn't do much to drive the story forward. Overall, I thoroughly enjoyed Interstellar. It's an incredibly captivating and emotional film that kept me hooked from start to finish. While it can be a bit confusing at times and definitely a lot to take in, I would absolutely recommend it to anyone who loves thought-provoking, visually stunning movies.

Stupid people like this. In the end, Nolan didn’t really know which direction he was going in, and I think he shoved in as much physics stuff as he could at the end movie which is what I believe He really wanted to make -which was an intelligent film about the fifth dimension or whatever - so he shoved it all roughly in in the last hour or so of the flic. watched Joker (2019) from director Todd Phillips and starring Joaquin Phoenix, Robert De Niro and Zazie Beetz. The film is about Arthur Fleck and he has a laughing disabilitie. He wants to be seen but he feels like he's not. Arthur did some horrible things and eventually became the Joker. The story is dark just like some other DC films. It's a good thing that it's dark because how else would you tell the story of the Joker. The story really focusses on Joker and not on other heroes or villains in Gotham like Batman. Joaquin Phoenix was fantastic as Joker. He played Joker so good that he's in my top 3 of Joker performances of all time. His acting made him so good. The laugh that he did was incredible. The amount of weight he lost for this role is insane. You could see his bones so that is how skinny he was. His dances were also great. The stair scene when he's dancing on them is the best scene in the movie. The make-up artists did an amazing job with the clown make-up. The clown make-up and his costume is different from other Jokers. The sets and film locations are beautiful. The darkness and sometimes the bright colors looked great in every scene. The music is also great. 'That's Life' is perfect for Joker. I got goosebumps from every scene when 'That's Life' played because it felt epic. I would highly recommend this film for everyone who loves DC Comics and superhero movies. The story is great and the acting is fantastic. The Oscar was well deserved for Joaquin Phoenix and always remember: "That's Life."

Visually, Joker stands out with its dark, gritty background contrasted by flashes of color, symbolizing Fleck’s rare moments of joy, mostly through his unsettling laughter. Overall, Joker is a chilling and unforgettable experience. It gives us a version a version of the Joker that feels authentic and human, not just a comic book villain. Phoenix’s performance and the film’s striking visuals leave a lasting impact.

Joker explores the central character's gradual descent into madness. The film's realistic approach to the making of the most famous - or perhaps infamous - madman in comic book history is both unsettling and haunting.

Joker es un personaje que ha perdurado bastante en el tiempo desde su aparición en los comics hasta trascender en diferentes medios como películas y dibujos animados. Lo cierto es que este personaje se ha vuelto uno de los más populares marcando la cultura popular. Hacer una película sobre él iba a ser algo dudoso, pero terminaron haciendo una película muy prometedora con un estilo del Hollywood clásico. Joker ha tenido diferentes versiones y diferentes orígenes que no son muy claros cuál es el auténtico. El mismo Joker no tiene recuerdos de su propio pasado, así que hay muchas posibilidades. Aquí decidieron hacer una historia de origen mucho más realista, con un Joker bastante humano y con una interesante crítica social que cuestiona la moral establecida por la sociedad. Joaquin Phoenix brinda una asombrosa actuación encarnando un Joker bastante trágico. Aquí el icónico villano es alguien lleno de dolor que vive en una ciudad donde no hay sentido de justicia y los menos afortunados son los que sufren más. Joker, bajo la identidad de Arthur, es alguien que vive en los sectores bajos y que sufre problemas debido a la inestabilidad social. Al inicio es asaltado, luego es despedido injustamente y cuando tiene la oportunidad de defenderse de otros asaltantes sus acciones son consideradas un crimen contra la sociedad. Es peor cuando Arthur va descubriendo la verdad sobre su madre y sobre las figuras que él consideraba ideales como Thomas Wayne y Murray Franklin. Arthur se convierte en una bomba a punto de estallar y al perder acceso a los medicamentos que lo mantenían estable por culpa del recorte, Arthur va perdiendo el control. Se puede concluir que Joker es una víctima de las circunstancias y la poca atención de una sociedad injusta ha impedido que él obtuviera la ayuda que necesitaba para no convertirse en un psicópata. Arthur se da cuenta de que está viviendo en una sociedad injusta donde a nadie le importa su dolor y por eso decide dejar salir su lado más salvaje. Si bien Joker puede parecer un psicópata, todo lo que sucede a su alrededor demuestra que él tiene razón. A veces la gente se deja llevar tanto por la idea de lo bueno y lo malo implantado por la sociedad, que no se toman la molestia de plantearse si todo en la sociedad está bien. El detonante es cuando Joker acaba con la vida de tres empleados de Wayne Enterprises que lo han atacado y las noticias retratan a estas personas como víctimas. Eso hace que Joker quede pintado como un vilano, pero gana apoyo por parte de los menos afortunados. Ciudad Gótica tiene un serio problema económico y vemos como la gente harta de su situación actual decide recurrir a la violencia, inspirados por Joker. Tiene sentido porque de qué sirve respetar el orden en una sociedad donde no hay justicia para los más desafortunados. Las acciones de Joker contra sus asaltantes son vistas como algo malo, pero nadie sabe lo que ha pasado realmente. La realidad es que no se sabe a ciencia cierta si la víctima de un asesinato fue alguien realmente inocente, porque detrás de un crimen hay una razón. Si es por algo que la víctima hizo para dañar de cualquier forma a su futuro victimario, entonces el crimen está justificado. Las acciones de Joker están justificadas, si se deja de lado la moral. Muchas veces alguien comete un crimen contra la sociedad debido a que la sociedad lo trato injustamente o nadie respondió el grito de auxilio del individuo cuando más lo necesitaba. Eso justifica bastante las acciones de alguien, por más que la sociedad lo vea como algo malo. Analizando el paradigma completo, la verdad es que no existe tal cosa como lo bueno y lo malo y tampoco la persona inocente como tal. Si las acciones de Joker fueran algo totalmente repudiable, no hubiese tenido apoyo de los manifestantes. Así que si un psicópata comete tales actos porque al ver su historial se descubre que no ha tenido un trato justo por parte de la sociedad, entonces esa persona tiene razón en hacer lo que hace. Si el ser humano como tal nace con la capacidad de hacer lo inenarrable, entonces la sociedad misma es quien lo forja y lo corrompe de forma directa o indirecta. La misma sociedad es la que crea a sus monstruos. Joker termina siendo una excelente historia de origen, desarrollando su trasfondo psicológico y haciendo que podamos entender sus acciones. No es una película de acción, pero es un gran drama psicológico con una buena historia que explica como Ciudad Gótica fue invadida por el crimen antes de la llegada de Batman. Una sociedad inestable da origen a una ola de crimen insostenible. No se sabe si Thomas Wayne era un hombre humilde, pero Bruce demostró ser mejor al no recurrir a métodos extremos cuando se convirtió en Batman. Aunque sea una historia independiente sin relación con el universo cinematográfico de DC, Joker logra ser una de las mejores películas de DC Comics que nos ha brindado una de las mejores versiones de este icónico villano. Mi calificación final para esta película es un 10/10.

This is an amazing take on the Joker's origin story. Some may say that it isn't really a Joker movie and is basically just a random bloke called Arthur Fleck masquerading as the Joker, but the way I see it, it is. The Joker's philosophy is that all it takes to become like him is one bad day. This movie basically embodies that philosophy. All it took Arthur to begin the path to becoming the Clown Prince of Crime was one bad day where he got fired from his job and beaten up by 3 people on the subway. It fits the character well. Even if Joker 2 takes the plot in a very different (and still good) direction, this movie still holds up as an amazing Joker origin story.

Joker - 10/10. Masterpiece. I don't like calling films masterpieces or incredible very often, but I also can't get this film out of my head since I watched it. Joker is one of those movies that sticks with you. For what it was trying to do (creating a serious drama driven comic book film), the film passes with flying colours. First and foremost, this is NOT a movie for everyone. It's rated R for a reason, and it's subject matter and the manner that the film progresses quite possibly be off putting for some people. It's a harrowing experience to see how Arthur Fleck lives from the beginning of the film, and it is also deeply disturbing how he transforms from a depressed outcast to becoming a horrible and maniacal villain. Joaquin Phoenix takes what Heath Ledger brought to the character in The Dark Knight, and creates a different look for the character. You progress from feeling bad for the guy to becoming genuinely terrified of what he will do/think next. Joaquin does an amazing job of creating the journey of Arthur with just subtle changes to his body language and delivery of dialogue from scene to scene. Todd Phillips does a spectacular job of reinventing his visual and story telling methods (even with the obvious nods to previous Martin Scorsese films). The cinematography is incredible and the music is haunting. It's a film that holds your attention and refuses to let go. Probably the best film of the year and one of the best of this decade! Well done!

Joker 2 alternative theories: Was Harleen a honey trap? Did anyone consider the potential for deceit, when the bully guard (Played by Brendan Gleeson), in an uncharacteristic kind act, effectively takes Arthur to meet Harleen (Lee) at the choir? As the film progresses, we find out from Arthur's Lawyer who Harleen really is. Did she lure him in with him with a false personal story or do they really have a connection, a Folie a Deux? Arthur questions Harleen who further reels him. Arthur then ignores his lawyer's motherly warning. At this point he totally smitten with Harleen. In my opinion Arthur's lawyer was the only character who genuinely cared for him. She was wise to the institution harm at Arkham: she understood the neglect and torture that was inflicted on Arthur by the guards, and psychological torment belitting him, e.g., they mock how easy he was to catch, through his unstrategic crime to kill someone live on TV. Arthur's lawyers pleads insanity and builds a defense case highlighting his abusive childhood, to help him avoid the death sentence. It was Harleen that drove the wedge between them. Ultimately Arthur fires his lawyer and represents himself dressed as the joker. He talk about folie! Harleen being a honey trap would also explain how she manages to bend the rules of the prison regime over and over again. For example gaining private access to his cell where the films' sex takes place (its depiction is the antithesis of porn: bleak and over in a flash). The only problematic scene would be the fire during the movie night at Arkham. If Harleen was really working as some kind of undercover agent, then would it be plausible for her to go that far to destroy property? It was a reckless move but it paid off in gaining Arthur's trust. On reflection it was another example of her managing to evade consequence to her actions and instead is released from the jail. Ultimately Lee breaks up with him, at the very moment that their fantasy to live together as a family could have become true. She appears to be disappointed in him, for taking an unprecedented move to admit in the court room that he's not mentally ill. But I think that was exactly what she wanted to happen. I think she was a honey trap, planted whether working alone or undercover in cahoots with New York state and her doctor father, on a mission to lead him to Arthur to his demise. I think sabotage Arthur's chances of winning his freedom during the trial: the State of New York versus Arthur Fleck.

"I love this movie, I think it’s brilliant and not only Todd Phillips' best film but it’s exciting because it’s on a frontier. And that’s usually where very good things happen. Todd and Scott Silver’s screenplay has that relevance that occurs when work is authentic and not derivative. We find Arthur disturbing and poignant simultaneously. He’s both child victim and adult perpetrator. Both are true, as is the case with most schizophrenics. That both are true is uncomfortable. We find ourselves in a fugue state. It’s counterpoint. It’s why Arthur and the film’s impact sustains so strongly in memory. To build on all of this, and for Joaquin Phoenix, Todd, and Scott, to impact upon on this powerfully is a difficult accomplishment." - Michael Mann Hard to argue with one the greatest filmmakers ever.

Although Joaquin Phoenix did a fantastic job of portraying the writer and directors vision of the Joker, I believe the idea of the Joker has been too Humanized. Heath Ledgers Portrayal of the Joker brought us up to the level that could be considered human, just the right balance, in the world of super humans. Fast forward to Jared Leto's Joker in suicide squad and hes a gangster with gold chains and tattoos, Overly humanized. This movie obviously tries to introduce the Joker as just a regular guy, twisted by his upbringing and the lack of respect from the outside world. Yet, it fails to depict the Joker as the brilliant evil genius that he is. In comics and other movie sources it is made clear that the entity known as the Joker has never been diagnosed with any mental illness because of how he can manipulate the therapists trying to label him. In front of one therapists he will portray himself as a cool and calculated sociopath, to another a manic depressive with suicidal tendencies, to another a hysterical, maniacal person completely lacking control of his emotions or a cold blooded Psycopath. It was this skill of manipulation after all, that turned Harlene Quinzel into Harley Quin, the Jokers protege. So, great acting throughout the movie, unfortunately failing due to the script missing the essence of The Joker.

Arthur is the ultimate joker, an unreliable narrator with a fractured mind, his story told through inventive camera angles and Edward Hopper lighting. His mind dances unravelled through an atmospheric score and underlining lyrics of popular songs, as events that might have happened unfold before us, horrific, darkly humorous, clues to his background scattered like the detritus of a ransacked room. Phoenix gives us as much nuance as we can stand, colouring in right up to the corners, his physicality informing us as much as his words, earning every accolade he received for this. Joker does not conform to the standard fare of comic-inspired film, concentrating on a tiny corner of a dirty laundry basket rather than any kind of wide redemptive or narrative arc. It is not joyful or predictable, but it does leave a lasting impression of a truly troubled mind told in an intriguing way and is a significant contribution to the comic-book oeuvre

Watching this again five years later, which ironically, this film had just turned five years old yesterday (today being October 5th), and I will say what I'd thought this was indeed a masterpiece, I kinda had some second thoughts since I'm a little wiser as I'm getting older. Not to say that this is a terrible movie, but rather still one of the best movies out there when it was released in 2019. We can already say that the acting was amazing, the cinematography was amazing, even the setting was amazing. Not to mention how this sets in about mental illness and social problems when it came to delivering the message from Arthur himself. Funny, if you remember a cartoon called Duckman, I couldn't help but imagine the character of the same name say the same lines as Joker made while also keeping that line in mind since we live in a dysfunctional internet culture of today. Sure, you could say society is as mucky as it normally does, whether you're sane or not. I am aware about Joaquin Pheonix's strict diet to play the role, but one thing I have to say is that it is a job, after all. Sometimes you're dedicated to do as request or turn it down and walk away as it's always been such for decades, whether you work with Hollywood or anywhere else, big or small. Now, about some things that does cross my mind is having to think about the actions that Arthur has done off camera does have me guessing, but technically you'd have to use your sense of imagination to figure out if certain events had happened or not like when he was at his ex-girlfriend's apartment room. Also, I was curious on the jump cut at the ending, which I won't spoil too much, but curious how Arthur had gotten to that after a certain time of event as the ending rolls on. But I digress. For the most, I still had a fun time, had some good laughs and does keep me laser focused from start to finish after seeing this again for the second time, especially before I see this sequel for myself. I'd give it nine dancing Arthur's out of ten. 9/10.

This is a very difficult movie to review. Which is both a good thing, and a bad thing. I went in with an idea that this was going to be a strange movie, and I was not disappointed. The positives were pretty much the same as the previous Joaquin Phoenix interpretation. A stellar performance, although getting a second Oscar for playing the character would probably be a reach. The story was well written, and although I wasn't a big fan of the first movies ending, it seems that this one a slightly better one, despite the fact that it came from out of the same left field corner alley. I was also skeptical of the fact that it's a musical in the truest sense of the word. Although I admit I was pleasantly surprised that chose to use mostly classic show tune numbers. I'm not a huge Lady Gaga fan, but I thought her and Phoenix played well off each other, resulting in a "decent" vocalization performance on both parts, which gave the movie a realism that you don't usually see in musicals. I would have liked to have seen Lady Gaga portray a more "traditional" rendition of Harley Quinn, but it's hard to say if she would have been able to pull it off, and still keep a realistic tone in the movie. The fact this, like the previous movie, was only loosely based on the DC comics, was not an issue, although anyone watching this with said notion will be disappointed as they probably were if they saw the first. I'm not sure if this is a primary interpretation of either of the films, but they seem to imply that certain people, for better or for worse, have the ability to "polarize" communities as a whole to the point that they lose control of those that are captivated by the mere existence of their fixation. C+

Acting and brilliant general filmmaking saves it enough for me to give it a star and a half, but this movie loses itself in the message it hopes to leave. It clearly wants to send one message, but actually sends another, and me being a critically thinking person with a full functioning brain that actually gives a F, this movie me had me cringing and raging inside for how blind the filmmaker was when he did this. And I’m glad the sequel just proved my point.

Joaquin Phoenix’s performance inspires empathy in the viewer and I was along for his journey for the first 2/3 of the film. The ending feels rushed though and it’s hard to believe that all these people would be inspired by him after just one murderous interview.

*Joker* is a brilliant character study with Joaquin Phoenix delivering an outstanding, raw performance. The film's strength lies in its exploration of Arthur Fleck's descent into madness, blending gritty drama with Gotham City's eerie atmosphere. I love how it keeps you guessing what’s real and what’s imagined, making the audience question Arthur's reality. However, it's a strange choice to connect it to the DC universe, as it feels disconnected from Batman or the traditional Joker character. Story-wise, it heavily mirrors *Taxi Driver* and *The King of Comedy*, which makes it feel less original, but the execution still works. Despite being a bit overrated, it remains an engaging watch with strong visuals and intense emotional depth. It may not be groundbreaking, but *Joker* offers an easy-to-follow, gripping character study that holds up on multiple viewings. Phoenix’s performance alone makes it worth watching again and again. 3.5 stars.

Watching "Joker" in two sessions on two different planes might not have been ideal, but honestly, even under perfect conditions, this movie feels like it’s trying too hard to be profound. The hype set the bar so high that it was almost inevitable it wouldn’t live up to it. It’s an interesting slow burn, but the suspense just wasn’t there for me, and I struggled to connect with the characters. The whole movement sparked by the murder of three guys on a subway felt a bit far-fetched. And Joker’s descent into madness? It seemed like it was only half-baked, more a stumble than a true spiral. Most frustrating of all, it felt like nothing really happened throughout the movie. And if nothing’s going to happen, you’d at least hope for some standout characters to carry the weight, but even that fell short. It’s one of those films that tries to be deep but ends up feeling a bit hollow.

As a psychotherapist and a person with mental illness, I can say subjectively, that anyone who's suffered mental health issues will understand the depth of this movie. To those who have an empathetic nature, has gone through mental illness (and is aware of their illness, aka not in denial), Joker will resonate with you as it depicts a character who you may see in yourself.

I can understand why this can be polarizing. I can see why someone would see this potentially as glorifiying Mass shooter types, or painting mental illness as old fashioned Norman Bates crazy stereotypes. But it's much deeper than that an is a deconstructive character study done 70's style on what could drive someone insane who is responsible. Is it nature or nuture? Are we born mad or made mad or a bit of both? Even after the great plot twist it's never clear what is real and what isn't. It's a portrait of madness and the fallout asking uncomfortable questions. It's one of the darkest if not the most disturbing comic book movie ever made. But also an All Time Classic. Really the only issue is it fits ALOT of ideas into under 2 hours extremely well but it can feel a stuffed more than bloated but the editing is really good still. It's cinematography is inspired by the likes of Se7en and Fight Club and does it admirably. The supporting cast is very good but almost comedically over the top "Evil" and mean. But Phoenix steals the show and gives an amazing performance. It is fasinating watching him go down the rabbit hole of madness and the deeper it goes the more riveting it becomes. Everyone should give this a try once. It will 100% leave an impression even if you don't love it.
