Summary: In 1912, a huge and fancy cruise, the Titanic, was voyaging from England to New York. It was a cruise that carried people's dream of new life in America. There is also a romantic story that happened on the cruise. There are two main characters in the movie, Jack and Rose. Jack was born in a poor family. He won the Titanic's tickets from a bar. He was full of dreams and was excited about having a new life in America. Rose was born into a wealthy family. However, her family went broke a few years ago. Her mom wanted to maintain a wealthy life, she wanted Rose to marry a rich guy who Rose doesn't love. Rose was reluctant to get married to him and she decided to jump off the boat to kill herself. However, Jack walked by and saved her. At first, Rose wasn't happy about Jack saving her life. For Rose, a life of pretending to be rich seemed superficial to her. She almost felt suffocated in life like this. Jack's appearance was a beam from the sun to her foggy heart. Jack showed to Rose that even the people who lived in the third class were not rich, but they owned the real happiness. Meanwhile, Jack and Rose got to have more chances to stay with each other, and they fell in love. While they were dreaming for their future in America, they didn't know that the danger was getting closer to them. Analysis: Titanic is a movie with romance and history. It is adapted from a real story. All the story starts from Rose's memory in the Titanic. By recalling the scene, it brings the audience back to 1920. Through highly restored scenes from the Titanic, the audiences can experience the life on the Titanic. I think Titanic was popular at that time for three reasons: fancy special effects, the romantic story, and that it was based on a real story. Wallace Hartley was a real violinist who played with his band their last song on the Titanic and in their lives. That is the most unforgettable scene for me: while the boat was sinking, the violinists started to play ‘Nearer, My God, to Thee' on the cabin. They didn't rush to try to get a spot from the rescue boat, instead they chose to play this music to calm down people. Here are two different aspects of why they chose to play this song. Firstly, the song can bring people peace. Secondly, the song mentions the coming death, and it acted like a funeral song because most of the people would die because of lack of rescue boats. Through playing this song, people can realize that death is not the end and God is always watching over his people, and they would be able to meet God and their beloved one. Eventually, the violinists sacrificed their lives for playing music to the people. Titanic is not just a movie but also a society, it shows people from different social statuses experiencing that disaster together. There are heroes and villains. The violinists are heroes. Their music brought the Spirit and peace to the boat, and they even all sacrificed themselves in the end. Critic/Recommendation: I think Titanic is an awesome movie, not only because of its reality but also based on what they wanted to share with the audiences. Titanic is a romantic movie with a disastrous ending. In addition, I think the director is good at mixing every element in the movie. As I mentioned before, the Titanic is not just a cruise, it also represents a society. Through people's words and actions, I can learn from history and experience the love between Jack and Rose. The special effects were a hit at that time. When the movie came out, special effects were not as common as now, also most people have never been into that background of the early 20th century. The movie lets them have the chance to experience life at that time which can make the audience more involved in the movie while watching it. Even after twenty-two years have passed its special effects are still a legend. Due to its perfect story and fantastic special effects, I rate it 5/5 stars. I highly recommend people go watch the movie.

James Cameron's Titanic is the kind of big budget blockbuster that makes audiences both love and hate Hollywood films. From the hate angle, it feels deeply unsettling to use a horrific maritime disaster as the platform for a love story involving the dashingly handsome artist Jack Dawson (Leonardo DiCaprio) and the wealthy but dissatisfied Rose (Kate Winslet). In addition, like so many Hollywood epics, it tends to drag on much longer than it needs to. On the love side, there's nothing else quite like it. It's a well-executed and thoroughly engaging exploration of the struggle between the classes and the idea of enduring, eternal love that will draw the viewer into the drama regardless of whether the audience wants to be drawn in or not.

Not one person survived with a Third Class ticket. The rich negotiate, offer leverage, hide in spacious lifeboats and Rose survives instead of Jack. This is an accurate story but should be received as a tragedy instead of a romance. What lines of memorable dialogue are there? They pass the plot along, the ship must sink. There is a trend happening more now than ever where people hate on classic films for the sake of hating because they are classic films and loved by the majority of the public. As I start this "Re-watching and Re-visiting films" series, I will be repeating this many times. I do not quite get people's issue and "beef" (to put it less sophisticated) with Titanic. Is it one of the best movies of all time? Not quite. Is it a really well-done film that stays in our minds years and years after seeing it for the first time and if it is playing on a TV channel, you put it on? Why, yes. I understand the bother with a "pointless" love story plot line for dramatization but what's funny is that it works with the strong performances and magical chemistry between DiCaprio and Winslet. But what I want to focus on in Titanic is the little scenes. There are many scenes where the tears uncontrollably fall down your face. Towards more the last section of the film where the boat officially sunk down, there is a shot from sky above of all the passengers screaming and flapping around the water. Up close, it is suffocating hysteria and from afar, it is just one sound in the middle of the gigantic ocean. People being left to die (as there are themes being shown of the lower class being purposely cast aside and the rich prioritized) and people coming to terms this might be their last breath on earth. Playing with camera angles intensifies a small scene for a viewer and makes that small scene stand out in a 3 hour movie.

Titanic came out over 20 years ago and to this day is still a huge phenomenon. I watched several previous versions of the Titanic story leading up to this viewing to increase my appreciation of the spectacle that is this movie, but it actually backfired a little bit as what it showed was that this version was more derivative than I had previously imagined. There had long been a definitive, historically accurate movie about the ship sinking and there had even been one where a love story is told while the ship sank as a backdrop. The good news is that this knowledge didn't really sully my experience at all; they did a FAR greater job here at capturing the sense of wonder that the ship provided its passengers, the love story was more compelling, they took the right creative liberties by creating high-quality antagonists and they did a better job creating a sense of foreboding with the sinking alluded to throughout the runtime. The main thing I disliked was the way they framed the narrative as nearly all of it felt clumsy, from the Old Rose narration sounding like she was reading off a piece of paper to the treasure hunting guy having conflicting attributes with his clearly-expensive effort to dig up artifacts trumped by knowledge he would've had beforehand, that some ship passengers loved each other. The movie would fall a bit short from a purely technical standpoint but it's still one of the greatest viewing experiences ever provided by film as a medium, so I'm giving it the full score here. Woohoo!

Titanic - 10/10. It baffles me that people bash on this film just because it became a cultural zeitgeist. Titanic was everywhere and anywhere. People who've never seen movies went to watch it and owned it on VHS/DVD/Blu Ray. People who were cinephiles would go watch it in theaters almost monthly. History on the Titanic got a huge boom of interest and museums began to invest more and teach more on what happened on that fateful day. The movie won 11 Academy Awards, tying the record. It became the biggest box office hit for a while, and the first billion dollar movie. It ran in theaters worldwide for nearly a whole calendar year. And all this, was thanks to the genius and perseverance of a dedicated filmmaker, James Cameron. When the usually R rated content director wanted to make a sweeping PG-13 epic that was gonna be half a romance film and half a disaster film, many looked at him different. But Titanic became a cultural film because it connected with people in many different ways. Not only was it about romance and the ship, but it was also about classism, sexism, ageism, greed, and the bright and dark shades of human nature in desperate times. Its such a deep blockbuster, and one that wasn't designed to have sequels. All of this is encapsulated within one film, and its so impressive that every time you revisit this film, it feels like you enter a journey and are transported to those times. Cameron's film is one of those movie you need to see to believe!

Cameron's exquisite attention to detail in regards to the sets, costumes and of course the innovative CGI is what makes this film work. Also helping it along is the wonderful Kate Winslet as Rose and Leonardo DiCaprio as Jack. She and Leo DiCaprio have amazing chemistry together as the fictional couple from different worlds. The way that sci-fi and horror director Cameron turns the Titanic into a monster when it hits the iceberg is something to see - the last fifteen minutes of the sinking is awesome to watch. What doesn't work? With so many amazing real life stories of the passengers and crew of the famous ship, James Cameron decides not just to ignore them, but create a rather foolish and preposterous tale about a missing diamond and filling out the supporting cast with cliched, silent film type characters (the snooty mother, an odious fiancé, a greedy publicity hungry shipping magnate) which takes away from the natural power of the famous shipwreck. Billy Zane is particularly bad here in a Snidely Whiplash-esque turn here as Rose's fiancé Cal Hockley, complete with an equally nefarious sidekick/right hand man played by David Warner. And Frances Fisher as Rose's mercenary mother Ruth, gives an icy, one-dimensional performance, like a scheming matriarch in a nighttime soap opera. Fisher is a much better actress than that. And Kathy Bates is criminally wasted as Molly Brown, who was probably the ballsiest passenger onboard. Her presence is muted here, but Bates works with what she's got. And the crew and second class passengers are pretty much ignored. We are left with the wealthy, entitled and elitist first class passengers and the naive, plucky and resourceful immigrants in third class. No one else counts. I also like Bill Paxton in his role as the fortune hunter Brock. But the film is infectious fun despite its glaring flaws; it's impossible to not get caught up in the sheer spectacle, from the treasure hunters using cutting edge technology to inspect the Titanic's rusty bones, to the excitement of a glamorous ocean liner making its maiden voyage, to the tragically dramatic wreck. The film still manages to impress.

Forrest Gump isn’t just a movie—it’s a cinematic masterpiece that has earned its place as one of the most beloved films of all time. Directed by Robert Zemeckis, the film is filled with warmth, emotion, and unforgettable moments that make it feel as close to perfect as cinema can get. At the center of it all is Tom Hanks’ legendary performance as Forrest, a man with special needs whose pure heart, determination, and unique perspective allow him to stumble into some of the most iconic events of the 20th century. But what makes this film so powerful isn’t just Forrest’s story—it’s the way the movie introduces and builds the people around him. From Bubba and his dream of a shrimping business, to Jenny and her complicated but heartfelt relationship with Forrest, to Mrs. Gump and her tough-love wisdom, every character feels fully alive. Zemeckis allows us to engage with them, understand them, and ultimately fall in love with them. The writing and storytelling are nothing short of brilliant. The script blends humor, heartbreak, history, and hope seamlessly, creating a film that feels timeless. Iconic lines like “Life is like a box of chocolates, you never know what you’re gonna get” have become part of our cultural language, but the movie goes far beyond catchphrases. Its military storylines, its portrait of love, its message about perseverance and destiny—it all resonates on a deeply human level. What could have easily come across as offensive or unrealistic—a film centered on a man with special needs—was instead handled with such grace and sincerity that it brought audiences together. Rather than dividing, it united viewers through empathy and love, showing us that innocence and kindness are often stronger than intelligence or power. Nearly three decades later, Forrest Gump still holds up as one of the greatest films ever made. It’s a movie you can rewatch endlessly, and each time it finds a way to move you all over again. Verdict: A masterpiece. If you’ve never seen Forrest Gump, you might as well be living under a rock. This is a film I recommend to everyone, and it will always remain a gold standard in heartfelt storytelling.

Forrest Gump is my second favorite movie of all time, and for good reason. Sometimes, life is full of unexpected twists, just like Forrest Gump famously said: “Life is like a box of chocolates, you never know what you’re gonna get.” This movie is not just about one man’s life but a journey through significant historical moments and a wide range of emotions. Forrest Gump is directed by Robert Zemeckis in 1994 with a protagonist Tom Hanks as Forrest Gump, a man with below-average intelligence but a pure heart. With a mix of historical fiction, romance, and inspiration, this movie blends humor, drama, and profound life lessons. Forrest Gump is a must-watch film that beautifully captures themes of love, and destiny. The story follows Forrest Gump, a kind-hearted man with a low IQ but an extraordinary ability to be in the right place at the right time. From his childhood struggles with bullying and leg braces to becoming a college football star, serving in the Vietnam War, and even influencing major historical events, Forrest’s life is nothing short of remarkable. Along the way, he remains deeply in love with Jenny Curran his childhood friend whose turbulent life contrasts sharply with Forrest’s. He also forms meaningful friendships with Lieutenant Dan Taylor, a war veteran, and Bubba Blue, a fellow soldier who inspires Forrest to start a shrimp business. The screenplay masterfully blends humor, emotion, and historical events to create an engaging narrative. The story is unpredictable flows seamlessly, keeping the audience captivated from start to finish. The film’s ability to integrate Forrest into real historical footage such as meeting U.S. presidents adds an immersive and unique touch. Tom Hanks delivers a career-defining performance as Forrest, embodying his innocence, sincerity, and optimism effortlessly. His portrayal won him an Academy Award for Best Actor and remains one of the most memorable in cinematic history. The artwork is beautiful and realistic for that era. The background music sets the mood very well. Along with songs from famous artists of that era such as Elvis Presley and The Beatles. The editing in the story was flawless. For the Themes and Messages is about Destiny vs. Free Will, Love & Loss, Perseverance & Optimism, Historical and Social Commentary. Forrest Gump is more than just a movie, it’s an emotionally moving, deeply inspiring, and beautifully crafted masterpiece. With its timeless storytelling, outstanding performances, and thought-provoking themes, it remains relevant even decades after its release. Who Would Enjoy It? -Fans of drama, romance, and historical fiction. -Viewers who enjoy character-driven stories with emotional depth. -Anyone looking for a motivational and feel-good movie. -And it is suitable for people aged 13 years and over because it is a movie that contains scenes about drugs, sex, and inappropriate language. If viewers are under 13 years of age, adult supervision is advised. The best types of movies are the ones with some underlying message or meaning. To me, this movie portrays the message that a person is best defined by the actions they take. The character of Forrest, played by Tom Hanks, symbolizes this message. Hanks is perfect for the Forrest role in this movie and his acting combined with a great soundtrack and beautiful picture makes this such a wonderful movie. I also think that the storyline is very well-written, encapsulating the idea that ordinary (even less than ordinary, in Forrest’s case) people can accomplish and do remarkable things. The character of Forrest is one of my favorite movie characters I have ever watched, and my favorite scene comes when it is revealed how he spent his shrimp earnings. Forrest invested and gave away his millions of dollars, and chose to spend his time cutting grass for free. This specific scene symbolizes the character of Forrest and the movie itself, proving that any person is capable of great things and gratitude. Lastly, this movie has some remarkable quotes. Some of these stuck with me, I will list them below. "Life is like a box of chocolates, you never know what you're gonna get.” I like this quote because it symbolizes the randomness of life that can come to anyone. "But at night time when there was nothing to do and the house was all empty, I'd always think of Jenny.” I like this quote because it shows that there will always be times of peace and quiet, and what you do with that time can define you as a person. "My mama always said you've got to put the past behind you before you can move on.” This is just a good life lesson. I’d rate it 9.5/10.

Filme: Forrest Gump: O Contador de Histórias Assistido: 1-9-24 Elenco:       Modelo: ventura omance Duração: 2h 22m Ano: 1994 Minha opinião: Depois deste filme, começou uma nova fase na vida de Hanks de Sucesso atrás de Sucesso e solidificando sua carreira Brilhante. A Espera de um Milagre, O Resgate do Soldade Ryan, Náufrago, O Terminal, O Código Da Vinci, Prenda-me se For Capaz, Elvis,.... Um filme Espetacular. O filme começa com Gump criança que usa armação para poder andar, considerado com QI abaixo da média, parece que tem autismo, quem sabe se o filme nos dias de hoje seria colocado. E com o inicio das aulas o único amigo(a) é Jenny (Wright) e pelos outros sofrendo bulling. E Jenny se torna seu amor platônico e real, do ínicio ao fim do filme. Onde em todo o filme ela segue seu caminho de loucura. Onde ela quando criança seu pai a molestava, assim crescendo com seus traumas. Mas ela foi a que incentivou Gump no inicio depois as coisas vão acontecendo em sua vida, como um tabuleiro de xadrez. Ela diz para Gump “CORRA” e com este comando ele entra no time de Futebol Americano e na faculdade. Até o dia que se alista no exercito, e la faz amizade com Benjamim (Mykelti) que conta as estoria dos camarões e chama para serem sócio, mas ele acaba morrendo. E Salva Tem. Dan da morte. Após isso ele começa a treinar tênis de mesa sozinho e acaba indo para China e vencendo representando os EUA. Ganhando medalhas do presidente, entrevista ao lado Lenon, até o dia que o exercito o dispensa. Gump vai atrás da promessa dos camarões. Mas nada da certo até o dia que vem o tem. Dan e eles acertam e se tornam milionários e ainda acionista da Maçã. Neste períodos ele encontra com Jenny, mas sempre acaba seguindo seu caminho Hipe, drogas, Rock Hall, até o dia que aparece na sua casa de Gump, que estava lá desde morte da sua mãe. Jenny vai embora novamente até o dia que retorna, mas com uma surpresa pois ela trouxe seu filho Forrest (Osment) e ela com uma doença terminal pela vida que levou. Até quando ela parte, e Gump vive com seu filho que relembra da sua infância. Uma interpretação impecável de Hanks, de Robin Wright, Gary Sinise, Mykelti. Um elenco que teve muita sinergia. Roteiro e enredo Parabéns, como algo fora do comum, que digo da estoria, se torna um sucesso. Vale apena assistir? Com certeza Nota: 10

I hadn't seen this movie in a very long time, and as I recall, I never thought it was all that, so had no desire to rewatch it, but decided to last night. I think I enjoyed it more this time. I remember being put-off by what I originally conceived of as the antifeminist message—that Jenny had to love an intellectually and emotionally challenged man or she would die. But this time I felt the message was just more that she was so incredibly damaged from the abuse she suffered as a child that she had no idea how to love a man who was good to her. (I also felt this time that the child clearly did not belong to Forrest, but that she thought the kid would be best of with him so when she found out she was dying, she told that little lie). Anyway, a decent film and did make me tear up a bit. I still think Shawshank was the better movie and should have won all the Oscars.

As Forrest's exploits are expertly (and oftentimes nonsensically) woven through some of history's most famous events, the messages of the film - that love knows no bounds and that ordinary people are capable of extraordinary things - remain in their purest forms throughout the film. Hanks' portrayal of this unlikely American icon lends credulity to his character's extraordinary feats, keeping the unbelievable nature of his exploits closer to fantastical rather than inconceivable. Gump's genuine nature grants us the perfect accents of simple humor and heartwarming emotion, simultaneously ameliorating the audience from over-the-top gags and overly saccharine moments. The iconic soundtrack stretches across decades worth of music's most influential names, though at times can be a little too "on-the-nose". The selections could have benefited from a deeper dive into some of the artists' catalogs in certain spots. Understandably, the idea was to capture certain moments in time through music, and in that regard, it does its job perfectly. When infused with Alan Silvestri's epochal score, the film's musical presence becomes another character whose presence we should all appreciate. "Forrest Gump" is what every moviegoer should get treated to whenever they step inside a theater, and its rare mastery of storytelling is why it remains one of the 20th century's classics. It should continue to stand the test of time in the minds and hearts of movie lovers.

"Forrest Gump stands as a cinematic masterpiece, a tapestry of human experience intricately woven with threads of humor, heartache, and profound wisdom. Tom Hanks' portrayal of Forrest is nothing short of extraordinary, embodying the character's simplicity with a nuanced grace that tugs at the heartstrings. The film's brilliance lies in its seamless navigation through decades of American history, as witnessed through Forrest's unique lens. From the Vietnam War to the Watergate scandal, each historical chapter serves as a backdrop to the protagonist's unassuming yet impactful journey. It's a poignant reminder that even the simplest among us can leave an indelible mark on the tapestry of time. What truly elevates Forrest Gump is its ability to evoke a spectrum of emotions. Moments of laughter are juxtaposed with scenes that delve into the profundity of life's unpredictability. The iconic line, 'Life is like a box of chocolates; you never know what you're gonna get,' encapsulates the film's central theme – the beauty found in embracing the uncertainty of existence. Alan Silvestri's enchanting score complements the narrative, evoking nostalgia and punctuating pivotal moments. The film's visual storytelling, aided by groundbreaking special effects that seamlessly place Forrest in historical footage, adds a layer of authenticity that is both captivating and innovative. Forrest Gump isn't just a movie; it's a timeless exploration of the human spirit. It invites us to reflect on the interconnectedness of our lives, the power of love, and the profound impact we can have on the world around us. In a world often marred by complexity, this cinematic gem stands as a testament to the enduring beauty found in the simplicity of a life well-lived."

Excelente película, en mi opinión una de las mejores películas de todos los tiempos y el mejor trabajo de Tom Hanks. Es una película mágica, que cuenta una historia hermosa de una persona que paso por muchas dificultades en su vida pero que la sigue viviendo al máximo a pesar de todo y hasta logra ser la influencia (con o sin intención) de varias cosas utilizadas en un futuro como la frase "shit happens" o la camiseta con una cara sonriente; además de la gran cantidad de celebridades o estrellas que logro conocer debido a su alocada vida. Es una cinta muy entretenida, que pueden parecer varias historias que se conectan con el protagonista, contando como fue su vida desde que era un niño que sufría bullying hasta que es mayor y paso por varias cosas como ir a la guerra, jugar al ping pong, jugar al futbol americano, etc. Además, es un chico que cuenta con algunas personas importantes en su vida, como Jenny, su amigo Bubba, su madre y el teniente Dan; y al final termina perdiendo a gran parte de estas personas. Algo que hay que destacar es el soundtrack de Alan Silvestri, teniendo algunos temas que se volvieron icónicos. Por otro lado, los efectos son excelentes, por ejemplo en las escenas en las que conoce celebridades como a John F. Kennedy o John Lennon, las cuales están muy bien hechas. Por ultimo, las actuaciones son brillantes, principalmente Tom Hanks, quien en mi opinión hace el mejor papel de su carrera; además, tiene buenas actuaciones de Gary Sinise, Sally Field y Robin Wright. En conclusión, una excelente película que creo que todos deberían ver porque cuenta un historia hermosa, mágica, emotiva y entretenida que queda en los corazones de todo el que la vea. Muy recomendada.

There's a scene in Forrest Gump that encapsulates the film. Jenny, who is dying from an STD, asks Forrest if he was scared in Vietnam. Forrest then tells Jenny about the stars in Vietnam, the sunset he saw from the shrimp boat, and the mountain lake from his cross-country run. Forrest even mentions a desert sunrise so stunning that he didn't know "where heaven stopped and the earth began." Forrest sees the beauty in everything. He took a question about fear and spun it into poetic gold. This is why we love him. His attitude and childlike wonder towards life represents humanity at its best. Something to aspire to. Based on the novel by Winston Groom, and adapted by the amazing Eric Roth, Forrest Gump is an opus about the power of optimism and how to endure life's pain. Forrest Gump masterfully depicts the hero's journey with amazing plotting and structure. It's a journey I want to take time and time again. Robert Zemeckis is a pro storyteller and crafts each scene with the right amount of humor, nostalgia, intensity, and human emotion. The framing device of Forrest telling his story is perfect. We get to live inside Gump's head and see a heightened version of reality from his mind's eye. It's a dream, fairy tale, magic trick, and memory all in one. Forrest Gump grew up in Greenbow, Alabama during the 1950s. Zemeckis paints Greenbow with Norman Rockwell idealism. Childhood is a time of wonder but Zemeckis doesn't let us live there Scott free. Forrest has to deal with a single mother, a low IQ, leg braces, and bullies. Zemeckis is genuine about the story he's telling. Only a director that earnest can pull off a joke about Mrs. Gump banging the school principle and make it work. All of these characters come from a place of Southern Boomer love and affection. The genius of Forrest Gump is the contrast between Forrest's naive innocence and Jenny's cynical life crisis. We get two opposite journeys in one. Forrest is the vanilla protagonist and audience stand in. He's an ordinary man who experiences the extraordinary. Forrest Gump is wish fulfillment. He's a country boy that sees the world. He's the feather that floats in the wind. Forrest isn't focused on the destination, he's just in love with the journey. His heart may pine for Jenny and Greenbow but Forrest makes the best of where he is. He embraces the now. James Cameron once said that a movie doesn't have to be possible it just has to be probable. The byproduct of Forrest's low IQ and social awkwardness is that he has extreme focus. He can assemble a gun and play ping pong better than anyone. He can run from coast to coast and keep a pace. Forrest pops up in so many historical moments that we half expect him to reveal the Watergate scandal that led to Nixon's resignation. This explanation is enough for the audience. In the army, Forrest finds a second family. Bubba becomes a brother to Forrest. "I gotta find Bubba" is the ultimate heartbreaking plea. Lieutenant Dan becomes the mentor and father figure that Forrest needs. Dan is a no nonsense bad ass who challenges Forrest and grows to respect him. There's a scene where Forrest is recuperating at a VA hospital by enjoying ice cream. This moment is interrupted when Forrest receives a stack of "Return to Sender" letters that he sent to Jenny. This is classic Zemeckis. He gives you bliss one moment and breaks your heart into a thousand pieces the next. With Zemeckis we never know what we're gonna get. Lieutenant Dan goes through the crazy character development that Forrest doesn't. After getting both his legs amputated, Dan becomes a shell of himself. He's a cigar-chomping drunk with a crisis of faith. He hates that Forrest saved his life. Dan has a lot of reinventing to do. When Forrest buys a shrimp boat, Dan agrees to be his first mate. There's an amazing scene where Forrest and Dan survive a hurricane. When the storm clears, the duo have more shrimp then they know what to do with. Peacefully floating in the water, Dan thanks Forrest for saving his life and then makes his peace with God. Dan gets new legs and a new lease on life. Jenny spends the whole movie running from her demons. She tries to fill the void left by her abusive childhood and only half succeeds. She returns home to Greenbow but she's not ready to stay. She's not done running. Forrest is crushed and the only way he can deal with his pain is to run. He runs for three years and eventually his heart begins to heal. When Forrest sits at the bus stop at the beginning and end he's wearing the old pair of Nikes that Jenny got him. To Forrest, the little things in life are the big things. At the end of Back to Future, Marty is rewarded with a better life. Some people don't like this ending but this is classic Zemeckis optimism. Forrest goes through hell and he gets rewarded for it. This is the hope of the film. We want to believe that every disadvantage contains an equal or more powerful advantage. We want to believe in the spiritual concept that all things work together for the good. When Forrest reunites with Jenny it's the healthiest we've seen her the whole movie. She has finally found peace. At the end, Forrest walks his son to the bus stop and the movie comes full circle. Zemeckis doesn't just wrap a present, he puts a bow on top. 1994 was a great year for film and against distinguished competition Forrest Gump won six Academy Awards including Best Director, Best Screenplay, and a second Oscar for Tom Hanks. Is Forrest Gump really that good? I believe it is. Alan Silvestri composed an amazing score and the film features a remarkable song list from the 1960s and 1970s. Forrest Gump may not be for everyone but it hit me right where I live. Robert Zemeckis and Eric Roth's ode through 20th century America is as sweet as a box of chocolates. And that's all I have to say about that.

It's not every day that a movie released will still maintain relevancy nearly three decades later, but Forrest Gump has proven itself to be a timeless movie and a blockbuster of its time. I have watched this movie numerous times and have somewhat of a habit of going back and watching this movie at least once every couple of years. I love the way that Forrest Gump's story is told by Forrest's naivete so that throughout the story we can infer what happened through the imagery and inferences. To those who are on the fence about watching this movie because it looks like it would be dull, I urge you to reconsider. This movie is extremely close to what I would consider being a masterpiece of its time due to the versatility of the scenes, the story that it wistfully guides you through as if you were spectating Forrest Gump's life in real-time, and my favorite part of this movie, the character development. There is not much more that I enjoy in a movie as much as I enjoy seeing a character grow and change throughout a movie whether a character reaches a goal and is a different person because of it or even witnessing a character's descent into madness. This movie's character development had me enthralled with the storytelling skills and development of the characters Jenny, Forrest, and Lieutenant Dan. Jenny's character in this story plays an important role in Forrest's life as a love interest that he is constantly chasing through the bounds of the common trope of unrequited love. In the beginning, Jenny found Forrest as a genuine love interest, but throughout the years she grew distant from him perhaps looking for something more than what she had. We watch Jenny go on these adventures throughout the film as if she were searching for something that she had been missing or dreaming about but she never really seems happy with herself. She has then reunited with Forrest again near the end of the film and it is at that point that she finds out that what she truly missed out on was a comfortable life with Forrest. Tom Hanks performed the role of Forrest Gump exceptionally well to the point of becoming synonymous with him. Forrest does have some character development, but not in the traditional personality changing way that we often see in films and shows. Forrest changes others through his interactions, but he remains the same innocent and kind-hearted man as he was in the beginning. Lieutenant Dan however is a very strong case of character development done right. Upon meeting Lieutenant Dan, he appears to be a goal-orientated man with confidence, but after having a traumatic event happen to him, he feels degraded and cheated from his destiny by Forrest. However, we can witness Lieutenant Dan recuperate from his tragic downfall and come back stronger, and happier than he was before through events orchestrated, albeit accidentally, by Forrest again. Again, this movie is the basis of what I would consider being a perfect example of movies done right with the correct execution of character development. For this reason, Forrest Gump has solidified itself in the rankings of my favorite movies I've watched to date.

Among other things, Robert Zemeckis' Forrest Gump asks the following question: in life, are we guided by destiny or is life a random series of events? If you can ignore the fact that the movie is shamelessly manipulative at times, it is a wildly entertaining ride through the life of the mentally disadvantaged Forrest Gump. It covers the time period from the ‘50s to the ‘80s, with the titular hero inadvertently immersing himself in Vietnam, Watergate, Chinese diplomacy, and a variety of other scenarios. The film is helped along by a great performance from Tom Hanks, a colorful story, some fantastic dialogue, wonderfully creative visual effects and a memorable soundtrack. While it seems to be fashionable these days to slag the movie, it remains a powerful piece of filmmaking almost thirty years after it was released.

Combining elements of comedy, motivation to satire. Forrest Gump, a film directed by Robert Zemeckis and starring veteran actor Tom Hanks, manages to instill very deep moral values ​​in every scene. The film, which was made in 1994, deserves to be called the best film of all time. The film, based on the novel by Winston Groom, tells the story of a man named Forrest Gump. Forrest who since childhood was considered a stupid child with an IQ of 75 has a unique life story. Having been belittled by everyone, Forrest continued to go forward with a stupid label by others against him. Forrest Gump is an epic film that makes the audience realize that behind the shortcomings there are many advantages in each person. The nature of the main character Forrest Gump can certainly be a good example for everyone. So what kind of traits can we imitate from Forrest Gump's character? 1. Loving Parents We can see how much Forrest Gump loves his mother. In the film he is willing to swim from the ocean and run through the city when he hears the news that his mother, Mrs. Gump is sick. Forrest Gump certainly realized that his mother's struggle could not be reciprocated with anything. The mother who always supports Forrest in the midst of his shortcomings makes Forrest realize that his mother is his hero 2. Always positive and optimistic Although Forrest Gump is known as an idiot character in the film. But his stupidity is not a problem for a Forrest. He keeps going and always thinks positive. Don't complain and always try. In the film, Forrest Gump always shows his positive nature in any situation and in any crisis. Can you copy this? 3. Never give up and be generous Of course, if you have watched the Forrest Gump movie, you will realize how generous the character Forrest Gump is. After he managed to create a shrimp company with the initials of his friend Bubba Gump Shrimp Corporation. He and Lieutenant Dan, a character frustrated by his disability during the Vietnam war, started a shrimp fishing business. After repeatedly failing to catch shrimp at the beginning of his search for shrimp. Forrest Gump didn't give up. He tried many times and of course failed many times. Until one day his shrimp catch was successful and together with Lieutenant Dan he managed to create the most successful shrimp fishing company in his city. Forrest Gump, who seemed to be a very successful businessman, didn't feel happy.Until finally he handed over his company to Lieutenant Dan and gave his income to the Bubba family, his best friend who had motivated him to start the shrimp fishing company 4. Good promise holder Bubba is a black man whom Forrest met when he joined the military. Forrest and Bubba's relationship is quite unique. It's said that their friends don't seem too close. But this is the other side of the Forrest Gump movie. Bubba, who when he was with Forrest, always talked about the world of shrimp, of course, for many people who listened to him talk about shrimp, it was quite boring. But not with Forrest, he always listened to Bubba talk about shrimp and Bubba's dream that when he finished his military duty he would set up a shrimp company with Forrest. But unlucky, Bubba died on the battlefield. Until it was left Forrest with his promise with Bubba to set up a shrimp fishing company. Instead of burying the promise. Forrest kept his promise to his best friend Bubba by successfully founding a very successful company, the Bubba Gump Shrimp Corporation. Forrest's promise and dream with Bubba finally came true 5. Don't forget friends and best friends in any situation The next Forrest Gump trait that you can emulate is that he always helps anyone. You can see it in the film even in critical times when Forrest and his troops are attacked by the enemy. Had separated well with his best friend Bubba and Lieutenant Dan. Forrest did not want to stay silent, he finally returned to the battlefield and saved his friends who were still alive even though they were full of wounds. No exception for Lieutenant Dan who he saved even though he had to lose his leg in the end. Lieutenant Dan, who was frustrated with his disability, was angry with Forrest. But again Forrest did not want to forget the Lieutenant Dan. He accidentally meets Lieutenant Dan who turns into a beggar in a wheelchair. Forrest, who at that time was a hero of his country, certainly felt sorry for Lieutenant Dan. Over time Forrest managed to raise new hope for Lieutenant Dan by getting him to join his shrimp fishing company. Lieutenant Dan joins in until Forrest gladly hands over the company he built to Lieutenant Dan. An extraordinary trait. 6. Faithful in love affairs Not only comedy and motivational elements in the Forrest Gump film. Of course the romance drama between Forrest and Jenny can be a good example for everyone. The single love story between Forrest Gump and Jenny seems to break the audience's heart when they see how loyal Forrest Gump is to Jenny. Although he had been separated several times for a long time and many times Forrest Gump was rejected by Jenny and many times he saw Jenny's bad side. Forrest Gump remained standing faithfully waiting for Jenny. He still loves Jenny with all her flaws. Until finally he and Jenny got married. But the marriage did not last long because Jenny had to leave the world early due to a virus due to her wild life. Forrest Gump must have been very sad, Jenny's long-awaited love finally ended briefly. For Forrest Gump, Jenny was his first and last love. 7. Good father At the end of the story, Forrest Gump who has become a father, gives his best love to his son. He applies the love he gets from his mother who is also a single parent. Without Jenny's presence, Forrest Gump performed his role appropriately to be a good father to his son. This film deserves to be watched and imitated in our daily lives because there are so many valuable messages and moral values ​​that we can follow in this film. This film, which has been nominated for 13 Academy Awards, you must watch this at least once in your life!!!!

Watching Forrest Gump is a bit like watching your 6-year-old niece's gymnastics routine: charming at first, even mildly impressive, but more and more tedious as she performs again and again. Yes, Gump is a good-hearted, simple man who inadvertently changes the world and helps the people around him - the film shows us this, over and over again, for more than two hours. One suspects that with lesser acting it would be impossible to get through, but Hanks' committed performance and equally stellar work by the supporting cast make it good enough when you're in the mood for brainless schmaltz.

The book this movie was based on, which I haven't read, was more satirical in tone, which explains the basic concept of a simpleton managing to have such great influence on American politics and culture without being aware of it. His childhood leg problem inspires Elvis Presley, he unintentionally mocks Lyndon Johnson's showing off his surgery scar, he goes to Maoist China to play Ping-Pong, he unintentionally starts the 1970's jogging fad, etc. The book's story was purposely contrived; the movie plays everything straight. As for those who claim the movie glorifies stupidity, the phrase "Stupid is as stupid does" has a more honest message, namely that stupidity isn't an inability to think but an unwillingness to. As for the movie's uncomplimentary view of the counterculture, there was plenty of bad as well as good about the 1960's-divisiveness, racial and other hatred, violence, the spread of venereal diseases, etc. But not only the left gets skewered. Remember the scene where the legless Dan described being told he could "walk with Jesus"? The acting serves to make the movie work, just as Monty Python's comedy worked by everyone being able to play it all straight.

Forrest Gump is a 1994 film directed by Robert Zemeckis and starring Tom hanks and Robin Wright. Forrest Gump (Tom Hanks), a slow but simple man from Alabama takes us through decades of his life, which includes various historical settings but all the while his heart is on Jenny (Robin Wright Penn), a childhood friend. FORREST GUMP was released and quickly became a huge hit and ended up winning many Oscars. Today, for whatever reason, the film seems to be hated by many people because of the movies it beat out. I've never really understood putting too much importance on Oscars or any other award show and I really don't understand why one movie must take a beating just because of what films it beat out. ORDINARY PEOPLE takes a beating because it beat RAGING BULL. Something like DANCES WITH WOLVES takes a beating because it beat GOODFELLAS. Then there's FORREST GUMP that takes a beating because it beat out PULP FICTION or THE SHAWSHANK REDEMPTION. As far as the film itself goes I think this is a great one. I've always liked how the film took a look at a simple person's life and a simple person who is always in very big situations yet never really understands it. There are countless bits of dialogue that are remembered by mans and they've entered the public IQ but the one dealing with knowing what love is is the one that always caught my attention as far as what this film is about. To me Gump goes through all these historic things yet it's always his love for Jenny that is the heart of the picture. I thought the story itself was quite great and especially how we take a look at American history through the 60s, 70s and 80s. I know some people make this a political movie but I've always found that to be rather foolish. The film has a wonderful soundtrack to highlight the various eras that are shown and we also get some clever use of CGI to put Gump in the presence of people like JFK and Richard Nixon. The screenplay hits all the right notes and there's no question that technically speaking the film is impressive. Then there are the performances that really make the movie. Hanks picked up his second Best Actor award and while I personally would have given it to Paul Newman for his performance in NOBODY'S FOOL, there's no question that Hanks is great here. He certainly nailed that "simple" man and there's not a false moment in the performance. Gary Sinise is wonderful in his role as is Mykelti Williamson in his small bit. Robin Wright Penn is the perfect opposite to Hank's character and Sally Field is good as well. No matter what people say, FORREST GUMP is still a wonderful little gem that has a lot of great things in it.

Forrest Gump is one of those feel-good Hollywood movies that grows on people within age. Based on a novel, the film follows the life of Forrest Gump (Tom Hanks), a mentally-handicapped savant from Greenbow, Alabama who rides through waves of the second half of the 20th Century: meeting Elvis Presley, joining the University of Alabama's football team, meeting Presidents Kennedy, Johnson and Nixon, enlisting in Vietnam, joining the ping-pong tournament, fishing for shrimp, and even jogging across the United States. During which he starts an on-again off-again relationship with Jenny (Robin Wright) and they have a child, get married and she dies of AIDS. While not without its sappy and corny moments, the film has plenty of heart in all the right places. The best parts are Hanks's performance and his epic 30-year journey edited with him in present-day sitting on a bench talking to random passengers. It's so mesmerizing hearing his Southern accent as he tells his story and it makes you want to listen to him even more. The worst parts involve Jenny, who I believe takes advantage of Forrest and leaves him in the dust to pose for Playboy, snort cocaine, and join the Black Panther party. She doesn't even notice the fact that he traveled from one country to another just to see her again. On top of that, Jenny is probably the least interesting character in the movie as she holds accountable for its sugary syrupy moments and cliched lines. Despite my complaints, Forrest Gump is still a great all-American breakfast with just the right amount of eggs, bacon and short stacks. (4 Shrimp with Ping Pong Paddles out of 5)

Forrest Gump (1994) is a movie that follows a man, Forrest Gump, with a low IQ who keeps accidentally finding himself in many important and historical moments. This movie is full of intertextuality with real life, such as the Vietnam War, The Black Panther Party, and the Ping Pong diplomacy. I believe that the intertextualities in this movie help the director present the movie's political stance. A movie's political stance is the thoughts that the movie tries to instill in people's minds to either teach them something or make them act a certain way. In order for a movie to have a political stance, it needs to have an ideological position – a system of beliefs. The politics and ideology of Forrest Gump are ones that advocate for simplicity and patience. Through the form and content – where the form is the way the movie is shot and content is the dialogue – one can notice that the movie is saying that leading a simple life, being an honest person, and not complicating things like Forrest, can lead you to accomplishing great things. The movie's political stance is not one that can be noticed easily since it relies on macro narratives, where the audience need to look at the bigger picture and link all the events of the movie together to understand what idea the movie trying to spread. It feels like the movie itself was conscious of its themes of simplicity, but Forrest was not. Forrest was often unaware of the importance of the events happening around him such as the Hippie movement or being dragged into the Black Panther Party, however, everyone else around him was. Jenny, Forrest's love interest and his first ever friend, was aware that the successes he reached to, such as being awarded the Medal of Honor and being really rich due to his shrimp business, was due to the fact that he was an honest man who always did the right thing. Forrest's patience for Jenny to love him back ended up in them starting a family. Just like any other movie, Forrest Gump relies on elements such as irony, foreshadowing, and architecture to present its plot and political stance. I found it ironic how when Forrest started telling his story to people, he explained the origins of his name to a black woman. This is ironic because he was named after his ancestor, the founder of the The Klu Klux Klan, a hate group that targeted African Americans and supported slavery. The irony of this scene, however, sets the floor for the political stance to start forming, since Forrest thinks in the simplest way to the point where he did not realize that it is probably not a good idea to tell an African American woman that he was related to the founder of the KKK. Forrest Gump relies heavily on foreshadowing. It was foreshadowed that Forrest and Jenny would eventually end up together from the beginning of the movie when Jenny and Forrest were sitting together on a tree branch and then Jenny holds his hand and tells him to stay with her a little longer. When Jenny and Forrest went to different universities, Forrest would visit her in her university. One time, Forrest saw her in a car with another man and they were engaged in a sexual interaction however it seemed to hurt Jenny. Forrest stepped in and pulled the man away from her even though he could have ended up in a fight with the man. This scene foreshadowed two important things, first, Jenny would end up in a lot of abusive relationships, and second, Forrest will always be loyal and protective of her no matter how much it would hurt him. Moreover, the movie also relies on referencing itself in order to foreshadow upcoming events. This can be seen in the scene when Forrest rides the bus on his way to the army and no one would let him sit next to them except for Bubba. The movie is refencing itself because a similar scene happened in the beginning of the movie when Forrest rode the bus on his way to school and only Jenny would let him sit next to her. This self-referencing foreshadowed that Forrest and Bubba were to be best friends and that Forrest would remain loyal to him. Moreover, the movie uses its architecture to foreshadow and build up its political stance. The architecture of a movie consists of the buildings and the lighting of the movie – in other words, it is the design of the movie's environment. Forrest and his mother live in a big house in the rural Alabama. Rural areas are characterized by simplicity and honesty. Forrest living in a simple environment foreshadows that Forrest himself will grow up to be a simple man. Since children are the product of their environment, and the accomplishments of one are a product of who they are, then the environment you grew up in causes your accomplishments. Forrest living in a rural area helps the movie's political stance because all of Forrest's accomplishments are due to simplicity. Forrest Gump is a brilliant movie that uses many aspects of films and links them together in a unique way to present its political stance. The political stance of Forrest Gump is leading a simple life and having patience can lead you to accomplishing great things. The movie presents its politics through the use of irony, foreshadowing and architecture. I really enjoyed this movie and I would recommend others to watch it.

" You can reach everything if you only want to!" "Forrest Gump" is just an epic movie that touches people throughout all ages and generations. The simplicity of this film is the main reason to love it. This is a movie of a heart-breaker of oddball wit and startling grace. There's talk of another Oscar for Tom Hanks.In a college dorm with Jenny, who lets him touch her breast, the virginal Forrest ejaculates instantly, losing her interest and his self-respect. In the Army, Forrest saves his captain (Gary Sinise), whose legs are later amputated, and the captain resents him. Forrest is everything we admire in the American character - honest, brave, loyal - and the film's fierce irony is that nobody can stay around him for long. Zemeckis doesn't fall into the trap of using Forrest as an ad for arrested development. He knows the limits of a holy fool who can't understand the hypocrisy of postwar America that this picaresque epic so powerfully reveals. The peace-love pretensions of the '60s are skewered as neatly as the greed decades that follow. But there is something of Forrest that Zemeckis would like to see rub off on us: his capacity for hope. It's an ambitious goal in this age of rampant cynicism. Godspeed.

On July 6, 1994, Paramount unveiled Robert Zemeckis' Forrest Gump in theaters. The Tom Hanks satire would go on to win six Oscars at the 67th Academy Awards, including best picture. The Hollywood Reporter's original review is below: Forrest Gump is not stupid. Although his IQ is 75, he sees the world far clearer than most. Through his decent, childlike eyes, we too see things in a less confused and muddled way. In this cheerfully straight-arrow moral tale, Tom Hanks stars as the "wise fool" Forrest Gump and delivers yet another Oscar-level performance. Paramount will win sensational box office with this Robert Zemeckis-directed film. Raised in the '50s in rural Alabama by a single mother (Sally Field), Forrest, being "different," must fend for himself, struggling against not only perceived expectations but boyhood bullies. He unwittingly finds that he's blessed with a talent — he can run like the wind, which wins him a football scholarship to play for Bear Bryant at the University of Alabama. And there's no stopping him after that. An uplifting saga about one young boy's earnest and good-natured attempts to overcome his disabilities, Forrest Gump is also a cheeky social satire of the past 40 years of U.S. social-political history. Eric Roth's screenplay, adapted from Winston Groom's novel, nimbly intertwines Forrest's life with the seminal social events and players of the past several decades. Unassuming Forrest, with his golly-gee enthusiasm and inbred decency, encounters the likes of Elvis, George Wallace, presidents Kennedy through Nixon, Dick Cavett, John Lennon and Abbie Hoffman as he graduates from 'Bama, fights in Vietnam, competes in international ping-pong, founds a shrimping company, engages in philanthropy and jogs cross-country. Contrasting Forrest's unassuming innocence with the upheavals and rancor of the times, the film is a wisely goofy commentary on the stupidity of smartness. While Forrest's foray's into the dens of the big and powerful are cheekily amusing, the film ambles along over a deeper, darker layer: Forrest's love for his childhood girlfriend, Jenny (Robin Wright). An abused child, Jenny's life path is a desperate wander to find solid ground. She falls prey to every social movement and fad of the times; unlike Forrest, whose unwavering strength and sense of right and wrong protect him from being caught up in social slides, Jenny's genuflections reflect her lack of firm values and inner confidence. To some extent, one could argue that Jenny symbolizes most of us. If any criticism might be leveled at the film, it is that its most heart-wrenching moments are too adeptly skirted, but, then again, that's in keeping with Forrest's strength. Highest praise to Zemeckis, who has reached a higher maturity plane with his gracefully, technically eloquent direction. Carrying his torso in an erect, straight-arched manner, Hanks' body language is all-telling. With each strange or perplexing situation, Hanks erupts with the smallest twitch or turn, signaling Forrest's deep-seated disapproval or, in special other cases, his gleeful, thankful wonderment. Mykelti Williamson, as Forrest's simple-minded G.I. buddy, is also outstanding, while Gary Sinise is sympathetic as Forrest's bitter platoon leader, legless after the Vietnam War.
